column2: the abdominal wall represents the boundaries of the abdominal cavity. The abdominal wall is split into the anterolateral and posterior walls.

column1: There is a common set of layers covering and forming all the walls: the deepest being the visceral peritoneum
column2: which covers many of the abdominal organs (most of the large and small intestines
column3: for example)
column4: and the parietal peritoneum—which covers the visceral peritoneum below it
column5: the extraperitoneal fat
column6: the transversalis fascia
column7: the internal and external oblique and transversus abdominis aponeurosis
column8: and a layer of fascia
column9: which has different names according to what it covers (e.g.
column10: transversalis
column11: psoas fascia).

column2: the term 'abdominal wall' most commonly refers to the layers composing the anterior abdominal wall which
column3: in addition to the layers mentioned above
column4: includes the three layers of muscle: the transversus abdominis (transverse abdominal muscle)
column5: the internal (obliquus internus) and the external oblique (obliquus externus).

column1: The contour of abdominal wall is roughly hexagonal. Its superior border is bounded by the coastal margins
column2: lateral borders by mid-axillary lines
column3: and inferior borders bounded by the anterior half of the iliac crest
column4: inguinal ligaments
column5: pubic crest
column6: and pubic symphysis.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organ_transplantation|A01.941|D019737|Organ transplantation|"Organ transplantation is a medical procedure in which an organ is removed from one body and placed in the body of a recipient
column2: to replace a damaged or missing organ.  The donor and recipient may be at the same location
column3: or organs may be transported from a donor site to another location. Organs and/or tissues that are transplanted within the same person's body are called autografts. Transplants that are recently performed between two subjects of the same species are called allografts. Allografts can either be from a living or cadaveric source.

column1: Organs that have been successfully transplanted include the heart
column2: kidneys
column3: liver
column4: lungs
column5: pancreas
column6: intestine
column7: thymus and uterus. Tissues include bones
column8: tendons (both referred to as musculoskeletal grafts)
column9: corneae
column10: skin
column11: heart valves
column12: nerves and veins.  Worldwide
column13: the kidneys are the most commonly transplanted organs
column14: followed by the liver and then the heart. Corneae and musculoskeletal grafts are the most commonly transplanted tissues; these outnumber organ transplants by more than tenfold.

column2: brain dead
column3: or dead via circulatory death. Tissue may be recovered from donors who die of circulatory death
column4: as well as of brain death – up to 24 hours past the cessation of heartbeat. Unlike organs
column5: most tissues (with the exception of corneas) can be preserved and stored for up to five years
column6: meaning they can be ""banked"". Transplantation raises a number of bioethical issues
column7: including the definition of death
column8: when and how consent should be given for an organ to be transplanted
column9: and payment for organs for transplantation. Other ethical issues include transplantation tourism (medical tourism) and more broadly the socio-economic context in which organ procurement or transplantation may occur. A particular problem is organ trafficking. There is also the ethical issue of not holding out false hope to patients.

column1: Transplantation medicine is one of the most challenging and complex areas of modern medicine. Some of the key areas for medical management are the problems of transplant rejection
column2: during which the body has an immune response to the transplanted organ
column3: possibly leading to transplant failure and the need to immediately remove the organ from the recipient. When possible
column4: transplant rejection can be reduced through serotyping to determine the most appropriate donor-recipient match and through the use of immunosuppressant drugs.

column1: Autografts are the transplant of tissue to the same person. Sometimes this is done with surplus tissue
column2: tissue that can regenerate
column3: or tissues more desperately needed elsewhere (examples include skin grafts
column4: vein extraction for CABG
column5: etc.). Sometimes an autograft is done to remove the tissue and then treat it or the person before returning it (examples include stem cell autograft and storing blood in advance of surgery). In a rotationplasty
column6: a distal joint is used to replace a more proximal one; typically a foot or ankle joint is used to replace a knee joint.  The person's foot is severed and reversed
column7: the knee removed
column8: and the tibia joined with the femur.

column1: An allograft is a transplant of an organ or tissue between two genetically non-identical members of the same species. Most human tissue and organ transplants are allografts. Due to the genetic difference between the organ and the recipient
column2: the recipient's immune system will identify the organ as foreign and attempt to destroy it
column3: causing transplant rejection. The risk of transplant rejection can be estimated by measuring the panel-reactive antibody level.

column1: An isograft is a subset of allograft in which organs or tissues are transplanted from a donor to a genetically identical recipient (such as an identical twin). Isografts are differentiated from other types of transplants because while they are anatomically identical to allografts
column2: they do not trigger an immune response.

column1: A xenograft is a transplant of organs or tissue from one species to another. An example is porcine heart valve transplant
column2: which is quite common and successful. Another example is attempted piscine–primate (fish to non-human primate) transplant of pancreatic islets. The latter research study was intended to pave the way for potential human use if successful. However
column3: xenotransplantation is often an extremely dangerous type of transplant because of the increased risk of non-functional compatibility
column4: rejection
column5: and disease carried in the tissue. In the opposite direction
column6: attempts are being made to devise a way to transplant human fetal hearts and kidneys into animals for future transplantation into human patients to address the shortage of donor organs.

column2: where both lungs need to be replaced
column3: it is a technically easier operation with a higher rate of success to replace both the heart and lungs of the recipient with those of the donor. As the recipient's original heart is usually healthy
column4: it can then be transplanted into a second recipient in need of a heart transplant
column5: thus making the person with CF a living heart donor.

column1: In a 2016 case at Stanford Medical Center
column2: a woman who was needing a heart-lung transplant had cystic fibrosis which had led to one lung expanding and the other shrinking
column3: thereby displacing her heart.  The second patient who in turn received her heart was a woman with right ventricular dysplasia which had led to a dangerously abnormal rhythm.  The dual operations required three surgical teams
column4: including one to remove the heart and lungs from a recently deceased initial donor.  The two living recipients did well and had an opportunity to meet six weeks after their simultaneous operations.

column1: Another example of this situation occurs with a special form of liver transplant in which the recipient has familial amyloid polyneuropathy
column2: a disease where the liver slowly produces a protein that damages other organs. The recipient's liver can then be transplanted into an older person for whom the effects of the disease will not necessarily contribute significantly to mortality.

column1: This term also refers to a series of living donor transplants in which one donor donates to the highest recipient on the waiting list and the transplant center utilizes that donation to facilitate multiple transplants. These other transplants are otherwise impossible due to blood type or antibody barriers to transplantation. The ""Good Samaritan"" kidney is transplanted into one of the other recipients
column2: whose donor in turn donates his or her kidney to an unrelated recipient. This method allows all organ recipients to get a transplant even if their living donor is not a match for them. This further benefits people below any of these recipients on waiting lists
column3: as they move closer to the top of the list for a deceased-donor organ. Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore and Northwestern University's Northwestern Memorial Hospital have received significant attention for pioneering transplants of this kind. In February 2012
column4: the last link in a record 60-person domino chain of 30 kidney transplants was completed.

column2: New York Presbyterian Morgan Stanley Children’s Hospital performed the first domino heart transplantation in a baby
column3: eventually saving two baby girls.

column1: Because very young children (generally under 12 months
column2: but often as old as 24 months) do not have a well-developed immune system
column3: it is possible for them to receive organs from otherwise incompatible donors. This is known as ABO-incompatible (ABOi) transplantation. Graft survival and people's mortality are approximately the same between ABOi and ABO-compatible (ABOc) recipients. While focus has been on infant heart transplants
column4: the principles generally apply to other forms of solid organ transplantation.

column1: The most important factors are that the recipient not have produced isohemagglutinins
column2: and that they have low levels of T cell-independent antigens. United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) regulations allow for ABOi transplantation in children under two years of age if isohemagglutinin titers are 1:4 or below
column3: and if there is no matching ABOc recipient. Studies have shown that the period under which a recipient may undergo ABOi transplantation may be prolonged by exposure to nonself A and B antigens. Furthermore
column4: should the recipient (for example
column5: type B-positive with a type AB-positive graft) require eventual retransplantation
column6: the recipient may receive a new organ of either blood type.

column1: Limited success has been achieved in ABO-incompatible heart transplants in adults
column2: though this requires that the adult recipients have low levels of anti-A or anti-B antibodies. Renal transplantation is more successful
column3: with similar long-term graft survival rates to ABOc transplants.

column2: people with obesity were not considered appropriate candidate donors for renal transplantation. In 2009
column3: the physicians at the University of Illinois Medical Center performed the first robotic renal transplantation in an obese recipient and have continued to transplant people with a body mass index over 35 using robotic surgery. As of January 2014
column4: over 100 people who would otherwise have been turned down because of their weight have successfully been transplanted.

column1: === Impact of Human Herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) Reactivation on Pediatric Liver Transplantation ===
Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) reactivation emerges as a notable concern in pediatric liver transplantation
column2: potentially influencing both graft and recipient health. HHV-6
column3: prevalent in a substantial portion of the population
column4: can manifest in liver transplant recipients with inherited chromosomally integrated HHV-6 (iciHHV-6)
column5: predisposing them to heightened risks of complications such as graft-versus-host disease and allograft rejections. Recent case studies underscore the significance of HHV-6 reactivation
column6: demonstrating its ability to infect liver grafts and impact recipient outcomes. Clinical management involves early detection
column7: targeted antiviral therapy
column8: and vigilant monitoring post-transplantation
column9: with future research aimed at optimizing preventive measures and therapeutic interventions to mitigate the impact of HHV-6 reactivation on pediatric liver transplant outcomes.

column1: Kidney transplantation is becoming increasingly common and is the preferred treatment for end-stage renal failure.  [1]
Liver transplantation is the only curative therapy for end-stage liver disease
column2: and the liver is the second most frequently transplanted solid organ.[2]

column1: Pancreatic transplantation is a complex surgical procedure performed in patients with severe chronic diabetes
column2: often in association with renal transplantation.[3]

column1: Heart transplantation is increasingly performed in patients with end-stage heart failure
column2: most often related to ischemic and non-ischemic cardiomyopathies.[4]

column1: The main complications are procedural complications
column2: infection
column3: acute rejection
column4: cardiac allograft vasculopathy and malignancy.

column1: Non-vascular and vascular complications can occur in the initial post-transplant phase and at later stages. Overall postoperative complications after kidney transplantation occur in approximately 12% to 25% of kidney transplant patients.
Organ donors may be living or may have died of brain death or circulatory death. Most deceased donors are those who have been pronounced brain dead. Brain dead means the cessation of brain function
column2: typically after receiving an injury (either traumatic or pathological) to the brain
column3: or otherwise cutting off blood circulation to the brain (drowning
column4: suffocation
column5: etc.). Breathing is maintained via artificial sources
column6: which
column7: in turn
column8: maintains heartbeat. Once brain death has been declared
column9: the person can be considered for organ donation. Criteria for brain death vary. Because less than 3% of all deaths in the US are the result of brain death
column10: the overwhelming majority of deaths are ineligible for organ donation
column11: resulting in severe shortages. It is important to note currently that patients that have been pronounced brain dead are one of the most common and ideal donors
column12: since often these donors are young and healthy
column13: thus leading to high quality organs.

column1: Organ donation is possible after cardiac death in some situations
column2: primarily when the person is severely brain-injured and not expected to survive without artificial breathing and mechanical support.  Independent of any decision to donate
column3: a person's next-of-kin may decide to end artificial support. If the person is expected to expire within a short period of time after support is withdrawn
column4: arrangements can be made to withdraw that support in an operating room to allow quick recovery of the organs after circulatory death has occurred.

column1: Tissues may be recovered from donors who die of either brain or circulatory death. In general
column2: tissues may be recovered from donors up to 24 hours past the cessation of heartbeat. In contrast to organs
column3: most tissues (with the exception of corneas) can be preserved and stored for up to five years
column4: meaning they can be ""banked."" Also
column5: more than 60 grafts may be obtained from a single tissue donor. Because of these three factors – the ability to recover from a non-heart-beating donor
column6: the ability to bank tissue
column7: and the number of grafts available from each donor – tissue transplants are much more common than organ transplants. The American Association of Tissue Banks estimates that more than one million tissue transplants take place in the United States each year.

column2: the donor remains alive and donates a renewable tissue
column3: cell
column4: or fluid (e.g.
column5: blood
column6: skin)
column7: or donates an organ or part of an organ in which the remaining organ can regenerate or take on the workload of the rest of the organ (primarily single kidney donation
column8: partial donation of liver
column9: lung lobe
column10: small bowel). Regenerative medicine may one day allow for laboratory-grown organs
column11: using person's own cells via stem cells
column12: or healthy cells extracted from the failing organs.

column1: Deceased donors (formerly cadaveric) are people who have been declared brain-dead and whose organs are kept viable by ventilators or other mechanical mechanisms until they can be excised for transplantation. Apart from brainstem-dead donors
column2: who have formed the majority of deceased donors for the last 20 years
column3: there is increasing use of after-circulatory-death donors (formerly non-heart-beating donors) to increase the potential pool of donors as demand for transplants continues to grow. Prior to the legal recognition of brain death in the 1980s
column4: all deceased organ donors had died of circulatory death.  These organs have inferior outcomes to organs from a brain-dead donor. For instance
column5: patients who underwent liver transplantation using donation-after-circulatory-death allografts have been shown to have significantly lower graft survival than those from donation-after-brain-death allografts due to biliary complications and primary nonfunction in liver transplantation. However
column6: given the scarcity of suitable organs and the number of people who die waiting
column7: any potentially suitable organ must be considered.  Jurisdictions with medically assisted suicide may co-ordinate organ donations from that source.

column1: In most countries there is a shortage of suitable organs for transplantation. Countries often have formal systems in place to manage the process of determining who is an organ donor and in what order organ recipients receive available organs.
The overwhelming majority of deceased-donor organs in the United States are allocated by federal contract to the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network
column2: held since it was created by the Organ Transplant Act of 1984 by the United Network for Organ Sharing
column3: or UNOS. (UNOS does not handle donor cornea tissue; corneal donor tissue is usually handled by multiple eye banks  with guidance from the Eye Bank Association of America (EBAA) and Food and Drug Administration (FDA). Individual regional organ procurement organizations
column4: all members of the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network
column5: are responsible for the identification of suitable donors and collection of the donated organs.  UNOS then allocates organs based on the method considered most fair by the leadership in the field. The allocation methodology varies somewhat by organ
column6: and changes periodically.  For example
column7: liver allocation is based partially on MELD score (Model of End-Stage Liver Disease)
column8: an empirical score based on lab values indicative of the sickness of the person from liver disease. In 1984
column9: the National Organ Transplant Act (NOTA) was passed; it gave way to the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network
column10: which maintains the organ registry and ensures equitable allocation of organs.  The Scientific Registry of Transplant Recipients was also established to conduct ongoing studies into the evaluation and clinical status of organ transplants.  In 2000 the Children's Health Act passed and required NOTA to consider special issues around pediatric patients and organ allocation.

column1: An example of ""line jumping"" occurred in 2003 at Duke University when doctors attempted to correct an initially incorrect transplant.  An American teenager received a heart-lung donation with the wrong blood type for her.  She then received a second transplant even though she was then in such poor physical shape that she normally would not be considered a good candidate for a transplant.
In an April 2008 article in The Guardian
column2: Steven Tsui
column3: the head of the transplant team at Papworth Hospital in the UK
column4: is quoted in raising the ethical issue of not holding out false hope.  He stated
column5: ""Conventionally we would say if people's life expectancy was a year or less we would consider them a candidate for a heart transplant. But we also have to manage expectations. If we know that in an average year we will do 30 heart transplants
column6: there is no point putting 60 people on our waiting list
column7: because we know half of them will die and it's not right to give them false hope.""

column2: but still very rare
column3: is directed or targeted donation
column4: in which the family of a deceased donor (often honoring the wishes of the deceased) requests an organ be given to a specific person
column5: subverting the allocation system. In the United States
column6: there are various lengths of waiting times due to the different availabilities of organs in different UNOS regions. In other countries such as the UK
column7: only medical factors and the position on the waiting list can affect who receives the organ.

column1: One of the more publicized cases of this type was the 1994 Chester and Patti Szuber transplant.  This was the first time that a parent had received a heart donated by one of their own children.  Although the decision to accept the heart from his recently killed child was not an easy decision
column2: the Szuber family agreed that giving Patti's heart to her father would have been something that she would have wanted.

column1: Access to organ transplantation is one reason for the growth of medical tourism.
== Reasons for donation and ethical issues ==
Living related donors donate to family members or friends in whom they have an emotional investment. The risk of surgery is offset by the psychological benefit of not losing someone related to them
column2: or not seeing them suffer the ill effects of waiting on a list.

column1: A ""paired-exchange"" is a technique of matching willing living donors to compatible recipients using serotyping. For example
column2: a spouse may be willing to donate a kidney to their partner but cannot since there is not a biological match. The willing spouse's kidney is donated to a matching recipient who also has an incompatible but willing spouse. The second donor must match the first recipient to complete the pair exchange. Typically the surgeries are scheduled simultaneously in case one of the donors decides to back out and the couples are kept anonymous from each other until after the transplant. Paired-donor exchange
column3: led by work in the New England Program for Kidney Exchange as well as at Johns Hopkins University and the Ohio organ procurement organizations
column4: may more efficiently allocate organs and lead to more transplants.

column1: Paired exchange programs were popularized in the New England Journal of Medicine article ""Ethics of a paired-kidney-exchange program"" in 1997 by L.F. Ross. It was also proposed by Felix T. Rapport in 1986 as part of his initial proposals for live-donor transplants ""The case for a living emotionally related international kidney donor exchange registry"" in Transplant Proceedings. A paired exchange is the simplest case of a much larger exchange registry program where willing donors are matched with any number of compatible recipients. Transplant exchange programs have been suggested as early as 1970: ""A cooperative kidney typing and exchange program.""

The first pair exchange transplant in the US was in 2001 at Johns Hopkins Hospital. The first complex multihospital kidney exchange involving 12 people was performed in February 2009 by The Johns Hopkins Hospital
column2: Barnes-Jewish Hospital in St. Louis and Integris Baptist Medical Center in Oklahoma City. Another 12-person multihospital kidney exchange was performed four weeks later by Saint Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston
column3: New Jersey
column4: Newark Beth Israel Medical Center and New York-Presbyterian Hospital. Surgical teams led by Johns Hopkins continue to pioneer this field with more complex chains of exchange
column5: such as an eight-way multihospital kidney exchange. In December 2009
column6: a 13 organ 13 recipient matched kidney exchange took place
column7: coordinated through Georgetown University Hospital and Washington Hospital Center
column8: Washington
column9: DC.

column1: Good Samaritan or ""altruistic"" donation is giving a donation to someone that has no prior affiliation with the donor. The idea of altruistic donation is to give with no interest of personal gain
column2: it is out of pure selflessness. On the other hand
column3: the current allocation system does not assess a donor's motive
column4: so altruistic donation is not a requirement. Some people choose to do this out of a personal need to donate. Some donate to the next person on the list; others use some method of choosing a recipient based on criteria important to them. Websites are being developed that facilitate such donation. Over half of the members of the Jesus Christians
column5: an Australian religious group
column6: have donated kidneys in such a fashion.

column2: in the form of reimbursement for out-of-pocket expenses

column4: and strictly only in the case of kidney transplant in the case of Singapore (minimal reimbursement is offered in the case of other forms of organ harvesting by Singapore). Kidney disease organizations in both countries have expressed their support.

column2: donors get money or other compensation in exchange for their organs. This practice is common in some parts of the world
column3: whether legal or not
column4: and is one of the many factors driving medical tourism.

column1: Organ transplantation in China has taken place since the 1960s

China's transplant programme attracted the attention of international news media in the 1990s due to ethical concerns about the organs and tissue removed from the corpses of executed criminals being commercially traded. In 2006 it became clear that about 41
column8: 500 organs had been sourced from Falun Gong practitioners in China since 2000.

One-third of all heart transplants performed on Israelis are done in China; others are done in Europe. Dr. Jacob Lavee

column3: 000 organ transplants were done in 2017

column1: Successful human allotransplants have a relatively long history of operative skills that were present long before the necessities for post-operative survival were discovered. Rejection and the side effects of preventing rejection (especially infection and nephropathy) were
column2: are

column1: Several apocryphal accounts of transplants exist well prior to the scientific understanding and advancements that would be necessary for them to have actually occurred. The Chinese physician Pien Chi'ao reportedly exchanged hearts between a man of strong spirit but weak will with one of a man of weak spirit but strong will in an attempt to achieve balance in each man. Roman Catholic accounts report the 3rd-century saints Damian and Cosmas as replacing the gangrenous or cancerous leg of the Roman deacon Justinian with the leg of a recently deceased Ethiopian. Most accounts have the saints performing the transplant in the 4th century
column2: many decades after their deaths; some accounts have them only instructing living surgeons who performed the procedure.

column1: The more likely accounts of early transplants deal with skin transplantation. The first reasonable account is of the Indian surgeon Sushruta in the 2nd century BC
column2: who used autografted skin transplantation in nose reconstruction
column3: a rhinoplasty. Success or failure of these procedures is not well documented. Centuries later
column4: the Italian surgeon Gasparo Tagliacozzi performed successful skin autografts; he also failed consistently with allografts
column5: offering the first suggestion of rejection centuries before that mechanism could possibly be understood. He attributed it to the ""force and power of individuality"" in his 1596 work De Curtorum Chirurgia per Insitionem.

column1: The first successful corneal allograft transplant was performed in 1837 in a gazelle model; the first successful human corneal transplant
column2: a keratoplastic operation
column3: was performed by Eduard Zirm at Olomouc Eye Clinic
column4: now in the Czech Republic

column1: The first transplant in the modern sense – the implantation of organ tissue in order to replace an organ function – was a thyroid transplant in 1883. It was performed by the Swiss surgeon and later Nobel laureate Theodor Kocher. In the preceding decades Kocher had perfected the removal of excess thyroid tissue in cases of goiter to an extent that he was able to remove the whole organ without the person dying from the operation. Kocher carried out the total removal of the organ in some cases as a measure to prevent recurrent goiter. By 1883
column2: the surgeon noticed that the complete removal of the organ leads to a complex of particular symptoms that we today have learned to associate with a lack of thyroid hormone. Kocher reversed these symptoms by implanting thyroid tissue to these people and thus performed the first organ transplant. In the following years Kocher and other surgeons used thyroid transplantation also to treat thyroid deficiency that appeared spontaneously
column3: without a preceding organ removal.

column1: Thyroid transplantation became the model for a whole new therapeutic strategy: organ transplantation. After the example of the thyroid
column2: other organs were transplanted in the decades around 1900. Some of these transplants were done in animals for purposes of research
column3: where organ removal and transplantation became a successful strategy of investigating the function of organs. Kocher was awarded his Nobel Prize in 1909 for the discovery of the function of the thyroid gland. At the same time
column4: organs were also transplanted for treating diseases in humans. The thyroid gland became the model for transplants of adrenal and parathyroid glands
column5: pancreas
column6: ovary
column7: testicles and kidney. By 1900
column8: the idea that one can successfully treat internal diseases by replacing a failed organ through transplantation had been generally accepted. Pioneering work in the surgical technique of transplantation was made in the early 1900s by the French surgeon Alexis Carrel
column9: with Charles Guthrie
column10: with the transplantation of arteries or veins. Their skillful anastomosis operations and the new suturing techniques laid the groundwork for later transplant surgery and won Carrel the 1912 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. From 1902
column11: Carrel performed transplant experiments on dogs. Surgically successful in moving kidneys
column12: hearts
column13: and spleens
column14: he was one of the first to identify the problem of rejection
column15: which remained insurmountable for decades. The discovery of transplant immunity by the German surgeon Georg Schöne
column16: various strategies of matching donor and recipient
column17: and the use of different agents for immune suppression did not result in substantial improvement so that organ transplantation was largely abandoned after WWI.

column2: the first ever successful transplant of any organ was done at the Brigham & Women's Hospital in Boston. The surgery was performed by American surgeon Dr. Joseph Murray
column3: who received the Nobel Prize in Medicine for his work. The success of this transplant was mostly due to the family relation between the recipient
column4: a Richard Herrick of Maine
column5: and his donor and identical twin brother Ronald. Richard Herrick was in the Navy and became severely ill with acute renal failure. His brother Ronald donated his kidney to Richard
column6: and Richard lived on for another eight years. Prior to this case
column7: transplant recipients did not survive for more than thirty days. Their close family relation meant there was no need for anti-rejection medications
column8: which was not known until this time
column9: so the case shed light on the cause of rejection and of possible anti-rejection medicine.

column1: Major steps in skin transplantation occurred during the First World War
column2: notably in the work of Harold Gillies at Aldershot
column3: United Kingdom. Among his advances was the tubed pedicle graft
column4: which maintained a flesh connection from the donor site until the graft established its own blood flow. Gillies' assistant
column5: Archibald McIndoe
column6: carried on the work into the Second World War as reconstructive surgery. In 1962
column7: the first successful replantation surgery was performed – re-attaching a severed limb and restoring (limited) function and feeling.

column1: Transplant of a single gonad (testis) from a living donor was carried out in early July 1926 in Zaječar
column2: Serbia
column3: by a Russian émigré surgeon Dr. Peter Vasil'evič Kolesnikov. The donor was a convicted murderer
column4: one Ilija Krajan
column5: whose death sentence was commuted to 20 years imprisonment
column6: and he was led to believe that it was done because he had donated his testis to an elderly medical doctor. Both the donor and the receiver survived
column7: but charges were brought in a court of law by the public prosecutor against Dr. Kolesnikov
column8: not for performing the operation
column9: but for lying to the donor.

column1: The first attempted human deceased-donor transplant was performed by the Ukrainian surgeon Yurii Voronoy in the 1930s; but failed due to ischemia. Joseph Murray and J. Hartwell Harrison performed the first successful transplant
column2: a kidney transplant between identical twins
column4: because no immunosuppression was necessary for genetically identical individuals.

column1: In the late 1940s British surgeon Peter Medawar
column2: working for the National Institute for Medical Research
column3: improved the understanding of rejection. Identifying the immune reactions in 1951
column4: Medawar suggested that immunosuppressive drugs could be used. Cortisone had been recently discovered and the more effective azathioprine was identified in 1959
column5: but it was not until the discovery of cyclosporine in 1970 that transplant surgery found a sufficiently powerful immunosuppressive.

column1: There was a successful deceased-donor lung transplant into an emphysema and lung cancer patient in June 1963 by James Hardy at the University of Mississippi Medical Center in Jackson
column2: Mississippi. The patient John Russell survived for eighteen days before dying of kidney failure.

column1: Thomas Starzl of Denver attempted a liver transplant in the same year
column2: but he was not successful until 1967.

column1: In the early 1960s and prior to long-term dialysis becoming available
column2: Keith Reemtsma and his colleagues at Tulane University in New Orleans attempted transplants of chimpanzee kidneys into 13 human patients.  Most of these patients only lived one to two months.  However
column4: a 23-year-old woman lived for nine months and even returned to her job as a school teacher until she suddenly collapsed and died.  It was assumed that she died from an acute electrolyte disturbance.  At autopsy
column5: the kidneys had not been rejected nor was there any other obvious cause of death. One source states this patient died from pneumonia. Tom Starzl and his team in Colorado used baboon kidneys with six human patients who lived one or two months
column6: but with no longer term survivors. Others in the United States and France had limited experiences.

column1: The heart was a major prize for transplant surgeons. But over and above rejection issues
column2: the heart deteriorates within minutes of death
column3: so any operation would have to be performed at great speed. The development of the heart-lung machine was also needed. Lung pioneer James Hardy was prepared to attempt a human heart transplant in 1964
column4: but when a premature failure of comatose Boyd Rush's heart caught Hardy with no human donor
column5: he used a chimpanzee heart
column6: which beat in his patient's chest for approximately one hour and then failed. The first partial success was achieved on 3 December 1967
column7: when Christiaan Barnard of Cape Town
column8: South Africa
column9: performed the world's first human-to-human heart transplant with patient Louis Washkansky as the recipient.  Washkansky survived for eighteen days amid what many saw as a distasteful publicity circus. The media interest prompted a spate of heart transplants. Over a hundred were performed in 1968–1969
column10: but almost all the people died within 60 days. Barnard's second patient
column11: Philip Blaiberg
column12: lived for 19 months.

column1: It was the advent of cyclosporine that altered transplants from research surgery to life-saving treatment. In 1968 surgical pioneer Denton Cooley performed 17 transplants
column2: including the first heart-lung transplant. Fourteen of his patients were dead within six months. By 1984 two-thirds of all heart transplant patients survived for five years or more. With organ transplants becoming commonplace
column3: limited only by donors
column4: surgeons moved on to riskier fields
column5: including multiple-organ transplants on humans and whole-body transplant research on animals. On 9 March 1981
column6: the first successful heart-lung transplant took place at Stanford University Hospital. The head surgeon
column7: Bruce Reitz
column8: credited the patient's recovery to cyclosporine.

column1: As the rising success rate of transplants and modern immunosuppression make transplants more common
column2: the need for more organs has become critical. Transplants from living donors
column3: especially relatives
column4: have become increasingly common. Additionally
column5: there is substantive research into xenotransplantation
column6: or transgenic organs; although these forms of transplant are not yet being used in humans
column7: clinical trials involving the use of specific cell types have been conducted with promising results
column8: such as using porcine islets of Langerhans to treat type 1 diabetes. However
column9: there are still many problems that would need to be solved before they would be feasible options in people requiring transplants.

column2: researchers have been looking into means of reducing the general burden of immunosuppression. Common approaches include avoidance of steroids
column3: reduced exposure to calcineurin inhibitors
column4: and other means of weaning drugs based on patient outcome and function. While short-term outcomes appear promising
column5: long-term outcomes are still unknown
column6: and in general
column7: reduced immunosuppression increases the risk of rejection and decreases the risk of infection. The risk of early rejection is increased if corticosteroid immunosuppression are avoided or withdrawn after renal transplantation.

column1: Many other new drugs are under development for transplantation.
The emerging field of regenerative medicine promises to solve the problem of organ transplant rejection by regrowing organs in the lab
column2: using person's own cells (stem cells or healthy cells extracted from the donor site).

column2: tissue transplants are regulated by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) which sets strict regulations on the safety of the transplants
column3: primarily aimed at the prevention of the spread of communicable disease. Regulations include criteria for donor screening and testing as well as strict regulations on the processing and distribution of tissue grafts. Organ transplants are not regulated by the FDA. It is essential that the HLA complexes of both the donor and recipient be as closely matched as possible to prevent graft rejection.

column2: the CDC reported the first-ever case of HIV and Hepatitis C being simultaneously transferred through an organ transplant. The donor was a 38-year-old male
column3: considered ""high-risk"" by donation organizations
column4: and his organs transmitted HIV and Hepatitis C to four organ recipients. Experts say that the reason the diseases did not show up on screening tests is probably because they were contracted within three weeks before the donor's death
column5: so antibodies would not have existed in high enough numbers to detect. The crisis has caused many to call for more sensitive screening tests
column6: which could pick up antibodies sooner. Currently
column7: the screens cannot detect the small number of antibodies produced in HIV infections within the last 90 days or Hepatitis C infections within the last 18–21 days before a donation is made.

column1: Nucleic acid testing is now being done by many organ procurement organizations and is able to detect HIV and hepatitis C directly within seven to ten days of exposure to the virus.
Both developing and developed countries have forged various policies to try to increase the safety and availability of organ transplants to their citizens. However
column2: whilst potential recipients in developing countries may mirror their more developed counterparts in desperation
column3: potential donors in developing countries do not. The Indian government has had difficulty tracking the flourishing organ black market in their country
column4: but in recent times it has amended its organ transplant law to make punishment more stringent for commercial dealings in organs. It has also included new clauses in the law to support deceased organ donation
column5: such as making it mandatory to request for organ donation in case of brain death. Other countries victimized by illegal organ trade have also implemented legislative reactions.  Moldova has made international adoption illegal in fear of organ traffickers. China has made selling of organs illegal as of July 2006 and claims that all prisoner organ donors have filed consent. However
column6: doctors in other countries
column7: such as the United Kingdom
column8: have accused China of abusing its high capital punishment rate. Despite these efforts
column9: illegal organ trafficking continues to thrive and can be attributed to corruption in healthcare systems
column10: which has been traced as high up as the doctors themselves in China and Ukraine
column11: and the blind eye economically strained governments and health care programs must sometimes turn to organ trafficking. Some organs are also shipped to Uganda and the Netherlands. This was a main product in the triangular trade in 1934.

column1: In an article appearing in the April 2004 issue of Econ Journal Watch
column2: economist Alex Tabarrok examined the impact of direct consent laws on transplant organ availability. Tabarrok found that social pressures resisting the use of transplant organs decreased over time as the opportunity of individual decisions increased. Tabarrok concluded his study suggesting that gradual elimination of organ donation restrictions and move to a free market in organ sales will increase supply of organs and encourage broader social acceptance of organ donation as a practice.

column1: In the United States 24 states have no law preventing discrimination against potential organ recipients based on cognitive ability
column2: including children. A 2008 study found that of the transplant centers surveyed in those states 85 percent considered disability when deciding transplant list and forty four percent would deny an organ transplant to a child with a neurodevelopmental disability.

column1: The existence and distribution of organ transplantation procedures in developing countries
column2: while almost always beneficial to those receiving them
column3: raise many ethical concerns. Both the source and method of obtaining the organ to transplant are major ethical issues to consider
column4: as well as the notion of distributive justice. The World Health Organization argues that transplantations promote health
column5: but the notion of ""transplantation tourism"" has the potential to violate human rights or exploit the poor
column6: to have unintended health consequences
column7: and to provide unequal access to services
column8: all of which ultimately may cause harm. Regardless of the ""gift of life""
column9: in the context of developing countries
column10: this might be coercive. The practice of coercion could be considered exploitative of the poor population
column11: violating basic human rights according to Articles 3 and 4 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. There is also a powerful opposing view
column12: that trade in organs
column13: if properly and effectively regulated to ensure that the seller is fully informed of all the consequences of donation
column14: is a mutually beneficial transaction between two consenting adults
column15: and that prohibiting it would itself be a violation of Articles 3 and 29 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

column1: Even within developed countries there is concern that enthusiasm for increasing the supply of organs may trample on respect for the right to life. The question is made even more complicated by the fact that the ""irreversibility"" criterion for legal death cannot be adequately defined and can easily change with changing technology.

column1: An early-stage medical laboratory and research company
column2: called Organovo
column3: designs and develops functional
column4: three dimensional human tissue for medical research and therapeutic applications. The company utilizes its NovoGen MMX Bioprinter for 3D bioprinting. Organovo anticipates that the bioprinting of human tissues will accelerate the preclinical drug testing and discovery process
column5: enabling treatments to be created more quickly and at lower cost. Additionally
column6: Organovo has long-term expectations that this technology could be suitable for surgical therapy and transplantation.

column1: A further area of active research is concerned with improving and assessing organs during their preservation. Various techniques have emerged which show great promise
column2: most of which involve perfusing the organ under either hypothermic (4–10 °C) or normothermic (37 °C) conditions. All of these add additional cost and logistical complexity to the organ retrieval
column3: preservation and transplant process
column4: but early results suggest it may well be worth it. Hypothermic perfusion is in clinical use for transplantation of kidneys and liver whilst normothermic perfusion has been used effectively in the heart

column7: less so

column2: the forehead is an area of the head bounded by three features
column3: two of the skull and one of the scalp.  The top of the forehead is marked by the hairline
column4: the edge of the area where hair on the scalp grows.  The bottom of the forehead is marked by the supraorbital ridge
column5: the bone feature of the skull above the eyes.  The two sides of the forehead are marked by the temporal ridge
column6: a bone feature that links the supraorbital ridge to the coronal suture line and beyond. However
column7: the eyebrows do not form part of the forehead.

column2: sinciput is given as the Latin equivalent to ""forehead"" (etymology of sinciput: from semi- ""half"" and caput ""head"".).

column1: The bone of the forehead is the squamous part of the frontal bone. The overlying muscles are the occipitofrontalis
column2: procerus
column3: and corrugator supercilii muscles
column4: all of which are controlled by the temporal branch of the facial nerve.

column1: The sensory nerves of the forehead connect to the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve and to the cervical plexus
column2: and lie within the subcutaneous fat.  The motor nerves of the forehead connect to the facial nerve. The ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve
column3: the supraorbital nerve
column4: divides at the orbital rim into two parts in the forehead.  One part
column5: the superficial division
column6: runs over the surface of the occipitofrontalis muscle.  This provides sensation for the skin of the forehead
column7: and for the front edge of the scalp. The other part
column8: the deep division
column9: runs into the occipitofrontalis muscle and provides frontoparietal sensation.

column1: The muscles of the forehead help to form facial expressions.  There are four basic motions
column2: which can occur individually or in combination to form different expressions.  The occipitofrontalis muscles can raise the eyebrows
column3: either together or individually
column4: forming expressions of surprise and quizzicality.  The corrugator supercilii muscles can pull the eyebrows inwards and down
column5: forming a frown.  The procerus muscles can pull down the centre portions of the eyebrows.

column1: The movements of the muscles in the forehead produce characteristic wrinkles in the skin. The occipitofrontalis muscles produce the transverse wrinkles across the width of the forehead
column2: and the corrugator supercilii muscles produce vertical wrinkles between the eyebrows above the nose. The procerus muscles cause the nose to wrinkle.

column1: The hip joint is a ball and socket synovial joint formed by the articulation of the rounded head of the femur and the cup-like acetabulum of the pelvis. The socket of the acetabulum is pointing downwards and anterolaterally. The socket is also turned such that the outer edge of its roof is more lateral than outer edge of the floor. It forms the primary connection between the bones of the lower limb and the axial skeleton of the trunk and pelvis. Both joint surfaces are covered with a strong but lubricated layer called articular hyaline cartilage.
The cuplike acetabulum forms at the union of three pelvic bones — the ilium
column2: pubis
column3: and ischium. The Y-shaped growth plate that separates them
column4: the triradiate cartilage
column5: is fused definitively at ages 14–16. It is a special type of spheroidal or ball and socket joint where the roughly spherical femoral head is largely contained within the acetabulum and has an average radius of curvature of 2.5 cm. The acetabulum grasps almost half the femoral ball
column6: a grip deepened by a ring-shaped fibrocartilaginous lip
column7: the acetabular labrum
column8: which extends the joint beyond the equator. The centre of the acetabulum (fovea) does not articulate to anything. Instead
column9: it is lined with fat pad and attached to ligamentum teres. The acetabular labrum is horse-shoe shaped. Its inferior notch is bridged by transverse acetabular ligament. The joint space between the femoral head and the superior acetabulum is normally between 2 and 7 mm.

column1: Acetabular angle (or Sharp's angle) is the angle between the horizontal line passing through the inferior aspects of triradiate cartilages (Hilgenreiner's line) and another line passing through the inferior angle of triradiate cartilage to superior acetabular rim. The angle measures 35 degrees at birth
column2: 25 degrees at one year of age
column3: and less than 10 degrees by 15 years of age. In adults the angle can vary from 33 to 38 degrees.

column1: The sagittal angle of the acetabular inlet is an angle between a line passing from the anterior to the posterior acetabular rim and the sagittal plane. It measures 7° at birth and increases to 17° in adults.
Wiberg's centre-edge angle (CE angle) is an angle between a vertical line and a line from the centre of the femoral head to the most lateral part of the acetabulum

column1: The strong but loose fibrous capsule of the hip joint permits the hip joint to have the second largest range of movement (second only to the shoulder) and yet support the weight of the body
column2: arms and head.

column1: The capsule has two sets of fibers: longitudinal and circular.
The circular fibers form a collar around the femoral neck called the zona orbicularis.
The longitudinal retinacular fibers travel along the neck and carry blood vessels.
The hip joint is reinforced by four ligaments
column2: of which three are extracapsular and one intracapsular.

column1: The extracapsular ligaments are the iliofemoral
column2: ischiofemoral
column3: and pubofemoral ligaments attached to the bones of the pelvis (the ilium
column4: ischium
column5: and pubis respectively). All three strengthen the capsule and prevent an excessive range of movement in the joint. Of these
column6: the Y-shaped and twisted iliofemoral ligament is the strongest ligament in the human body. It has a tensile strength of 350 kg. Iliofemoral ligament is a thickening of the anterior capsule extending from anterior inferior iliac spine to intertrochanteric line. Ischiofemoral ligament is the thickening of posterior capsule of the hip and pubofemoral ligament is the thickening of the inferior capsule. In the upright position
column7: iliofemoral ligament prevents the trunk from falling backward without the need for muscular activity
column8: thus preventing excessive hyperextension. In the sitting position
column9: it becomes relaxed
column10: thus permitting the pelvis to tilt backward into its sitting position. Ischiofemoral prevents excessive extension and the pubofemoral ligament prevents excess abduction and extension.

column2: which lies like a collar around the most narrow part of the femoral neck

column1: The hip muscles act on three mutually perpendicular main axes
column2: all of which pass through the center of the femoral head
column3: resulting in three degrees of freedom and three pair of principal directions: Flexion and extension around a transverse axis (left-right); lateral rotation and medial rotation around a longitudinal axis (along the thigh); and abduction and adduction around a sagittal axis (forward-backward); and a combination of these movements (i.e. circumduction
column4: a compound movement in which the leg describes the surface of an irregular cone).

column1: A hip fracture is a  break that occurs in the upper part of the femur. Symptoms may include pain around the hip particularly with movement and shortening of the leg. The hip joint can be replaced by a prosthesis in a hip replacement operation due to fractures or illnesses such as osteoarthritis. Hip pain can have multiple sources and can also be associated with lower back pain.

column2: a company named Safeware announced an airbag belt that is designed to prevent hip fractures among such uses as the elderly and hospital patients.

column1: Abnormal orientation of the acetabular socket as seen in hip dysplasia can lead to hip subluxation (partial dislocation)

unlike other animals
column3: the hip bones are substantially different in the two sexes. The hips of human females widen during puberty. The femora are also more widely spaced in females
column4: so as to widen the opening in the hip bone and thus facilitate childbirth. Finally
column5: the ilium and its muscle attachment are shaped so as to situate the buttocks away from the birth canal
column6: where contraction of the buttocks could otherwise damage the baby.

column1: The female hips have long been associated with both fertility and general expression of sexuality. Since broad hips facilitate childbirth and also serve as an anatomical cue of sexual maturity
column2: they have been seen as an attractive trait for women for thousands of years. Many of the classical poses women take when sculpted
column3: painted or photographed
column4: such as the Grande Odalisque
column5: serve to emphasize the prominence of their hips. Similarly
column6: women's fashion through the ages has often drawn attention to the girth of the wearer's hips.

Anatomists and other researchers focused on human anatomy have hundreds of definitions of opposition. Some anatomists restrict opposition to when the thumb is approximated to the fifth finger (little finger) and refer to other approximations between the thumb and other fingers as apposition. To anatomists
column2: this makes sense as two intrinsic hand muscles are named for this specific movement (the opponens pollicis and opponens digiti minimi respectively).

referring to opposition-apposition as the transition between flexion-abduction and extension-adduction; the side of the distal thumb phalanx thus approximated to the palm or the hand's radial side (side of index finger) during apposition and the pulp or ""palmar"" side of the distal thumb phalanx approximated to either the palm or other fingers during opposition.

column1: Moving a limb back to its neutral position is called reposition and a rotary movement is referred to as circumduction.

Primatologists and hand research pioneers John and Prudence Napier defined opposition as: ""A movement by which the pulp surface of the thumb is placed squarely in contact with – or diametrically opposite to – the terminal pads of one or all of the remaining fingers."" For this true
column2: pulp-to-pulp opposition to be possible
column3: the thumb must rotate about its long axis (at the carpometacarpal joint). Arguably
column4: this definition was chosen to underline what is unique to the human thumb.

column1: The East African maned rat (Lophiomys imhausi)
column2: an arboreal
column3: porcupine-like rodent
column4: has four fingers on its hands and feet and a partially opposable thumb.

column2: in many polydactyl cats

column1: In most phalangerid marsupials (a family of possums) except species Trichosurus and Wyulda
column2: the first and second toes of the forefoot are opposable to the other three. In the hind foot
column3: the first toe is clawless but opposable and provides firm grip on branches. The second and third toes are partly syndactylous
column4: united by skin at the top joint while the two separate nails serve as hair combs. The fourth and fifth toes are the largest of the hind foot.

column1: Koalas have five toes on their fore and hind feet with sharp curved claws except for the first toe of the hind foot. The first and second toes of the forefeet are opposable to the other three
column2: which enables the koala to grip smaller branches and search for fresh leaves in the outer canopy. Similar to the phalangerids
column3: the second and third toes of the hind foot are fused but have separate claws.

column1: Opossums are New World marsupials with opposable thumbs in the hind feet giving these animals their characteristic grasping capability (with the exception of the water opossum
column2: the webbed feet of which restrict opposability).

column2: Dromiciops gliroides
column3: is not closely related to opossums but has paws similar to these animals
column4: each having opposable toes adapted for gripping.

column1: The front feet of chameleons are organized into a medial bundle of toes 1
column2: 2 and 3
column3: and a lateral bundle of toes 4 and 5
column4: and the hind feet are organized into a medial bundle of toes 1 and 2
column5: and a lateral bundle of toes 3
column6: 4 and 5.

column1: Dinosaurs belonging to the family of bird-like dinosaur Troodontidae had a partially opposable finger. It is possible that this adaptation was used to better manipulate ground objects or moving undergrowth branches when searching for prey.

The small predatory dinosaur Bambiraptor may have had mutually opposable first and third fingers and a forelimb manoeuvrability that would allow the hand to reach its mouth. Its forelimb morphology and range of motion enabled two-handed prehension
column2: one-handed clutching of objects to the chest
column3: and use of the hand as a hook.

column1: Nqwebasaurus — a coelurosaur with a long
column2: three-fingered hand which included a partially opposable thumb (a ""killer claw"").
some other dinosaurs may have had partially or completely opposed toes in order to manipulate food and/or grasp prey.

column1: Most birds have at least one opposable toe on the foot
column2: in various configurations
column3: though these are seldom called ""thumbs"". They are more often known simply as halluxes.

column1: The wukongopterid pterosaur Kunpengopterus bore an opposable first toe on each wing. The presence of opposable thumbs in this taxon is thought to be an arboreal adaptation.

column2: a genus of frogs native to South America.

column1: The skeleton of the thumb consists of the first metacarpal bone which articulates proximally with the carpus at the carpometacarpal joint and distally with the proximal phalanx at the metacarpophalangeal joint. This latter bone articulates with the distal phalanx at the interphalangeal joint. Additionally
column2: there are two sesamoid bones at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

column1: The muscles of the thumb can be compared to guy-wires supporting a flagpole; tension from these muscular guy-wires must be provided in all directions to maintain stability in the articulated column formed by the bones of the thumb. Because this stability is actively maintained by muscles rather than by articular constraints
column2: most muscles attached to the thumb tend to be active during most thumb motions.

column1: The muscles acting on the thumb can be divided into two groups: The extrinsic hand muscles
column2: with their muscle bellies located in the forearm
column3: and the intrinsic hand muscles
column4: with their muscle bellies located in the hand proper.

column2: the flexor pollicis longus (FPL) originates on the anterior side of the radius distal to the radial tuberosity and from the interosseous membrane. It passes through the carpal tunnel in a separate tendon sheath
column3: after which it lies between the heads of the flexor pollicis brevis. It finally attaches onto the base of the distal phalanx of the thumb. It is innervated by the anterior interosseus branch of the median nerve (C7-C8) It is a persistence of one of the former contrahentes muscles that pulled the fingers or toes together.

column1: Three dorsal forearm muscles act on the thumb:
The abductor pollicis longus (APL) originates on the dorsal sides of both the ulna and the radius
column2: and from the interosseous membrane. Passing through the first tendon compartment
column3: it inserts to the base of the first metacarpal bone. A part of the tendon reaches the trapezium
column4: while another fuses with the tendons of the extensor pollicis brevis and the abductor pollicis brevis. Except for abducting the hand
column5: it flexes the hand towards the palm and abducts it radially. It is innervated by the deep branch of the radial nerve (C7-C8).

column1: The extensor pollicis longus (EPL) originates on the dorsal side of the ulna and the interosseous membrane. Passing through the third tendon compartment
column2: it is inserted onto the base of the distal phalanx of the thumb. It uses the dorsal tubercle on the lower extremity of the radius as a fulcrum to extend the thumb and also dorsiflexes and abducts the hand at the wrist. It is innervated by the deep branch of the radial nerve (C7-C8).

column1: The extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) originates on the ulna distal to the abductor pollicis longus
column2: from the interosseus membrane
column3: and from the dorsal side of the radius. Passing through the first tendon compartment together with the abductor pollicis longus
column4: it is attached to the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. It extends the thumb and
column5: because of its close relationship to the long abductor
column6: also abducts the thumb. It is innervated by the deep branch of the radial nerve (C7-T1).

column1: The tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis form what is known as the anatomical snuff box (an indentation on the lateral aspect of the thumb at its base) The radial artery can be palpated anteriorly at the wrist (not in the snuffbox).

The abductor pollicis brevis (APB) originates on the scaphoid tubercle and the flexor retinaculum. It inserts to the radial sesamoid bone and the proximal phalanx of the thumb. It is innervated by the median nerve (C8-T1).
The flexor pollicis brevis (FPB) has two heads. The superficial head arises on the flexor retinaculum
column2: while the deep head originates on three carpal bones: the trapezium
column3: trapezoid
column4: and capitate. The muscle is inserted onto the radial sesamoid bone of the metacarpophalangeal joint. It acts to flex
column5: adduct
column6: and abduct the thumb
column7: and is therefore also able to oppose the thumb. The superficial head is innervated by the median nerve
column8: while the deep head is innervated by the ulnar nerve (C8-T1).

column1: The opponens pollicis originates on the tubercle of the trapezium and the flexor retinaculum. It is inserted onto the radial side of the first metacarpal. It opposes the thumb and assists in adduction. It is innervated by the median nerve.
The adductor pollicis also has two heads. The transversal head originates along the entire third metacarpal bone
column2: while the oblique head originates on the carpal bones proximal to the third metacarpal. The muscle is inserted onto the ulnar sesamoid bone of the metacarpophalangeal joint. It adducts the thumb
column3: and assists in opposition and flexion. It is innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve (C8-T1).

column2: one of the central muscles of the hand
column3: extends from the base of the thumb metacarpal to the radial side of the proximal phalanx of the index finger.

column1: There is a variation of the human thumb where the angle between the first and second (proximal and distal) phalanges varies between 0° and almost 90° when the thumb is in a thumbs-up gesture.
It has been suggested that the variation is an autosomal recessive trait
column2: called a hitchhiker's thumb
column3: with homozygous carriers having an angle close to 90°. However this theory has been disputed
column4: since the variation in thumb angle is known to fall on a continuum and shows little evidence of the bi-modality seen in other recessive genetic traits.

column1: Other variations of the thumb include brachydactyly type D (which is a thumb with a congenitally short distal phalanx)
column2: a triphalangeal thumb (which is a thumb which has 3 phalanges instead of the usual two)
column3: and polysyndactyly (which is a combination of radial polydactyly and syndactyly).

column1: One of the earlier significant contributors to the study of hand grips was orthopedic primatologist and paleoanthropologist John Napier
column2: who proposed organizing the movements of the hand by their anatomical basis as opposed to work done earlier that had only used arbitrary classification. Most of this early work on hand grips had a pragmatic basis as it was intended to narrowly define compensable injuries to the hand
column3: which required an understanding of the anatomical basis of hand movement. Napier proposed two primary prehensile grips: the precision grip and the power grip. The precision and power grip are defined by the position of the thumb and fingers where:

column1: The power grip is when the fingers (and sometimes palm) clamp down on an object with the thumb making counter pressure. Examples of the power grip are gripping a hammer
column2: opening a jar using both your palm and fingers
column3: and during pullups.

column1: The precision grip is when the intermediate and distal phalanges (""fingertips"") and the thumb press against each other. Examples of a precision grip are writing with a pencil
column2: opening a jar with the fingertips alone
column3: and gripping a ball (only if the ball is not tight against the palm).

column1: Opposability of the thumb should not be confused with a precision grip as some animals possess semi-opposable thumbs yet are known to have extensive precision grips (Tufted Capuchins for example). Nevertheless
column2: precision grips are usually only found in higher apes
column3: and only in degrees significantly more restricted than in humans.

column1: The pad-to-pad pinch between the thumb and index finger is made possible because of the human ability to passively hyperextend the distal phalanx of the index finger. Most non-human primates have to flex their long fingers in order for the small thumb to reach them.

column2: the distal pads are wider than in other primates because the soft tissues of the finger tip are attached to a horseshoe-shaped edge on the underlying bone
column3: and
column4: in the grasping hand
column5: the distal pads can therefore conform to uneven surfaces while pressure is distributed more evenly in the finger tips. The distal pad of the human thumb is divided into a proximal and a distal compartment
column6: the former more deformable than the latter
column7: which allows the thumb pad to mold around an object.

column2: almost all robotic hands have a long and strong opposable thumb. Like human hands
column3: the thumb of a robotic hand also plays a key role in gripping an object. One inspiring approach of robotic grip planning is to mimic human thumb placement.

column2: human thumb placement indicates which surface or part of the object is good for grip. Then the robot places its thumb to the same location and plans the other fingers based on the thumb placement.

column1: The function of the thumb declines physiologically with aging. This can be demonstrated by assessing the motor sequencing of the thumb.
A primitive autonomization of the first carpometacarpal joint (CMC) may have occurred in dinosaurs. A real differentiation appeared an estimated 70 mya in early primates
column2: while the shape of the human thumb CMC finally appears about 5 mya. The result of this evolutionary process is a human CMC joint positioned at 80° of pronation
column3: 40 of abduction
column4: and 50° of flexion in relation to an axis passing through the second and third CMC joints.

column1: Opposable thumbs are shared by some primates
column2: including most catarrhines. The climbing and suspensory behaviour in orthograde apes
column3: such as chimpanzees
column4: has resulted in elongated hands while the thumb has remained short. As a result
column5: these primates are unable to perform the pad-to-pad grip associated with opposability. However
column6: in pronograde monkeys such as baboons
column7: an adaptation to a terrestrial lifestyle has led to reduced finger length and thus hand proportions similar to those of humans. Consequently
column8: these primates have dexterous hands and are able to grasp objects using a pad-to-pad grip. It can thus be difficult to identify hand adaptations to manipulation-related tasks based solely on thumb proportions.

column1: The evolution of the fully opposable thumb is usually associated with Homo habilis
column2: a forerunner of Homo sapiens. This
column3: however
column4: is the suggested result of evolution from Homo erectus (around 1 mya) via a series of intermediate anthropoid stages
column5: and is therefore a much more complicated link.

column1: Modern humans are unique in the musculature of their forearm and hand.  Yet
column2: they remain autapomorphic
column3: meaning each muscle is found in one or more non-human primates. The extensor pollicis brevis and flexor pollicis longus allow modern humans to have great manipulative skills and strong flexion in the thumb.

column2: a more likely scenario may be that the specialized precision gripping hand (equipped with opposable thumb) of Homo habilis preceded walking
column3: with the specialized adaptation of the spine
column4: pelvis
column5: and lower extremities preceding a more advanced hand. And
column6: it is logical that a conservative
column7: highly functional adaptation be followed by a series of more complex ones that complement it. With Homo habilis
column8: an advanced grasping-capable hand was accompanied by facultative bipedalism
column9: possibly implying
column10: assuming a co-opted evolutionary relationship exists
column11: that the latter resulted from the former as obligate bipedalism was yet to follow. Walking may have been a by-product of busy hands and not vice versa.

column1: HACNS1 (also known as Human Accelerated Region 2) is a gene enhancer ""that may have contributed to the evolution of the uniquely opposable human thumb
column2: and possibly also modifications in the ankle or foot that allow humans to walk on two legs"". Evidence to date shows that of the 110
column3: 000 gene enhancer sequences identified in the human genome
column4: HACNS1 has undergone the most change during the human evolution since the chimpanzee–human last common ancestor.
