https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chin|A14.521.632.300;A02.835.232.781.324.502.632.130;A01.456.505.259|D002680|Chin|"The chin is the forward pointed part of the anterior mandible (mental region) below the lower lip. A fully developed human skull has a chin of between 0.7 cm and 1.1 cm.

The presence of a well-developed chin is considered to be one of the morphological characteristics of Homo sapiens that differentiates them from other human ancestors such as the closely related Neanderthals. Early human ancestors have varied symphysial morphology
column2: but none of them have a well-developed chin. The origin of the chin is traditionally associated with the anterior–posterior breadth shortening of the dental arch or tooth row; however
column3: its general mechanical or functional advantage during feeding
column4: developmental origin
column5: and link with human speech
column6: physiology
column7: and social influence are highly debated.

column1: Robinson (1913) suggests that the demand to resist masticatory stresses triggered bone thickening in the mental region of the mandible and ultimately formed a prominent chin. Moreover
column2: Daegling (1993) explains the chin as a functional adaptation to resist masticatory stress that causes vertical bending stresses in the coronal plane. Others have argued that the prominent chin is adapted to resisting wishboning  forces
column3: dorso-ventral shear forces
column4: and generally a mechanical advantage to resist lateral transverse bending and vertical bending in the coronal plane. On the contrary
column5: others have suggested that the presence of the chin is not related to mastication. The presence of thick bone in the relatively small mandible may indicate better force resistance capacity. However
column6: the question  stands of whether the chin is an adaptive or nonadaptive structure.

column1: Recent works on the morphological changes of the mandible during development have shown that the human chin
column2: or at least the inverted-T shaped mental region
column3: develops during the prenatal period
column4: but the chin does not become prominent until the early postnatal period. This later modification happens by bone remodeling processes (bone resorption and bone deposition). Coquerelle et al. show that the anteriorly positioned cervical column of the spine and forward displacement of the hyoid bone limit the anterior–posterior breadth in the oral cavity for the tongue
column5: laryngeal
column6: and suprahyoid musculatures. Accordingly
column7: this leads the upper parts of the mandible (alveolar process) to retract posteriorly
column8: following the posterior movement of the upper tooth row
column9: while the lower part of the symphysis remained protruded to create more space
column10: thereby creating the inverted-T shaped mental relief during early ages and the prominent chin later. The alveolar region (upper or superior part of the symphysis) is sculpted by bone resorption
column11: but the chin (lower or inferior part) is depository in its nature. These coordinated bone growth and modeling processes mold the vertical symphysis present at birth into the prominent shape of the chin.

column1: Recent research on the development of the chin suggests that the evolution of this unique characteristic was formed not by mechanical forces such as chewing but by evolutionary adaptations involving reduction in size and change in shape of the face. Holton et al. claim that this adaptation occurred as the face became smaller compared to that of other ancient humans.
Robert Franciscus takes a more anthropological viewpoint: he believes that the chin was formed as a consequence of the change in lifestyle humans underwent approximately 80
column2: 000 years ago. As humans' hunter-gatherer societies grew into larger social networks
column3: territorial disputes decreased because the new social structure promoted building alliances in order to exchange goods and belief systems. Franciscus believes that this change in the human environment reduced hormone levels
column4: especially in men
column5: resulting in the natural evolution of the chin.

column2: human beings are unique in the sense that they are the only species among primates who have chins. In the paper The Enduring Puzzle of the Human Chin
column3: evolutionary anthropologists James Pampush and David Daegling discuss various theories that have been raised to solve the puzzle of the chin. They conclude that ""each of the proposals we have discussed falter either empirically or theoretically; some fail
column4: to a degree
column5: on both accounts… This should serve as motivation
column6: not discouragement
column7: for researchers to continue investigating this modern human peculiarity… perhaps understanding the chin will reveal some unexpected insight into what it means to be human.""

column2: chin cleft
column3: dimple chin
column4: or chin dimple refer to  a dimple on the chin. It is a Y-shaped fissure on the chin with an underlying bony peculiarity. Specifically
column5: the chin fissure follows the fissure in the lower jaw bone that resulted from the incomplete fusion of the left and right halves of the jaw bone
column6: or muscle
column7: during the embryonal and fetal development. It can also develop during the later mandibular symphysis
column8: due to growth of the mental protuberance during puberty
column9: or as a result of acromegaly. In some cases
column10: one mental tubercle may grow more than another
column11: which can cause facial asymmetry.

column1: A cleft chin is an inherited trait in humans and can be influenced by many factors. The cleft chin is also a classic example of variable penetrance with environmental factors or a modifier gene possibly affecting the phenotypical expression of the actual genotype. Cleft chins can be presented in a child when neither parent presents a cleft chin. Cleft chins are common among people originating from Europe
column2: the Middle East and South Asia.

column1: There is a possible genetic cause for cleft chins
column2: a genetic marker called rs11684042
column3: which is located in chromosome 2.

column2: the chin dimple is considered a factor of beauty and is metaphorically referred to as ""the chin pit"" or ""the chin well"": a well in which the poor lover is fallen and trapped.

column1: A double chin is a loss of definition of the jawbone or soft tissue under the chin. There are two possible causes for a double chin
column2: which have to be differentiated.
commonly the layer of subcutaneous fat around the neck sags down and creates a wrinkle
column3: creating the appearance of a second chin. This fat pad is occasionally surgically removed and the corresponding muscles under the jaw shortened (hyoid lift).

column1: Another cause can be a bony deficiency
column2: commonly seen in people of normal weight. When the jaw bones (mandible and by extension the maxilla) do not project forward enough
column3: the chin in turn will not project forward enough to give the impression of a defined jawline and chin. Despite low amounts of fat in the area
column4: it can appear as if the chin is melting into the neck. The extent of this deficiency can vary drastically and usually has to be treated surgically. In some patients
column5: the aesthetic deficit can be overcome with genioplasty alone
column6: in others the lack of forward growth might warrant orthognathic surgery to move one or two jaws forward. If the patient suffers from sleep apnea
column7: early maxillomandibular advancement is usually the only causal treatment and necessary to preserve normal life expectancy.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heel|A01.378.610.250.510|D006365|Heel|"The heel is the prominence at the posterior end of the foot. It is based on the projection of one bone
column2: the calcaneus or heel bone
column3: behind the articulation of the bones of the lower leg.

column1: To distribute the compressive forces exerted on the heel during gait
column2: and especially the stance phase when the heel contacts the ground
column3: the sole of the foot is covered by a layer of subcutaneous connective tissue up to 2 cm thick (under the heel). This tissue has a system of pressure chambers that both acts as a shock absorber and stabilises the sole.  Each of these chambers contains fibrofatty tissue covered by a layer of tough connective tissue made of collagen fibers. These septa (""walls"") are firmly attached both to the plantar aponeurosis above and the sole's skin below. The sole of the foot is one of the most highly vascularized regions of the body surface
column4: and the dense system of blood vessels further stabilize the septa.

column1: The Achilles tendon is the muscle tendon of the triceps surae
column2: a ""three-headed"" group of muscles—the soleus and the two heads of the gastrocnemius. The main function of the triceps surae is plantar flexion
column3: i.e. to stretch the foot downward. It is accompanied by a ""fourth head""
column4: the slight plantaris muscle
column5: the long slender tendon of which is also attached to the heel bone but not visible.

column1: The compressive forces applied to the foot are distributed along five rays
column2: three medial (side of big toe) and two lateral (side of little toe). The lateral rays stretch over the cuboid bone to the heel bone and the medial rays over the three cuneiform bones and the navicular bone to the ankle bone. Because the ankle bone is placed over the heel bone
column3: these rays are adjacent near the toes but overriding near the heel
column4: and together they form the arches of the foot that are optimized to distributed compressive forces across an uneven terrain. In this context the heel thus forms the posterior point of support that together with the balls of the large and little toes bear the brunt of the loads.

column1: Cracked heels is a common health problem and it may cause infections. It is caused by dryness of the foot skin
column2: and accumulation of dead skin. Over time
column3: it may cause pain and irritations. Various moisturising creams and foot files are available to cure and prevent it.

column2: both the hoofed species (unguligrade) and the clawed forms which walk on the toes (digitigrade)
column3: the heel is well above the ground at the apex of the angular joint known as the hock. In plantigrade species
column4: it rests on the ground. In birds
column5: the heel is the backward-pointing joint which is often mistaken as the ""knee"" (the actual knee of birds is hidden under the plumage).

column1: The articulations between the bones of the shoulder make up the shoulder joints. The shoulder joint
column2: also known as the glenohumeral joint
column3: is the major joint of the shoulder
column4: but can more broadly include the acromioclavicular joint.

column2: the shoulder joint comprises the part of the body where the humerus attaches to the scapula
column3: and the head sits in the glenoid cavity. The shoulder is the group of structures in the region of the joint.

column1: The shoulder joint is the main joint of the shoulder.  It is a ball and socket joint that allows the arm to rotate in a circular fashion or to hinge out and up away from the body.  The joint capsule is a soft tissue envelope that encircles the glenohumeral joint and attaches to the scapula
column2: humerus
column3: and head of the biceps. It is lined by a thin
column4: smooth synovial membrane. The rotator cuff is a group of four muscles that surround the shoulder joint and contribute to the shoulder's stability. The muscles of the rotator cuff are supraspinatus
column5: subscapularis
column6: infraspinatus
column7: and teres minor. The cuff adheres to the glenohumeral capsule and attaches to the humeral head.

column1: The shoulder must be mobile enough for the wide range actions of the arms and hands
column2: but stable enough to allow for actions such as lifting
column3: pushing
column4: and pulling.

column1: The shoulder consists of a ball-and-socket joint formed by the humerus and scapula and their surrounding structures - ligaments
column2: muscles
column3: tendons - which support the bones and maintain the relationship of one to another. These supporting structures attach to the clavicle
column4: humerus
column5: and scapula
column6: the latter providing the glenoid cavity
column7: acromion and coracoid processes. The main joint of the shoulder is the shoulder joint (or glenohumeral joint)
column8: between the humerus and the glenoid process of the scapular. The acromioclavicular joint and sternoclavicular joint also play a role in shoulder movements. White hyaline cartilage on the ends of the bones (called articular cartilage) allows the bones to glide and move on each other
column9: and the joint space is surrounded by a synovial membrane. Around the joint space are muscles - the rotator cuff
column10: which directly surrounds and attaches to the shoulder joint - and other muscles that help provide stability and facilitate movement.

column1: Two filmy sac-like structures called bursae permit smooth gliding between bone
column2: muscle
column3: and tendon. They cushion and protect the rotator cuff from the bony arch of the acromion.

column1: The glenoid labrum is the second kind of cartilage in the shoulder which is distinctly different from the articular cartilage. This cartilage is more fibrous or rigid than the cartilage on the ends of the ball and socket. Also
column2: this cartilage is also found only around the socket where it is attached.

column1: The shoulder joint (also known as the glenohumeral joint) is the main joint of the shoulder. It is a ball and socket joint that allows the arm to rotate in a circular fashion or to hinge out and up away from the body.  It is formed by the articulation between the head of the humerus and the lateral scapula (specifically-the glenoid cavity of the scapula).  The ""ball"" of the joint is the rounded
column2: medial anterior surface of the humerus and the ""socket"" is formed by the glenoid cavity
column3: the dish-shaped portion of the lateral scapula.  The shallowness of the cavity and relatively loose connections between the shoulder and the rest of the body allows the arm to have tremendous mobility
column4: at the expense of being much easier to dislocate than most other joints in the body. There is an approximately 4-to-1 disproportion in size between the large head of the humerus and the shallow glenoid cavity.The glenoid cavity is made deeper by the addition of the fibrocartilaginous ring of the glenoid labrum.

column1: The capsule is a soft tissue envelope that encircles the glenohumeral joint and attaches to the scapula
column2: humerus
column3: and head of the biceps. It is lined by a thin
column4: smooth synovial membrane.  This capsule is strengthened by the coracohumeral ligament which attaches the coracoid process of the scapula to the greater tubercle of the humerus.  There are also three other ligaments attaching the lesser tubercle of the humerus to lateral scapula and are collectively called the glenohumeral ligaments.

column2: which passes from the lesser tubercle to the greater tubercle of humerus
column3: covers the intertubercular groove

column1: The rotator cuff is an anatomical term given to the group of four muscles and their tendons that act to stabilize the shoulder. These muscles are the supraspinatus
column2: infraspinatus
column3: teres minor and subscapularis and that hold the head of the humerus in the glenoid cavity during movement. The cuff adheres to the glenohumeral capsule and attaches to the head of the humerus. Together
column4: these keep the humeral head in the glenoid cavity
column5: preventing upward migration of the humeral head caused by the pull of the deltoid muscle at the beginning of arm elevation. The infraspinatus and the teres minor
column6: along with the anterior fibers of the deltoid muscle
column7: are responsible for external rotation of the arm.

column1: The four tendons of these muscles converge to form the rotator cuff tendon.  This tendon
column2: along with the articular capsule
column3: the coracohumeral ligament
column4: and the glenohumeral ligament complex
column5: blend into a confluent sheet before insertion into the humeral tuberosities.  The infraspinatus and teres minor fuse near their musculotendinous junctions
column6: while the supraspinatus and subscapularis tendons join as a sheath that surrounds the biceps tendon at the entrance of the bicipital groove.

column1: In addition to the four muscles of the rotator cuff
column2: the deltoid muscle and teres major muscles arise and exist in the shoulder region itself. The deltoid muscle covers the shoulder joint on three sides
column3: arising from the front upper third of the clavicle
column4: the acromion
column5: and the spine of the scapula
column6: and travelling to insert on the deltoid tubercle of the humerus. Contraction of each part of the deltoid assists in different movements of the shoulder - flexion (clavicular part)
column7: abduction (middle part) and extension (scapular part). The teres major attaches to the outer part of the back of the scapula
column8: beneath the teres minor
column9: and attaches to the upper part of the humerus. It helps with medial rotation of the humerus.

column1: Muscles from the chest wall that contribute to the shoulder are:
The armpit (Latin: axilla) is formed by the space between the muscles of the shoulder. The nerves and blood vessels of the arm travel through the armpit
column2: and it possesses several sets of lymph nodes that are able to be examined. The armpit is formed by the pectoralis major and minor muscles at the front
column3: the latissimus dorsi and teres major muscles at the back
column4: the serratus anterior muscle on its inner surface
column5: and the intertubercular groove of the humerus on the outer side.

column1: The skin around the shoulder is supplied by C2-C4 (upper)
column2: and C7 and T2 (lower area). The brachial plexus emerges as nerve roots from the cervical vertebrae C5-T1. Branches of the plexus
column3: in particular from C5-C6
column4: supply the majority of the muscles of the shoulder.

column1: The subclavian artery arises from the brachiocephalic trunk on the right and directly from the aorta from the left.  This becomes the axillary artery as it passes beyond the first rib. The axillary artery also supplies blood to the arm
column2: and is one of the major sources of blood to the shoulder region. The other major sources are the transverse cervical artery and the suprascapular artery
column3: both branches of the thyrocervical trunk which itself is a branch of the subclavian artery. The blood vessels form a network (anastamosis) behind the shoulder that helps to supply blood to the arm even when the axillary artery is compromised.

column1: The muscles and joints of the shoulder allow it to move through a remarkable range of motion
column2: making it one of the most mobile joints in the human body.  The shoulder can abduct
column3: adduct
column4: rotate
column5: be raised in front of and behind the torso and move through a full 360° in the sagittal plane.  This tremendous range of motion also makes the shoulder extremely unstable
column6: far more prone to dislocation and injury than other joints

column1: The following describes the terms used for different movements of the shoulder:
Under the influence of testosterone and growth hormone
column2: the shoulders broaden in males during puberty.

column1: The shoulder is the most mobile and potentially unstable joint in the body. Due to this
column2: it is often prone to problems.

column1: Fractures of shoulder bones can include clavicular fractures
column2: scapular fractures
column3: and fractures of the upper humerus.

column2: including pain
column3: are common and can relate to any of the structures within the shoulder. The primary cause of shoulder pain is a rotator cuff tear. The supraspinatus is most commonly involved in a rotator cuff tear.

column1: When this type of cartilage starts to wear out (a process called arthritis)

column1: Imaging of the shoulder includes ultrasound

column2: and the standing or sitting patient lets the arm hang. This method reveals the joint gap and the vertical alignment towards the socket.

The horizontal centralization of the humerus head and socket

This projection has a low tolerance for errors and
column2: accordingly

column1: There are several advantages of ultrasound. It is relatively cheap
column2: does not emit any radiation
column3: is accessible
column4: is capable of visualizing tissue function in real time
column5: and allows the performance of provocative maneuvers in order to replicate the patient’s pain.  Those benefits have helped ultrasound become a common initial choice for assessing tendons and soft tissues. Limitations include
column6: for example
column7: the high degree of operator dependence and the inability to define pathologies in bones.  One also has to have an extensive anatomical knowledge of the examined region and keep an open mind to normal variations and artifacts created during the scan.

column2: like medical training in general
column3: is a lifelong process
column4: Kissin et al. suggests that rheumatologists who taught themselves how to manipulate ultrasound can use it just as well as international musculo-skeletal ultrasound experts to diagnose common rheumatic conditions.

column1: After the introduction of high-frequency transducers in the mid-1980s
column2: ultrasound has become a conventional tool for taking accurate and precise images of the shoulder to support diagnosis.

column1: Adequate for the examination are high-resolution
column2: high-frequency transducers with a transmission frequency of 5
column4: and 10 MHz. To improve the focus on structures close to the skin an additional ""water start-up length"" is advisable. During the examination the patient is asked to be seated
column5: the affected arm is then adducted and the elbow is bent to 90 degrees. Slow and cautious passive lateral and/or medial rotations have the effect of being able to visualize different sections of the shoulder. In order to also demonstrate those parts which are hidden under the acromion in the neutral position
column6: a maximum medial rotation with hyperextension behind the back is required.

column1: To avoid the different tendon echogenicities caused by different instrument settings
column2: Middleton compared the tendon’s echogenicity with that of the deltoid muscle
column3: which is still lege artis.

column1: Usually the echogenicity compared to the deltoid muscle is homogeneous intensified without dorsal echo extinction. Variability with reduced or intensified echo has also been found in healthy tendons. Bilateral comparison is very helpful when distinguishing and setting boundaries between physiological variants and a possible pathological finding. Degenerative changes at the rotator cuff often are found on both sides of the body. Consequently
column2: unilateral differences rather point to a pathological source and bilateral changes rather to a physiological variation.
a dynamic examination can help to differentiate between an ultrasound artifact and a real pathology.

column1: To accurately evaluate the echogenicity of an ultrasound
column2: one has to take into account the physical laws of reflection
column3: absorption and dispersion. It is at all times important to acknowledge that the structures in the joint of the shoulder are not aligned in the transversal
column4: coronal or sagittal plane
column5: and that therefore during imaging of the shoulder the transducer head has to be held perpendicularly or parallel to the structures of interest. Otherwise the appearing echogenicity may not be evaluated.

column1: Orthopedics established the MRI early on as the tool of choice for joint- and soft tissue-imaging because of its non-invasiveness

column1: MRIs can provide joint details to the treating orthopedist

the patient should lay down with the concerned arm is in lateral rotation. For signal detection it is recommended to use a surface-coil. To find pathologies of the rotator cuff in the basic diagnostic investigation

column1: Most morphological changes and injuries are sustained to the supraspinatus tendon. Traumatic rotator cuff changes are often located antero-superior
column2: meanwhile degenerative changes more likely are supero-posterior.

column1: Tendons are predominantly composed of dense collagen fiber bundles. Because of their extreme short T2-relaxation time they appear typically signal-weak

column4: inflammations and also partial and complete tears cause loss of the original tendon structure. Fatty deposits

Weishaupt D. et al. reached through two readers a significant better visibility of pulley lesions at the rotator interval and the expected location of the reflection pulley of the long biceps and subscapularis tendon on parasagittal (reader1/reader2 sensitivity: 86%/100%; specificity: 90%/70%) and axial (reader1/reader2 sensitivity: 86%/93%; specificity: 90%/80%) MRA images.

column1: Tetrapod forelimbs are characterised by a high degree of mobility in the shoulder-thorax connection.  Lacking a solid skeletal connection between the shoulder girdle and the vertebral column

column2: the shoulder shows characteristics that differ from other mammals

column1: In terms of comparative anatomy the human scapula represents two bones that have become fused together; the (dorsal) scapula proper and the (ventral) coracoid. column1: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pelvic_floor|A01.923.112.500;A02.633.567.050.750;A01.923.600.600|D017773|Pelvic floor|"The pelvic floor or pelvic diaphragm is an anatomical location in the human body
column2: which has an important role in urinary and anal continence
column3: sexual function and support of the pelvic organs. The pelvic floor includes muscles
column4: both skeletal and smooth
column5: ligaments and fascia. and separates between the pelvic cavity from above
column6: and the  perineum from below. It is formed by the levator ani muscle and coccygeus muscle
column7: and associated connective tissue.

column1: The pelvic floor has two hiatuses (gaps): (anteriorly) the urogenital hiatus through which urethra and vagina pass
column2: and (posteriorly) the rectal hiatus through which the anal canal passes.

column1: Some sources do not consider ""pelvic floor"" and ""pelvic diaphragm"" to be identical
column2: with the ""diaphragm"" consisting of only the levator ani and coccygeus
column3: while the ""floor"" also includes the perineal membrane and deep perineal pouch. However
column4: other sources include the fascia as part of the diaphragm. In practice
column5: the two terms are often used interchangeably.

column1: The pelvic cavity of the true pelvis has the pelvic floor as its inferior boundary (and the pelvic brim as its superior boundary). The perineum has the pelvic floor as its superior boundary.

column2: the pelvic floor extends into the anal triangle.

column1: It is important in providing support for pelvic viscera (organs)
column2: e.g. the bladder
column3: intestines
column4: the uterus (in females)
column5: and in maintenance of continence as part of the urinary and anal sphincters. It facilitates birth by resisting the descent of the presenting part
column6: causing the fetus to rotate forwards to navigate through the pelvic girdle. It helps maintain optimal intra-abdominal pressure.

column1: The pelvic floor is subject to clinically relevant changes that can result in:
Vaginal vault prolapse (roof of vagina) - after hysterectomy
Pelvic floor dysfunction can result after treatment for gynecological cancers.
Damage to the pelvic floor not only contributes to urinary incontinence but can lead to pelvic organ prolapse.  Pelvic organ prolapse occurs in women when pelvic organs (e.g. the vagina
column2: bladder
column3: rectum
column4: or uterus) protrude into or outside of the vagina.  The causes of pelvic organ prolapse are not unlike those that also contribute to urinary incontinence.  These include inappropriate (asymmetrical
column5: excessive
column6: insufficient) muscle tone and asymmetries caused by trauma to the pelvis.  Age
column7: pregnancy
column8: family history
column9: and hormonal status all contribute to the development of pelvic organ prolapse.  The vagina is suspended by attachments to the perineum
column10: pelvic side wall and sacrum via attachments that include collagen
column11: elastin
column12: and smooth muscle.  Surgery can be performed to repair pelvic floor muscles.  The pelvic floor muscles can be strengthened with Kegel exercises.

column1: Disorders of the posterior pelvic floor include rectal prolapse
column2: rectocele
column3: perineal hernia
column4: and a number of functional disorders including anismus. Constipation due to any of these disorders is called ""functional constipation"" and is identifiable by clinical diagnostic criteria.

column2: also known as Kegel exercises
column3: may improve the tone and function of the pelvic floor muscles
column4: which is of particular benefit for women (and less commonly men) who experience stress urinary incontinence. However
column5: compliance with PFE programs often is poor
column6: PFE generally is ineffective for urinary incontinence unless performed with biofeedback and trained supervision
column7: and in severe cases it may have no benefit. Pelvic floor muscle tone may be estimated using a perineometer
column8: which measures the pressure within the vagina. Medication may also be used to improve continence. In severe cases
column9: surgery may be used to repair or even to reconstruct the pelvic floor. One surgery which interrupts pelvic floor musculature in males is a radical prostatectomy. With the removal of the prostate
column10: many males experience urinary incontinence post operation; pelvic floor exercises may be used to counteract this pre and post operation. Pre-operative pelvic floor exercising significantly decreases the prevalence of urinary incontinence post radical prostatectomy.  Prostatitis and prostatectomies are two contributors to erectile dysfunction; following a radical prostatectomy studies show that erectile dysfunction is improved by pelvic floor muscle training under the supervision of physical therapists certified in pelvic floor rehabilitation .

column1: Perineology or pelviperineology is a specialty dealing with the functional troubles of the three axes (urological
column2: gynecological and coloproctological) of the pelvic floor.

column2: or simply the diaphragm (; Ancient Greek: διάφραγμα
column3: romanized: diáphragma
column4: lit. 'partition')
column5: is a sheet of internal skeletal muscle in humans and other mammals that extends across the bottom of the thoracic cavity. The diaphragm is the most important muscle of respiration
column6: and separates the thoracic cavity
column7: containing the heart and lungs
column8: from the abdominal cavity: as the diaphragm contracts
column9: the volume of the thoracic cavity increases
column10: creating a negative pressure there
column11: which draws air into the lungs. Its high oxygen consumption is noted by the many mitochondria and capillaries present; more than in any other skeletal muscle.

column2: created by Gerard of Cremona
column3: can refer to other flat structures such as the urogenital diaphragm or pelvic diaphragm
column4: but ""the diaphragm"" generally refers to the thoracic diaphragm. In humans
column5: the diaphragm is slightly asymmetric—its right half is higher up (superior) to the left half
column6: since the large liver rests beneath the right half of the diaphragm. There is also speculation that the diaphragm is lower on the other side due to heart's presence.

column2: and other vertebrates such as amphibians and reptiles have diaphragm-like structures
column3: but important details of the anatomy may vary
column4: such as the position of the lungs in the thoracic cavity.

column1: The diaphragm is an upward curved
column2: c-shaped structure of muscle and fibrous tissue that separates the thoracic cavity from the abdomen. The superior surface of the dome forms the floor of the thoracic cavity
column3: and the inferior surface the roof of the abdominal cavity.

column2: the diaphragm has peripheral attachments to structures that make up the abdominal and chest walls. The muscle fibres from these attachments converge in a central tendon
column3: which forms the crest of the dome. Its peripheral part consists of muscular fibers that take origin from the circumference of the inferior thoracic aperture and converge to be inserted into a central tendon.

column1: The muscle fibres of the diaphragm radiate outward from the central tendon. While the diaphragm is one muscle
column2: it is composed of two distinct muscle regions: the costal
column3: which serves as the driver in the work of breathing
column4: and crural diaphragm
column5: which serves as an ""anchor;"" attaching the muscle to the lower ribs and lumbar vertebrae. The costal diaphragm is further divided into ventral
column6: medial
column7: and dorsal costal portions.

column1: The vertebral part of the diaphragm arises from the crura and arcuate ligaments. Right crus arises from L1-L3 vertebral bodies and their intervertebral discs. Smaller left crus arises from L1
column2: L2 vertebral bodies and their intervertebral discs. Medial arcuate ligament arises from the fascia thickening from body of L2 vertebrae to transverse process of L1 vertebrae
column3: crossing over the body of the psoas major muscle. The lateral arcuate ligament arises from the transverse process of L1 vertebrae and is attached laterally to the 12th rib. The lateral arcuate ligament also arises from fascia thickening that covers the quadratus lumborum muscle. The median arcuate ligament arises from the fibrous parts of right and left crura where descending thoracic aorta passes behind it. No diaphramatic muscle arises from the median arcuate ligament. Both adrenal glands lie near the diaphragmatic crus and arcuate ligament.

column1: The costal part of diaphragm arises from the lower four ribs (7 to 10) costal cartilages.
The central tendon of the diaphragm is a thin but strong aponeurosis near the center of the vault formed by the muscle
column2: closer to the front than to the back of the thorax. The central part of the tendon is attached above to pericardium. The both sides of the posterior fibres are attached to paracolic gutters (the curving of ribs before attaching to both sides of the vertebral bodies).

column1: There are a number of openings in the diaphragm through which structures pass between the thorax and abdomen. There are three large openings — one for the aorta (aortic hiatus)
column2: one for the esophagus (esophageal hiatus)
column3: and one for the inferior vena cava (the caval opening)
column4: as well as a series of smaller openings.

column1: The inferior vena cava passes through the caval opening
column2: a quadrilateral opening at the junction of the right and middle leaflets of the central tendon
column3: so that its margins are tendinous. Surrounded by tendons
column4: the opening is stretched open every time inspiration occurs. However
column5: there has been argument that the caval opening actually constricts during inspiration. Since thoracic pressure decreases upon inspiration and draws the caval blood upwards toward the right atrium
column6: increasing the size of the opening allows more blood to return to the heart
column7: maximizing the efficacy of lowered thoracic pressure returning blood to the heart. The aorta does not pierce the diaphragm but rather passes behind it in between the left and right crus.

column1: There are several structures that pierce through the diaphragm
column2: including: left phrenic nerve pierces through the central tendon
column3: greater
column4: lesser
column5: and least thoracic splanchnic nerves pierces through bilateral crura
column6: and lymphatic vessels that pierce throughout the diaphragam
column7: especially behind the diaphragm.

column1: The diaphragm is primarily innervated by the phrenic nerve which is formed from the cervical nerves C3
column2: C4 and C5.  While the central portion of the diaphragm sends sensory afferents via the phrenic nerve
column3: the peripheral portions of the diaphragm send sensory afferents via the intercostal (T5–T11) and subcostal nerves (T12).

column1: Arteries and veins above and below the diaphragm supply and drain blood.

column2: the diaphragm receives blood from branches of the internal thoracic arteries
column3: namely the pericardiacophrenic artery and musculophrenic artery; from the superior phrenic arteries
column4: which arise directly from the thoracic aorta; and from the lower internal intercostal arteries. From below
column5: the inferior phrenic arteries supply the diaphragm.

column1: The diaphragm drains blood into the brachiocephalic veins
column2: azygos veins
column3: and veins that drain into the inferior vena cava and left suprarenal vein.

column1: The sternal portion of the muscle is sometimes wanting and more rarely defects occur in the lateral part of the central tendon or adjoining muscle fibers.
The thoracic diaphragm develops during embryogenesis
column2: beginning in the third week after fertilization with two processes known as transverse folding and longitudinal folding. The septum transversum
column3: the primitive central tendon of the diaphragm
column4: originates at the rostral pole of the embryo and is relocated during longitudinal folding to the ventral thoracic region.  Transverse folding brings the body wall anteriorly to enclose the gut and body cavities.  The pleuroperitoneal membrane and body wall myoblasts
column5: from somatic lateral plate mesoderm
column6: meet the septum transversum to close off the pericardio-peritoneal canals on either side of the presumptive esophagus
column7: forming a barrier that separates the peritoneal and pleuropericardial cavities.  Furthermore
column8: dorsal mesenchyme surrounding the presumptive esophagus form the muscular crura of the diaphragm.

column1: Because the earliest element of the embryological diaphragm
column2: the septum transversum
column3: forms in the cervical region
column4: the phrenic nerve that innervates the diaphragm originates from the cervical spinal cord (C3
column6: and 5).  As the septum transversum descends inferiorly
column7: the phrenic nerve follows
column8: accounting for its circuitous route from the upper cervical vertebrae
column9: around the pericardium
column10: finally to innervate the diaphragm.

column1: The diaphragm is the main muscle of respiration and functions in breathing. During inhalation
column2: the diaphragm contracts and moves in the inferior direction
column3: enlarging the volume of the thoracic cavity and reducing intra-thoracic pressure (the external intercostal muscles also participate in this enlargement)
column4: forcing the lungs to expand. In other words
column5: the diaphragm's movement downwards creates a partial vacuum in the thoracic cavity
column6: which forces the lungs to expand to fill the void
column7: drawing air in the process.

column1: Cavity expansion happens in two extremes
column2: along with intermediary forms. When the lower ribs are stabilized and the central tendon of the diaphragm is mobile
column3: a contraction brings the insertion (central tendon) towards the origins and pushes the lower cavity towards the pelvis
column4: allowing the thoracic cavity to expand downward. This is often called belly breathing. When the central tendon is stabilized and the lower ribs are mobile
column5: a contraction lifts the origins (ribs) up towards the insertion (central tendon) which works in conjunction with other muscles to allow the ribs to slide and the thoracic cavity to expand laterally and upwards.

column1: When the diaphragm relaxes (moves in the superior direction)
column2: air is exhaled by elastic recoil process  of the lung and the tissues lining the thoracic cavity. Assisting this function with muscular effort (called forced exhalation) involves the internal intercostal muscles used in conjunction with the abdominal muscles
column3: which act as an antagonist paired with the diaphragm's contraction. Diaphragm dysfunction is a well-known factor associated with various complications in patients
column4: such as prolonged respiratory failure
column5: difficulties in weaning from mechanical ventilation
column6: extended hospitalization
column7: increased morbidity
column8: and mortality. Studies have reported that a thin diaphragm leads to greater lung compliance
column9: which can contribute to respiratory failure. Furthermore
column10: reduction in diaphragm thickness during the early stages of disease can serve as a prognostic marker in sepsis patients
column11: and COVID-19 patients.

column1: The diaphragm is also involved in non-respiratory functions. It helps to expel vomit
column2: feces
column3: and urine from the body by increasing intra-abdominal pressure
column4: aids in childbirth
column5: and prevents acid reflux by exerting pressure on the esophagus as it passes through the esophageal hiatus.

column2: the diaphragm is not crucial for breathing; a cow
column3: for instance
column4: can survive fairly asymptomatically with diaphragmatic paralysis as long as no massive aerobic metabolic demands are made of it.

column2: cervical spine or brainstem is damaged
column3: this will sever the nervous supply to the diaphragm. The most common damage to the phrenic nerve is by bronchial cancer
column4: which usually only affects one side of the diaphragm. Other causes include Guillain–Barré syndrome and systemic lupus erythematosus.

column1: A hiatus hernia is a hernia common in adults in which parts of the lower esophagus or stomach that are normally in the abdomen pass/bulge abnormally through the diaphragm and are present in the thorax.  Hernias are described as rolling
column2: in which the hernia is beside the oesophagus
column3: or sliding
column4: in which the hernia directly involves the esophagus.  These hernias are implicated in the development of reflux
column5: as the different pressures between the thorax and abdomen normally act to keep pressure on the esophageal hiatus.  With herniation
column6: this pressure is no longer present
column7: and the angle between the cardia of the stomach and the oesophagus disappear. Not all hiatus hernias cause symptoms however
column8: although almost all people with Barrett's oesophagus or oesophagitis have a hiatus hernia.

column1: Hernias may also occur as a result of congenital malformation
column2: a congenital diaphragmatic hernia. When the pleuroperitoneal membranes fail to fuse
column3: the diaphragm does not act as an effective barrier between the abdomen and thorax. Herniation is usually of the left
column4: and commonly through the posterior lumbocostal triangle
column5: although rarely through the anterior foramen of Morgagni. The contents of the abdomen
column6: including the intestines
column7: may be present in the thorax
column8: which may impact development of the growing lungs and lead to hypoplasia. This condition is present in 0.8 - 5/10
column9: 000 births.  A large herniation has high mortality rate
column10: and requires immediate surgical repair.

column1: Due to its position separating the thorax and abdomen
column2: fluid abnormally present in the thorax
column3: or air abnormally present in the abdomen
column4: may collect on one side of the diaphragm. An X-ray may reveal this. Pleural effusion
column5: in which there is fluid abnormally present between the two pleurae of the lungs
column6: is detected by an X-ray of the chest
column7: showing fluid collecting in the angle between the ribs and diaphragm. An X-ray may also be used to reveal a pneumoperitoneum
column8: in which there is gas in the abdomen.

column1: An X-ray may also be used to check for herniation.

The adoption of a deeper breathing pattern typically occurs during physical exercise in order to facilitate greater oxygen absorption. During this process the diaphragm more consistently adopts a lower position within the body's core. In addition to its primary role in breathing
column2: the diaphragm also plays a secondary role in strengthening the posture of the core. This is especially evident during deep breathing where its generally lower position increases intra-abdominal pressure
column3: which serves to strengthen the lumbar spine.

column1: The key to real core stabilization is to maintain the increased IAP while going through normal breathing cycles. [...] The diaphragm then performs its breathing function at a lower position to facilitate a higher IAP.

column2: if a person's diaphragm position is lower in general
column3: through deep breathing
column4: then this assists the strengthening of their core during that period. This can be an aid in strength training and other forms of athletic endeavour. For this reason
column5: taking a deep breath or adopting a deeper breathing pattern is typically recommended when lifting heavy weights.

column1: The existence of a membrane separating the pharynx from the stomach can be traced widely among the chordates.  Thus the model organism
column2: the marine chordate lancelet
column3: possesses an atriopore by which water exits the pharynx
column4: which has been claimed (and disputed) to be homologous to structures in ascidians and hagfishes.  The tunicate epicardium separates digestive organs from the pharynx and heart
column5: but the anus returns to the upper compartment to discharge wastes through an outgoing siphon.

column1: Thus the diaphragm emerges in the context of a body plan that separated an upper feeding compartment from a lower digestive tract
column2: but the point at which it originates is a matter of definition.  Structures in fish
column3: amphibians
column4: reptiles
column5: and birds have been called diaphragms
column6: but it has been argued that these structures are not homologous.  For instance
column7: the alligator diaphragmaticus muscle does not insert on the esophagus and does not affect pressure of the lower esophageal sphincter.  The lungs are located in the abdominal compartment of amphibians and reptiles
column8: so that contraction of the diaphragm expels air from the lungs rather than drawing it into them.  In birds and mammals
column9: lungs are located above the diaphragm.  The presence of an exceptionally well-preserved fossil of Sinosauropteryx
column10: with lungs located beneath the diaphragm as in crocodiles
column11: has been used to argue that dinosaurs could not have sustained an active warm-blooded physiology
column12: or that birds could not have evolved from dinosaurs.  An explanation for this (put forward in 1905)
column13: is that lungs originated beneath the diaphragm
column14: but as the demands for respiration increased in warm-blooded birds and mammals
column15: natural selection came to favor the parallel evolution of the herniation of the lungs from the abdominal cavity in both lineages.

column2: birds do not have diaphragms.  They do not breathe in the same way as mammals and do not rely on creating a negative pressure in the thoracic cavity
column3: at least not to the same extent.  They rely on a rocking motion of the keel of the sternum to create local areas of reduced pressure to supply thin
column4: membranous airsacs cranially and caudally to the fixed-volume
column5: non-expansive lungs.  A complicated system of valves and air sacs cycles air constantly over the absorption surfaces of the lungs so allowing maximal efficiency of gaseous exchange.  Thus
column6: birds do not have the reciprocal tidal breathing flow of mammals.  On careful dissection
column7: around eight air sacs can be clearly seen.  They extend quite far caudally into the abdomen.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elbow|A01.378.800.420|D004550|Elbow|"The elbow is the region between the upper arm and the forearm that surrounds the elbow joint. The elbow includes prominent landmarks such as the olecranon
column2: the cubital fossa (also called the chelidon
column3: or the elbow pit)
column4: and the lateral and the medial epicondyles of the humerus. The elbow joint is a hinge joint between the arm and the forearm; more specifically between the humerus in the upper arm and the radius and ulna in the forearm which allows the forearm and hand to be moved towards and away from the body.

column1: The term elbow is specifically used for humans and other primates
column2: and in other vertebrates it is not used. In those cases
column3: forelimb plus joint is used.

column1: The name for the elbow in Latin is cubitus
column2: and so the word cubital is used in some elbow-related terms
column3: as in cubital nodes for example.

column1: The elbow joint has three different portions surrounded by a common joint capsule. These are joints between the three bones of the elbow
column2: the humerus of the upper arm
column3: and the radius and the ulna of the forearm.

column1: When in anatomical position there are four main bony landmarks of the elbow. At the lower part of the humerus are the medial and lateral epicondyles
column2: on the side closest to the body (medial) and on the side away from the body (lateral) surfaces. The third landmark is the olecranon found at the head of the ulna. These lie on a horizontal line called the Hueter line. When the elbow is flexed
column3: they form a triangle called the Hueter triangle
column4: which resembles an equilateral triangle.

column1: At the surface of the humerus where it faces the joint is the trochlea. In most people
column2: the groove running across the trochlea is vertical on the anterior side but it spirals off on the posterior side.  This results in the forearm being aligned to the upper arm during flexion
column3: but forming an angle to the upper arm during extension — an angle known as the carrying angle.

column1: The superior radioulnar joint shares the joint capsule with the elbow joint but plays no functional role at the elbow.
The elbow joint and the superior radioulnar joint are enclosed by a single fibrous capsule.  The capsule is strengthened by ligaments at the sides but is relatively weak in front and behind.

column2: the capsule consists mainly of longitudinal fibres.  However
column3: some bundles among these fibers run obliquely or transversely
column4: thickening and strengthening the capsule. These bundles are referred to as the capsular ligament.  Deep fibres of the brachialis muscle insert anteriorly into the capsule and act to pull it and the underlying membrane during flexion in order to prevent them from being pinched.

column2: the capsule is thin and mainly composed of transverse fibres.  A few of these fibres stretch across the olecranon fossa without attaching to it and form a transverse band with a free upper border.  On the ulnar side
column3: the capsule reaches down to the posterior part of the annular ligament.  The posterior capsule is attached to the triceps tendon which prevents the capsule from being pinched during extension.

column1: The synovial membrane of the elbow joint is very extensive.  On the humerus
column2: it extends up from the articular margins and covers the coronoid and radial fossae anteriorly and the olecranon fossa posteriorly.  Distally
column3: it is prolonged down to the neck of the radius and the superior radioulnar joint.  It is supported by the quadrate ligament below the annular ligament where it also forms a fold which gives the head of the radius freedom of movement.

column1: Several synovial folds project into the recesses of the joint.
These folds or plicae are remnants of normal embryonic development and can be categorized as either anterior (anterior humeral recess) or posterior (olecranon recess).
A crescent-shaped fold is commonly present between the head of the radius and the capitulum of the humerus.
On the humerus there are extrasynovial fat pads adjacent to the three articular fossae.  These pads fill the radial and coronoid fossa anteriorly during extension
column2: and the olecranon fossa posteriorly during flexion.  They are displaced when the fossae are occupied by the bony projections of the ulna and radius.
like other joints
column3: has ligaments on either side. These are triangular bands which blend with the joint capsule.  They are positioned so that they always lie across the transverse joint axis and are
column4: therefore
column5: always relatively tense and impose strict limitations on abduction
column6: adduction
column7: and axial rotation at the elbow.

column1: The ulnar collateral ligament has its apex on the medial epicondyle.  Its anterior band stretches from the anterior side of the medial epicondyle to the medial edge of the coronoid process
column2: while the posterior band stretches from posterior side of the medial epicondyle to the medial side of the olecranon.  These two bands are separated by a thinner intermediate part and their distal attachments are united by a transverse band below which the synovial membrane protrudes during joint movements.  The anterior band is closely associated with the tendon of the superficial flexor muscles of the forearm
column3: even being the origin of flexor digitorum superficialis.  The ulnar nerve crosses the intermediate part as it enters the forearm.

column1: The radial collateral ligament is attached to the lateral epicondyle below the common extensor tendon.  Less distinct than the ulnar collateral ligament
column2: this ligament blends with the annular ligament of the radius and its margins are attached near the radial notch of the ulna.

column1: There are three main flexor muscles at the elbow:

Brachialis acts exclusively as an elbow flexor and is one of the few muscles in the human body with a single function.  It originates low on the anterior side of the humerus and is inserted into the tuberosity of the ulna.

Brachioradialis acts essentially as an elbow flexor but also supinates during extreme pronation and pronates during extreme supination.  It originates at the lateral supracondylar ridge distally on the humerus and is inserted distally on the radius at the styloid process.
Biceps brachii is the main elbow flexor but
column2: as a biarticular muscle
column3: also plays important secondary roles as a stabiliser at the shoulder and as a supinator.  It originates on the scapula with two tendons: That of the long head on the supraglenoid tubercle just above the shoulder joint and that of the short head on the coracoid process at the top of the scapula.  Its main insertion is at the radial tuberosity on the radius.

column1: Brachialis is the main muscle used when the elbow is flexed slowly.  During rapid and forceful flexion all three muscles are brought into action assisted by the superficial forearm flexors originating at the medial side of the elbow.
The efficiency of the flexor muscles increases dramatically as the elbow is brought into midflexion (flexed 90°) — biceps reaches its angle of maximum efficiency at 80–90° and brachialis at 100–110°.
Active flexion is limited to 145° by the contact between the anterior muscles of the upper arm and forearm
column2: more so because they are hardened by contraction during flexion.  Passive flexion (forearm is pushed against the upper arm with flexors relaxed) is limited to 160° by the bony projections on the radius and ulna as they reach to shallow depressions on the humerus; i.e. the head of radius being pressed against the radial fossa and the coronoid process being pressed against the coronoid fossa.  Passive flexion is further limited by tension in the posterior capsular ligament and in triceps brachii.
so called epitrochleoanconeus muscle
column3: may be found on the medial aspect of the elbow running from the medial epicondyle to the olecranon.

column1: Elbow extension is simply bringing the forearm back to anatomical position.  This action is performed by triceps brachii with a negligible assistance from anconeus.  Triceps originates with two heads posteriorly on the humerus and with its long head on the scapula just below the shoulder joint.  It is inserted posteriorly on the olecranon.
Triceps is maximally efficient with the elbow flexed 20–30°.  As the angle of flexion increases
column2: the position of the olecranon approaches the main axis of the humerus which decreases muscle efficiency.  In full flexion
column3: however
column4: the triceps tendon is ""rolled up"" on the olecranon as on a pulley which compensates for the loss of efficiency.  Because triceps' long head is biarticular (acts on two joints)
column5: its efficiency is also dependent on the position of the shoulder.

column1: Extension is limited by the olecranon reaching the olecranon fossa
column2: tension in the anterior ligament
column3: and resistance in flexor muscles.  Forced extension results in a rupture in one of the limiting structures: olecranon fracture
column4: torn capsule and ligaments
column5: and
column6: though the muscles are normally left unaffected
column7: a bruised brachial artery.

column1: The arteries supplying the joint are derived from an extensive circulatory anastomosis between the brachial artery and its terminal branches.  The superior and inferior ulnar collateral branches of the brachial artery and the radial and middle collateral branches of the profunda brachii artery descend from above to reconnect on the joint capsule
column2: where they also connect with the anterior and posterior ulnar recurrent branches of the ulnar artery; the radial recurrent branch of the radial artery; and the interosseous recurrent branch of the common interosseous artery.

column1: There are two sets of lymphatic nodes at the elbow
column2: normally located above the medial epicondyle — the deep and superficial cubital nodes (also called epitrochlear nodes).  The lymphatic drainage at the elbow is through the deep nodes at the bifurcation of the brachial artery
column3: the superficial nodes drain the forearm and the ulnar side of the hand.  The efferent lymph vessels from the elbow proceed to the lateral group of axillary lymph nodes.

column1: The function of the elbow joint is to extend and flex the arm. The range of movement in the elbow is from 0 degrees of elbow extension to 150 degrees of elbow flexion. Muscles contributing to function are all flexion (biceps brachii
column2: brachialis
column3: and brachioradialis) and extension muscles (triceps and anconeus).

column2: the main task of the elbow is to properly place the hand in space by shortening and lengthening the upper limb.  While the superior radioulnar joint shares joint capsule with the elbow joint
column3: it plays no functional role at the elbow.

column2: the long axis of the humerus and that of the ulna coincide. At the same time
column3: the articular surfaces on both bones are located in front of those axes and deviate from them at an angle of 45°. Additionally
column4: the forearm muscles that originate at the elbow are grouped at the sides of the joint in order not to interfere with its movement.  The wide angle of flexion at the elbow made possible by this arrangement — almost 180° — allows the bones to be brought almost in parallel to each other.

column2: with the palm facing forward or up
column3: the bones of the upper arm (humerus) and forearm (radius and ulna) are not perfectly aligned. The deviation from a straight line occurs in the direction of the thumb
column4: and is referred to as the ""carrying angle"".

column1: The carrying angle permits the arm to be swung without contacting the hips.  Women on average have smaller shoulders and wider hips than men
column2: which tends to produce a larger carrying angle (i.e.
column3: larger deviation from a straight line than that in men).  There is
column4: however
column5: extensive overlap in the carrying angle between individual men and women
column6: and a sex-bias has not been consistently observed in scientific studies.

column1: The angle is greater in the dominant limb than the non-dominant limb of both sexes
column2: suggesting that natural forces acting on the elbow modify the carrying angle. Developmental
column3: aging and possibly racial influences add further to the variability of this parameter.

column1: The types of disease most commonly seen at the elbow are due to injury.

Two of the most common injuries at the elbow are overuse injuries: tennis elbow and golfer's elbow. Golfer's elbow involves the tendon of the common flexor origin which originates at the medial epicondyle of the humerus (the ""inside"" of the elbow). Tennis elbow is the equivalent injury
column2: but at the common extensor origin (the lateral epicondyle of the humerus).

column1: There are three bones at the elbow joint
column2: and any combination of these bones may be involved in a fracture of the elbow.  Patients who are able to fully extend their arm at the elbow are unlikely to have a fracture (98% certainty) and an X-ray is not required as long as an olecranon fracture is ruled out. Acute fractures may not be easily visible on X-ray.

column1: Elbow dislocations constitute 10% to 25% of all injuries to the elbow. The elbow is one of the most commonly dislocated joints in the body
column2: with an average annual incidence of acute dislocation of 6 per 100
column3: 000 persons. Among injuries to the upper extremity
column4: dislocation of the elbow is second only to a dislocated shoulder.

column1: A full dislocation of the elbow will require expert medical attention to re-align
column2: and recovery can take approximately 6 weeks.

column1: Infection of the elbow joint (septic arthritis) is uncommon.  It may occur spontaneously
column2: but may also occur in relation to surgery or infection elsewhere in the body (for example
column3: endocarditis).

column1: Elbow arthritis is usually seen in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis or after fractures that involve the joint itself. When the damage to the joint is severe
column2: fascial arthroplasty or elbow joint replacement may be considered.

column1: Elbow pain occurs when the tenderness of the tissues in the elbow become inflamed. Frequent exercise of the inflamed elbow will assist with healing.
Elbow pain can occur for a multitude of reasons
column2: including injury
column3: disease
column4: and other conditions. Common conditions include tennis elbow
column5: golfer's elbow
column6: distal radioulnar joint rheumatoid arthritis
column7: and cubital tunnel syndrome.

column1: Tennis elbow is a very common type of overuse injury. It can occur both from chronic repetitive motions of the hand and forearm
column2: and from trauma to the same areas. These repetitions can injure the tendons that connect the extensor supinator muscles (which rotate and extend the forearm) to the olecranon process (also known as ""the elbow""). Pain occurs
column3: often radiating from the lateral forearm. Weakness
column4: numbness
column5: and stiffness are also very common
column6: along with tenderness upon touch.

column1: A non-invasive treatment for pain management is rest. If achieving rest is an issue
column2: a wrist brace can also be worn. This keeps the wrist in flexion
column3: thereby relieving the extensor muscles and allowing rest. Ice
column4: heat
column5: ultrasound
column6: steroid injections
column7: and compression can also help alleviate pain. After the pain has been reduced
column8: exercise therapy is important to prevent injury in the future. Exercises should be low velocity
column9: and weight should increase progressively. Stretching the flexors and extensors is helpful
column10: as are strengthening exercises. Massage can also be useful
column11: focusing on the extensor trigger points.

column1: Golfer's elbow is very similar to tennis elbow
column2: but less common. It is caused by overuse and repetitive motions like a golf swing. It can also be caused by trauma. Wrist flexion and pronation (rotating of the forearm) causes irritation to the tendons near the medial epicondyle of the elbow. It can cause pain
column3: stiffness
column4: loss of sensation
column5: and weakness radiating from the inside of the elbow to the fingers.

column1: Rest is the primary intervention for this injury. Ice
column2: pain medication
column3: steroid injections
column4: strengthening exercises
column5: and avoiding any aggravating activities can also help. Surgery is a last resort
column6: and rarely used. Exercises should focus on strengthening and stretching the forearm
column7: and utilizing proper form when performing movements.

column1: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic disease that affects joints. It is very common in the wrist
column2: and is most common at the radioulnar joint. It results in pain
column3: stiffness
column4: and deformities.

column1: There are many different treatments for rheumatoid arthritis
column2: and there is no one consensus for which methods are best. Most common treatments include wrist splints
column3: surgery
column4: physical and occupational therapy
column5: and antirheumatic medication.

column2: more commonly known as ulnar neuropathy
column3: occurs when the ulnar nerve is irritated and becomes inflamed. This can often happen where the ulnar nerve is most superficial
column4: at the elbow. The ulnar nerve passes over the elbow

column6: repeated stress and pressure at this area

column9: numbness

column1: First line pain management techniques include the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory oral medicines. These help to reduce inflammation
column2: pressure
column3: and irritation of the nerve and around the nerve. Other simple fixes include learning more ergonomically friendly habits that can help prevent nerve impingement and irritation in the future. Protective equipment can also be very helpful. Examples of this include a protective elbow pad
column4: and an arm splint. More serious cases often involve surgery

column1: The now obsolete length unit ell relates closely to the elbow. This becomes especially visible when considering the Germanic origins of both words
column2: Elle (ell
column3: defined as the length of a male forearm from elbow to fingertips) and Ellbogen (elbow). It is unknown when or why the second ""l"" was dropped from English usage of the word. The ell as in the English measure could also be taken to come from the letter L

column5: as an elbow. The ell as a measure was taken as six handbreadths; three to the elbow and three from the elbow to the shoulder. Another measure was the cubit (from cubital). This was taken to be the length of a man's arm from the elbow to the end of the middle finger.

column5: lungs and intestines

column1: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lip|A14.549.336;A01.456.505.631.515|D008046|Lip|"The lips are a horizontal pair of soft appendages attached to the jaws and are the most visible part of the mouth of many animals
column2: including humans. Vertebrate lips are soft
column3: movable and serve to facilitate the ingestion of food (e.g. suckling and gulping) and the articulation of sound and speech. Human lips are also a somatosensory organ
column4: and can be an erogenous zone when used in kissing and other acts of intimacy.

column1: The upper and lower lips are referred to as the labium superius oris and labium inferius oris
column2: respectively.  The juncture where the lips meet the surrounding skin of the mouth area is the vermilion border
column3: and the typically reddish area within the borders is called the vermilion zone.  The vermilion border of the upper lip is known as the Cupid's bow.  The fleshy protuberance located in the center of the upper lip is a tubercle known by various terms including the procheilon (also spelled prochilon)
column4: the ""tuberculum labii superioris""
column5: and the ""labial tubercle"".  The vertical groove extending from the procheilon to the nasal septum is called the philtrum.

column2: with three to five cellular layers
column3: is very thin compared to typical face skin
column4: which has up to 16 layers. With light skin color
column5: the lip skin contains fewer melanocytes (cells which produce melanin pigment
column6: which give skin its color). Because of this
column7: the blood vessels appear through the skin of the lips
column8: which leads to their notable red coloring. With darker skin color this effect is less prominent
column9: as in this case the skin of the lips contains more melanin and thus is visually darker.  The skin of the lip forms the border between the exterior skin of the face
column10: and the interior mucous membrane of the inside of the mouth.

column1: The lip skin is not hairy and does not have sweat glands. Therefore
column2: it does not have the usual protection layer of sweat and body oils which keep the skin smooth
column3: inhibit pathogens
column4: and regulate warmth. For these reasons
column5: the lips dry out faster and become chapped more easily.

column1: The lower lip is formed from the mandibular prominence
column2: a branch of the first pharyngeal arch. The lower lip covers the anterior body of the mandible. It is lowered by the depressor labii inferioris muscle and the orbicularis oris borders it inferiorly.

column1: The upper lip covers the anterior surface of the body of the maxilla. Its upper half is of usual skin color and has a depression at its center
column2: directly under the nasal septum
column3: called the philtrum
column4: which is Latin for ""lower nose""
column5: while its lower half is a markedly different
column6: red-colored skin tone more similar to the color of the inside of the mouth
column7: and the term vermillion refers to the colored portion of either the upper or lower lip.

column1: It is raised by the levator labii superioris and is connected to the lower lip by the thin lining of the lip itself.
Thinning of the vermilion of the upper lip and flattening of the philtrum are two of the facial characteristics of fetal alcohol syndrome
column2: a lifelong disability caused by the mother's consumption of alcohol during pregnancy.

column1: The skin of the lips is stratified squamous epithelium. The mucous membrane is represented by a large area in the sensory cortex
column2: and is therefore highly sensitive. The frenulum labii inferioris is the frenulum of the lower lip. The frenulum labii superioris is the frenulum of the upper lip.

column1: The infraorbital nerve is a branch of the maxillary branch. It supplies not only the upper lip but also much of the skin of the face between the upper lip and the lower eyelid
column2: except for the bridge of the nose.

column1: The mental nerve is a branch of the mandibular branch (via the inferior alveolar nerve).  It supplies the skin and mucous membrane of the lower lip and labial gingiva (gum) anteriorly.
The facial artery is one of the six non-terminal branches of the external carotid artery.
This artery supplies both lips by its superior and inferior labial branches. Each of the two branches bifurcate and anastomose with their companion branch from the other terminal.

The muscles acting on the lips are considered part of the muscles of facial expression.  All muscles of facial expression are derived from the mesoderm of the second pharyngeal arch and are therefore supplied (motor supply) by the nerve of the second pharyngeal arch
column2: the facial nerve (7th cranial nerve). The muscles of facial expression are all specialized members of the panniculus carnosus
column3: which attach to the dermis and so wrinkle or dimple the overlying skin. Functionally
column4: the muscles of facial expression are arranged in groups around the orbits
column5: nose
column6: and mouth.

column1: The muscles acting on the lips:

column2: formerly thought to be a single sphincter or ring of muscle)

column1: Because they have their own muscles and bordering muscles
column2: the lips are easily movable. Lips are used for eating functions
column3: like holding food or to get it in the mouth. In addition
column4: lips serve to close the mouth airtight shut
column5: to hold food and drink inside
column6: and to keep out unwanted objects. Through making a narrow funnel with the lips
column7: the suction of the mouth is increased. This suction is essential for babies to breast feed. Lips can also be used to suck in other contexts
column8: such as sucking on a straw to drink liquids.

column1: The lips serve for creating different sounds—mainly labial
column2: bilabial
column3: and labiodental consonant sounds as well as vowel rounding—and thus are an important part of the speech apparatus.  The lips enable whistling and the performing of wind instruments such as the trumpet
column4: clarinet
column5: flute
column6: and saxophone. People who have hearing loss may unconsciously or consciously lip read to understand speech without needing to perceive the actual sounds
column7: and visual cues from the lips affect the perception of what sounds have been heard
column8: for example the McGurk effect.

column1: The lip has many nerve endings  and reacts as part of the tactile (touch) senses.  Lips are very sensitive to touch
column2: warmth
column3: and cold.  It is therefore an important aid for exploring unknown objects for babies and toddlers.

column1: Because of their high number of nerve endings
column2: the lips are an erogenous zone. The lips therefore play a crucial role in kissing and other acts of intimacy.

column1: A woman's lips are also a visible expression of her fertility. In studies performed on the science of human attraction
column2: psychologists have concluded that a woman's facial and sexual attractiveness is closely linked to the makeup of her hormones during puberty and development.  Contrary to the effects of testosterone on a man's facial structure
column3: the effects of a woman's oestrogen levels serve to maintain a relatively ""childlike"" and youthful facial structure during puberty and during final maturation.  It has been shown that the more oestrogen a woman has
column4: the larger her eyes and the fuller her lips
column5: characteristics which are perceived as more feminine.  Surveys performed by sexual psychologists have also found that universally
column6: men find a woman's full lips to be more sexually attractive than lips that are less so.  A woman's lips are therefore sexually attractive to males because they serve as a biological indicator of a woman's health and fertility.  A woman's lipstick (or collagen lip enhancement) attempts to take advantage of this fact by creating the illusion that a woman has more oestrogen than she actually has and thus that she is more fertile and attractive.

column1: Lip size is linked to sexual attraction in both men and women. Women are attracted to men with masculine lips that are more middle size and not too big or too small; they are to be rugged and sensual. In general
column2: the researchers found that a small nose
column3: big eyes and voluptuous lips are sexually attractive both in men and women. The lips may temporarily swell during sexual arousal due to engorgement with blood.

column1: The lips contribute substantially to facial expressions. The lips visibly express emotions such as a smile or frown
column2: iconically by the curve of the lips forming an up-open or down-open parabola
column3: respectively. Lips can also be made pouty when whining or perky to be provocative.

column1: As an organ of the body
column2: the lip can be a focus of disease or show symptoms of a disease:

column1: One of the most frequent changes of the lips is a blue coloring due to cyanosis; the blood contains less oxygen and thus has a dark red to blue color
column2: which shows through the thin skin.  Cyanosis is the reason why corpses sometimes have blue lips. In cold weather cyanosis can appear
column3: so especially in the winter
column4: blue lips may not be an uncommon sight.

column1: Inflammation of the lips is termed cheilitis. This can be in several forms such as chapped lips (dry
column2: peeling lips)
column3: angular cheilitis (inflammation of the corners of the mouth)
column4: herpes labialis (cold sore
column5: a form of herpes simplex) and actinic cheilitis (chronically sun damaged lips).

column1: Cleft lip is a type of birth defect that can be successfully treated with surgery.

Carcinoma (a malignant cancer that arises from epithelial cells) at the lips is caused predominantly by using tobacco and overexposure of sunlight. Alcohol appears to increase the carcinoma risk associated with tobacco use. It is most often a diffuse and often hyperkeratinised lesion
column2: occasionally has the form of nodules and grows infiltratively
column3: and can also be a combination of the two types. It more often occurs at the lower lip
column4: where it is also much more malign. Lower lip carcinoma is exclusively planocellular carcinoma
column5: whereas at the upper lip
column6: it can also be basocellular carcinoma.

column1: Lips are often viewed as a symbol of sensuality and sexuality. This has many origins; above all
column2: the lips are a very sensitive erogenous and tactile organ. Furthermore
column3: in many cultures of the world
column4: a woman's mouth and lips are veiled because of their representative association with the vulva
column5: and because of their role as a woman's secondary sexual organ.

column2: the lips are also associated with the symbolism associated with the mouth as orifice by which food is taken in.  The lips are also linked symbolically to neonatal psychology (see for example oral stage of the psychology according to Sigmund Freud).

column1: Lip piercing or lip augmentation is sometimes carried out for cosmetic reasons. Products designed for use on the lips include lipstick
column2: lip gloss and lip balm.
the lips are relatively unimportant folds of tissue lying just outside the jaws. However
column3: in mammals
column4: they become much more prominent
column5: being separated from the jaws by a deep cleft  (a notable exception being the naked mole-rat
column6: whose lips close behind the front teeth). They are also more mobile in mammals than in other groups since it is only in this group that they have any attached muscles. In some teleost fish
column7: the lips may be modified to carry sensitive barbels. In birds and turtles
column8: the lips are hard and keratinous
column9: forming a solid beak. Clevosaurids like Clevosaurus are notable for the presence of bone ""lips""; in these species the tooth-like jaw projections common to all sphenodontians form a beak-like edge around the jaws
column10: protecting the teeth within.
