https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_nose|A01.456.505.733;A04.531;A09.531|D009666|Human nose|"The human nose is the first organ of the respiratory system.  It is also the principal organ in the olfactory system.  The shape of the nose is determined by the nasal bones and the nasal cartilages
column2: including the nasal septum
column3: which separates the nostrils and divides the nasal cavity into two.

column1: The nose has an important function in breathing. The nasal mucosa lining the nasal cavity and the paranasal sinuses carries out the necessary conditioning of inhaled air by warming and moistening it. Nasal conchae
column2: shell-like bones in the walls of the cavities
column3: play a major part in this process. Filtering of the air by nasal hair in the nostrils prevents large particles from entering the lungs. Sneezing is a reflex to expel unwanted particles from the nose that irritate the mucosal lining. Sneezing can transmit infections
column4: because aerosols are created in which the droplets can harbour pathogens.

column1: Another major function of the nose is olfaction
column2: the sense of smell. The area of olfactory epithelium
column3: in the upper nasal cavity
column4: contains specialised olfactory cells responsible for this function.

column1: The nose is also involved in the function of speech. Nasal vowels and nasal consonants are produced in the process of nasalisation. The hollow cavities of the paranasal sinuses act as sound chambers that modify and amplify speech and other vocal sounds.
There are several plastic surgery procedures that can be done on the nose
column2: known as rhinoplasties available to correct various structural defects or to change the shape of the nose. Defects may be congenital
column3: or result from nasal disorders or from trauma. These procedures are a type of reconstructive surgery. Elective procedures to change a nose shape are a type of cosmetic surgery.

column1: Several bones and cartilages make up the bony-cartilaginous framework of the nose
column2: and the internal structure. The nose is also made up of types of soft tissue such as skin
column3: epithelia
column4: mucous membrane
column5: muscles
column6: nerves
column7: and blood vessels. In the skin there are sebaceous glands
column8: and in the mucous membrane there are nasal glands. The bones and cartilages provide strong protection for the internal structures of the nose. There are several muscles that are involved in movements of the nose. The arrangement of the cartilages allows flexibility through muscle control to enable airflow to be modified.

column1: The bony structure of the nose is provided by the maxilla
column2: frontal bone
column3: and a number of smaller bones.

column1: The topmost bony part of the nose is formed by the nasal part of the frontal bone
column2: which lies between the brow ridges
column3: and ends in a serrated nasal notch. A left and a right nasal bone join with the nasal part of the frontal bone at either side; and these at the side with the small lacrimal bones and the frontal process of each maxilla. The internal roof of the nasal cavity is composed of the horizontal
column4: perforated cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone through which pass sensory fibres of the olfactory nerve. Below and behind the cribriform plate
column5: sloping down at an angle
column6: is the face of the sphenoid bone.

column1: The wall separating the two cavities of the nose
column2: the nasal septum
column3: is made up of bone inside and cartilage closer to the tip of the nose. The bony part is formed by the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid bone at the top
column4: and the vomer bone below. The floor of the nose is made up of the incisive bone and the horizontal plates of the palatine bones
column5: and this makes up the hard palate of the roof of the mouth. The two horizontal plates join at the midline and form the posterior nasal spine that gives attachment to the musculus uvulae in the uvula.

column1: The two maxilla bones join at the base of the nose at the lower nasal midline between the nostrils
column2: and at the top of the philtrum to form the anterior nasal spine. This thin projection of bone holds the cartilaginous center of the nose. It is also an important cephalometric landmark.

column1: The nasal cartilages are the septal
column2: lateral
column3: major alar
column4: and minor alar cartilages. The major and minor cartilages are also known as the greater and lesser alar cartilages. There is a narrow strip of cartilage called the vomeronasal cartilage that lies between the vomer and the septal cartilage.

column2: extends from the nasal bones in the midline
column3: to the bony part of the septum in the midline
column4: posteriorly. It then passes along the floor of the nasal cavity. The septum is quadrangular–the upper half is attached to the two lateral nasal cartilages
column5: which are fused to the dorsal septum in the midline. The septum is laterally attached
column6: with loose ligaments
column7: to the bony margin of the anterior nasal aperture
column8: while the inferior ends of the lateral cartilages are free (unattached). The three or four minor alar cartilages are adjacent to the lateral cartilages
column9: held in the connective tissue membrane
column10: that connects the lateral cartilages to the frontal process of the maxilla.

column1: The nasal bones in the upper part of the nose are joined by the midline internasal suture. They join with the septal cartilage at a junction known as the rhinion. The rhinion is the midline junction where the nasal bone meets the septal cartilage. From the rhinion to the apex
column2: or tip
column3: the framework is of cartilage.

column1: The major alar cartilages are thin
column2: U-shaped plates of cartilage on each side of the nose that form the lateral and medial walls of the vestibule
column3: known as the medial and lateral crura. The medial crura are attached to the septal cartilage
column4: forming fleshy parts at the front of the nostrils on each side of the septum
column5: called the medial crural footpods. The medial crura meet at the midline below the end of the septum to form the columella and lobule. The lobule contains the tip of the nose and its base contains the nostrils. At the peaks of the folds of the medial crura
column6: they form the alar domes the tip-defining points of the nose
column7: separated by a notch. They then fold outwards
column8: above and to the side of the nostrils forming the lateral crura. The major alar cartilages are freely moveable and can respond to muscles to either open or constrict the nostrils.

column1: There is a reinforcing structure known as the nasal scroll that resists internal collapse from airflow pressure generated by normal breathing. This structure is formed by the junction between the lateral and major cartilages. Their edges interlock by one scrolling upwards and one scrolling inwards.
The muscles of the nose are a subgroup of the facial muscles. They are involved in respiration and facial expression. The muscles of the nose include the procerus
column2: nasalis
column3: depressor septi nasi
column4: levator labii superioris alaeque nasi
column5: and the orbicularis oris of the mouth. As are all of the facial muscles
column6: the muscles of the nose are innervated by the facial nerve and its branches. Although each muscle is independent
column7: the muscles of the nose form a continuous layer with connections between all the components of the muscles and ligaments
column8: in the nasal part of a superficial muscular aponeurotic system (SMAS). The SMAS is continuous from the nasofrontal process to the nasal tip. It divides at level of the nasal valve into superficial and deep layers
column9: each layer having medial and lateral components.

column1: The procerus muscle produces wrinkling over the bridge of the nose
column2: and is active in concentration and frowning. It is a prime target for Botox procedures in the forehead to remove the lines between the eyes.

column1: The nasalis muscle consists of two main parts: a transverse part called the compressor naris
column2: and an alar part termed the dilator naris. The compressor naris muscle compresses the nostrils and may completely close them. The alar part
column3: the dilator naris mainly consists of the dilator naris posterior
column4: and a much smaller dilator naris anterior
column5: and this muscle flares the nostrils. The dilator naris helps to form the upper ridge of the philtrum. The anterior
column6: and the posterior dilator naris
column7: (the alar part of the nasalis muscle)
column8: give support to the nasal valves.

column1: The depressor septi nasi may sometimes be absent or rudimentary. The depressor septi pulls the columella
column2: the septum
column3: and the tip of the nose downwards. At the start of inspiration
column4: this muscle tenses the nasal septum and with the dilator naris widens the nostrils.

column1: The levator labii superioris alaeque nasi divides into a medial and a lateral slip. The medial slip blends into the perichondrium of the major alar cartilage and its overlying skin. The lateral slip blends at the side of the upper lip with the levator labii superioris
column2: and with the orbicularis oris. The lateral slip raises the upper lip and deepens and increases the curve above the nasolabial furrow. The medial slip pulls the lateral crus upwards and modifies the curve of the furrow around the alae
column3: and dilates the nostrils.

column1: The skin of the nose varies in thickness along its length. From the glabella to the bridge (the nasofrontal angle)
column2: the skin is thick
column3: fairly flexible
column4: and mobile. It tapers to the bridge where it is thinnest and least flexible as it is closest to the underlying bone. From the bridge until the tip of the nose the skin is thin. The tip is covered in skin that is as thick as the top section
column5: and has many large sebaceous glands.

column1: The thickness of the skin varies but is still separated from the underlying bones and cartilage by four layers – a superficial fatty layer; a fibromuscular layer continued from the SMAS; a deep fatty layer
column2: and the periosteum.

column1: Other areas of soft tissue are found where there is no support from cartilage; these include an area around the sides of the septum – the paraseptal area – an area around the lateral cartilages
column2: an area at the top of the nostril
column3: and an area in the alae.

column1: The nasal root is the top of the nose that attaches the nose to the forehead. The nasal root is above the bridge and below the glabella
column2: forming an indentation known as the nasion at the frontonasal suture where the frontal bone meets the nasal bones. The nasal dorsum also known as the nasal ridge is the border between the root and the tip of the nose
column3: which in profile can be variously shaped. The ala of the nose (ala nasi
column4: ""wing of the nose""; plural alae) is the lower lateral surface of the external nose
column5: shaped by the alar cartilage and covered in dense connective tissue. The alae flare out to form a rounded eminence around the nostril. Sexual dimorphism is evident in the larger nose of the male. This is due to the increased testosterone that thickens the brow ridge and the bridge of the nose making it wider.

column1: Differences in the symmetry of the nose have been noted in studies. Asymmetry is predominantly seen in wider left-sided nasal and other facial features.
The nasal cavity is the large internal space of the nose
column2: and is in two parts – the nasal vestibule and the nasal cavity proper. The nasal vestibule is the frontmost part of the nasal cavity
column3: enclosed by cartilages.  The vestibule is lined with skin
column4: hair follicles
column5: and a large number of sebaceous glands. A mucous ridge known as the limen nasi separates the vestibule from the rest of the nasal cavity and marks the change from the skin of the vestibule to the respiratory epithelium of the rest of the nasal cavity. This area is also known as a mucocutaneous junction and has a dense microvasculature.

column1: The nasal cavity is divided into two cavities by the nasal septum
column2: and each is accessed by an external nostril. The division into two cavities enables the functioning of the nasal cycle that slows down the conditioning process of the inhaled air.

column1: At the back of the nasal cavity there are two openings
column2: called choanae (also posterior nostrils)
column3: that give entrance to the nasopharynx
column4: and rest of the respiratory tract.

column1: On the outer wall of each cavity are three shell-like bones called conchae
column2: arranged as superior
column3: middle and inferior nasal conchae. Below each concha is a corresponding superior
column4: middle
column5: and inferior nasal meatus
column6: or passage. Sometimes when the superior concha is narrow
column7: a fourth supreme nasal concha is present situated above and sharing the space with the superior concha. The term concha refers to the actual bone; when covered by soft tissue and mucosa
column8: and functioning
column9: a concha is termed a turbinate. Excessive moisture as tears collected in the lacrimal sac travel down the nasolacrimal ducts where they drain into the inferior meatus in the nasal cavity.

column1: Most of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses is lined with respiratory epithelium as nasal mucosa. In the roof of each cavity is an area of specialised olfactory epithelium. This region is about 5 square cm
column2: covering the superior concha
column3: the cribriform plate
column4: and the nasal septum.

column1: The nasal cavity has a nasal valve area that includes an external nasal valve
column2: and an internal nasal valve. The external nasal valve is bounded medially by the columella
column3: laterally by the lower lateral nasal cartilage
column4: and posteriorly by the nasal sill. The internal nasal valve is bounded laterally by the caudal border of the upper lateral cartilage
column5: medially by the dorsal nasal septum
column6: and inferiorly by the anterior border of the inferior turbinate. The internal nasal valve is the narrowest region of the nasal cavity and is the primary site of nasal resistance. The valves regulate the airflow and resistance. Air breathed in is forced to pass through the narrow internal nasal valve
column7: and then expands as it moves into the nasal cavity. The sudden change in the speed and pressure of the airflow creates turbulence that allows optimum contact with the respiratory epithelium for the necessary warming
column8: moisturising
column9: and filtering. The turbulence also allows movement of the air to pass over the olfactory epithelium and transfer odour information. The angle of the valve between the septum and the sidewall needs to be sufficient for unobstructed airflow
column10: and this is normally between 10 and 15 degrees.

column1: The borders of each nasal cavity are a roof
column2: floor
column3: medial wall (the septum)
column4: and lateral wall. The middle part of the roof of the nasal cavity is composed of the horizontal
column5: perforated cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone
column6: through which pass sensory fibres of the olfactory nerve into the cranial cavity.

column1: The mucosa that lines the nasal cavity extends into its chambers
column2: the paranasal sinuses. The nasal cavity and the paranasal sinuses are referred to as the sinonasal tract or sinonasal region
column3: and its anatomy is recognised as being unique and complex. Four paired paranasal sinuses – the frontal sinus
column4: the sphenoid sinus
column5: the ethmoid sinus and the maxillary sinus drain into regions of the nasal cavity.

column1: The sinuses are air-filled extensions of the nasal cavity into the cranial bones. The frontal sinuses are located in the frontal bone; the sphenoidal sinuses in the sphenoid bone; the maxillary sinuses in the maxilla; and the ethmoidal sinuses in the ethmoid bone.

A narrow opening called a sinus ostium from each of the paranasal sinuses allows drainage into the nasal cavity. The maxillary sinus is the largest of the sinuses and drains into the middle meatus. Most of the ostia open into the middle meatus and the anterior ethmoid
column2: that together are termed the ostiomeatal complex. Adults have a high concentration of cilia in the ostia. The cilia in the sinuses beat towards the openings into the nasal cavity. The increased numbers of cilia and the narrowness of the sinus openings allow for an increased time for moisturising
column3: and warming.

column1: The shape of the nose varies widely due to differences in the nasal bone shapes and formation of the bridge of the nose. Anthropometric studies have importantly contributed to craniofacial surgery
column2: and the nasal index is a recognised anthropometric index used in nasal surgery.

column1: Paul Topinard developed the nasal index as a method of classifying ethnic groups. The index is based on the ratio of the breadth of the nose to its height. The nasal dimensions are also used to classify nasal morphology into five types: Hyperleptorrhine is a very long
column2: narrow nose with a nasal index of 40 to 55. Leptorrhine describes a long
column3: narrow nose with an index of 55–70. Mesorrhine is a medium nose with an index of 70–85. Platyrrhine is a short
column4: broad nose with an index of 85–99·9. The fifth type is the hyperplatyrrhine having an index of more than 100. Variations in nose size between ethnicities may be attributed to differing evolutionary adaptations to local temperatures and humidity. Other factors such as sexual selection may also account for ethnic differences in nose shape.

column1: Some deformities of the nose are named
column2: such as the pug nose and the saddle nose. The pug nose is characterised by excess tissue from the apex that is out of proportion to the rest of the nose. A low and underdeveloped nasal bridge may also be evident. A saddle nose deformity involving the collapse of the bridge of the nose is mostly associated with trauma to the nose but can be caused by other conditions including leprosy.
a condition associated with premature aging
column3: causes a ""bird-like"" appearance due to pinching of the nose.

column1: Down syndrome commonly presents a small nose with a flattened nasal bridge. This can be due to the absence of one or both  nasal bones
column2: shortened nasal bones
column3: or nasal bones that have not fused in the midline.

column1: The blood supply to the nose is provided by branches of the ophthalmic
column2: maxillary
column3: and facial arteries – branches of the carotid arteries. Branches of these arteries anastomose to form plexuses in and under the nasal mucosa. In the septal region Kiesselbach's plexus is a common site of nosebleeds.

column1: Branches of the ophthalmic artery – the anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries supply the roof
column2: upper bony septum
column3: and ethmoidal and frontal sinuses. The anterior ethmoidal artery also helps to supply the lower septal cartilage. Another branch is the dorsal nasal artery a terminal branch that supplies the skin of the alae and dorsum.

column1: Branches of the maxillary artery include the greater palatine artery; the sphenopalatine artery and its  branches – the posterior lateral nasal arteries and posterior septal nasal branches; the pharyngeal branch; and the infraorbital artery and its branches – the superior anterior and posterior alveolar arteries.

The sphenopalatine artery and the ethmoid arteries supply the outer walls of the nasal cavity. There is additional supply from a branch of the facial artery – the superior labial artery. The sphenopalantine artery is the artery primarily responsible for supplying the nasal mucosa.

The skin of the alae is supplied by the septal and lateral nasal branches of the facial artery. The skin of the outer parts of the alae and the dorsum of the nose are supplied by the dorsal nasal artery a branch of the ophthalmic artery
column2: and the infraorbital branch of the maxillary arteries.

column1: Veins of the nose include the angular vein that drains the side of the nose
column2: receiving lateral nasal veins from the alae. The angular vein joins with the superior labial vein. Some small veins from the dorsum of the nose drain to the nasal arch of the frontal vein at the root of the nose.

column1: In the posterior region of the cavity
column2: specifically in the posterior part of the inferior meatus is a venous plexus known as Woodruff's plexus. This plexus is made up of large thin-walled veins with little soft tissue such as muscle or fiber. The mucosa of the plexus is thin with very few structures.

column1: From different areas of the nose superficial lymphatic vessels run with the veins
column2: and deep lymphatic vessels travel with the arteries.

column1: Lymph drains from the anterior half of the nasal cavity
column2: including both the medial and lateral walls
column3: to join that of the external nasal skin to drain into the

column1: submandibular lymph nodes. The rest of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses all drain to the upper deep cervical lymph nodes
column2: either directly or through the retropharyngeal lymph nodes. The back of the nasal floor probably drains to the parotid lymph nodes.

column1: The nerve supply to the nose and paranasal sinuses comes from two branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V): the ophthalmic nerve (CN V1)
column2: the maxillary nerve (CN V2)
column3: and branches from these.

column2: the nasal mucosa is divided in terms of nerve supply into a back lower part (posteroinferior)
column3: and a frontal upper part (anterosuperior). The posterior part is supplied by a branch of the maxillary nerve – the nasopalatine nerve
column4: which reaches the septum. Lateral nasal branches of the greater palatine nerve supply the lateral wall.

column1: The frontal upper part is supplied from a branch of the ophthalmic nerve – the  nasociliary nerve
column2: and its branches – the anterior and posterior ethmoidal nerves.

column1: Most of the external nose – the dorsum
column2: and the apex are supplied by the infratrochlear nerve
column3: (a branch of the nasociliary nerve). The external branch of the anterior ethmoidal nerve also supplies areas of skin between the root and the alae.

column1: The alae of the nose are supplied by nasal branches of CN V2
column2: the infraorbital nerve
column3: and internal nasal branches of infraorbital nerve that supply the septum and the vestibule.

column1: The maxillary sinus is supplied by superior alveolar nerves from the maxillary and infraorbital nerves. The frontal sinus is supplied by branches of the supraorbital nerve. The ethmoid sinuses are supplied by anterior and posterior ethmoid branches of the nasociliary nerve. The sphenoid sinus is supplied by the posterior ethmoidal nerves.

The muscles of the nose are supplied by branches of the facial nerve. The nasalis muscle is supplied by the buccal branches. It may also be supplied by one of the zygomatic branches. The procerus is supplied by temporal branches of the facial nerve and lower zygomatic branches; a supply from the buccal branch has also been described. The depressor septi is innervated by the buccal branch
column2: and sometimes by the zygomatic branch
column3: of the facial nerve. The levator labii superioris alaeque nasi is innervated by zygomatic and superior buccal branches of the facial nerve.

column1: The sense of smell is transmitted by the olfactory nerves. Olfactory nerves are bundles of very small unmyelinated axons that are derived from olfactory receptor neurons in the olfactory mucosa. The axons are in varying stages of maturity
column2: reflecting the constant turnover of neurons in the olfactory epithelium. A plexiform network is formed in the lamina propria
column3: by the bundles of axons that are surrounded by olfactory ensheathing cells. In as many as twenty branches
column4: the bundled axons cross the cribriform plate and enter the overlying olfactory bulb ending as glomeruli. Each branch is enclosed by an outer dura mater that becomes continuous with the nasal periosteum.

column1: The nasal mucosa in the nasal cavity is also supplied by the autonomic nervous system. Postganglionic nerve fibers from the deep petrosal nerve join  with preganglionic nerve fibers from the greater petrosal nerve to form the nerve of the pterygoid canal.  Sympathetic postganglionic fibers are distributed to the blood vessels of the nose.  Postganglionic parasympathetic fibres derived from the pterygopalatine ganglion provide the secretomotor supply to the nasal mucous glands
column2: and are distributed via branches of the maxillary nerves.

column1: In the early development of the embryo
column2: neural crest cells migrate to form the mesenchymal tissue as ectomesenchyme of the pharyngeal arches. By the end of the fourth week
column3: the first pair of pharyngeal arches form five facial prominences or processes - an unpaired frontonasal process
column4: paired mandibular processes and paired maxillary processes. The nose is largely formed by the fusion of these five facial prominences. The frontonasal process gives rise to the bridge of the nose. The medial nasal processes provide the crest and the tip of the nose
column5: and the lateral nasal processes form the alae or sides of the nose. The frontonasal process is a proliferation of mesenchyme in front of the brain vesicles
column6: and makes up the upper border of the stomadeum.

column2: the maxillary processes increase in size and at the same time the ectoderm of the frontonasal process becomes thickened at its sides and also increases in size
column3: forming the nasal placodes. The nasal placodes are also known as the olfactory placodes. This development is induced by the ventral part of the forebrain. In the sixth week
column4: the ectoderm in each nasal placode invaginates to form an indented oval-shaped pit
column5: which forms a surrounding  raised ridge of tissue. Each nasal pit forms a division between the ridges
column6: into a lateral nasal process on the outer edge
column7: and a medial nasal process on the inner edge.

column2: the nasal pits deepen as they penetrate into the underlying mesenchyme. At this time
column3: the medial nasal processes migrate towards each other and fuse forming the primordium of the bridge of the nose and the septum. The migration is helped by the increased growth of the maxillary prominences medially
column4: which compresses the medial nasal processes towards the midline. Their merging takes place at the surface
column5: and also at a deeper level. The merge forms the intermaxillary segment
column6: and this is continuous with the rostral part of the nasal septum. The tips of the maxillary processes also grow and fuse with the intermaxillary process. The intermaxillary process gives rise to the philtrum of the upper lip.

column1: At the end of the sixth week
column2: the nasal pits have deepened further and they fuse to make a large ectodermal nasal sac. This sac will be above and to the back of the intermaxillary process. Leading into the seventh week
column3: the nasal sac floor and posterior wall grow to form a thickened plate-like ectodermal structure called the nasal fin. The nasal fin separates the sac from the oral cavity. Within the fin
column4: vacuoles develop that fuse with the nasal sac. This enlarges the nasal sac and at the same time thins the fin to a membrane - the oronasal membrane that separates the nasal pits from the oral cavity. During the seventh week the oronasal membrane ruptures and disintegrates to form an opening - the single primitive choana. The intermaxillary segment extends posteriorly to form the primary palate
column5: which makes up the floor of the nasal cavity. During the eighth and ninth weeks
column6: a pair of thin extensions form from the medial walls of the maxillary process. These extensions are called the palatine shelves that form the secondary palate. The secondary palate will endochondrally ossify to form the hard palate - the end-stage floor of the nasal cavity. During this time
column7: ectoderm and mesoderm of the frontonasal process produce the midline septum. The septum grows down from the roof of the nasal cavity and fuses with the developing palates along the midline. The septum divides the nasal cavity into two nasal passages opening into the pharynx through the definitive choanae.

column2: the cells differentiate into muscle
column3: cartilage
column4: and bone. Problems at this stage of development can cause birth defects such as choanal atresia (absent or closed passage)
column5: facial clefts and nasal dysplasia (faulty or incomplete development) or extremely rarely polyrrhinia the formation of a duplicate nose.

column1: Normal development is critical because the newborn infant breathes through the nose for the first six weeks
column2: and any nasal blockage will need emergency treatment to clear.

column1: The four pairs of paranasal sinuses - the maxillary
column2: ethmoid
column3: sphenoid
column4: and frontal
column5: develop from the nasal cavity as invaginations extending into their named bones. Two pairs of sinuses form during prenatal development and two pairs form after birth. The maxillary sinuses are the first to appear during the fetal third month. They slowly expand within the maxillary bones and continue to expand throughout childhood. The maxillary sinuses form as invaginations from the nasal sac. The ethmoid sinuses appear in the fetal fifth month as invaginations of the middle meatus. The ethmoid sinuses do not grow into the ethmoid bone and do not completely develop until puberty.

column1: The sphenoid sinuses are extensions of the ethmoid sinuses into the sphenoid bones. They begin to develop around two years of age
column2: and continue to enlarge during childhood.

column1: The frontal sinuses only develop in the fifth or sixth year of childhood
column2: and continue expanding throughout adolescence. Each frontal sinus is made up of two independent spaces that develop from two different sources; one from the expansion of ethmoid sinuses into frontal bone
column3: and the other develops from invagination. They never coalesce so drain independently.

column1: The nose is the first organ of the upper respiratory tract in the respiratory system. Its main respiratory function is the supply and conditioning
column2: by warming
column3: moisturising and filtering of particulates of inhaled air. Nasal hair in the nostrils traps large particles preventing their entry into the lungs.

column1: The three positioned nasal conchae in each cavity provide four grooves as air passages
column2: along which the air is circulated and moved to the nasopharynx. The internal structures and cavities
column3: including the conchae and paranasal sinuses form an integrated system for the conditioning of the air breathed in through the nose. This functioning also includes the major role of the nasal mucosa
column4: and the resulting conditioning of the air before it reaches the lungs is important in maintaining the internal environment and proper functioning of the lungs. The turbulence created by the conchae and meatuses optimises the warming
column5: moistening
column6: and filtering of the mucosa. A major protective role is thereby provided by these structures of the upper respiratory tract
column7: in the passage of air to the more delicate structures of the lower respiratory tract.

column1: Sneezing is an important protective reflex action initiated by irritation of the nasal mucosa to expel unwanted particles through the mouth and nose. Photic sneezing is a reflex brought on by different stimuli such as bright lights. The nose is also able to provide sense information as to the temperature of the air being breathed.
Variations in shape of the nose have been hypothesised to possibly be adaptive to regional differences in temperature and humidity
column2: though they may also have been driven by other factors such as sexual selection.

column1: The nose also plays the major part in the olfactory system. It contains an area of specialised cells
column2: olfactory receptor neurons responsible for the sense of smell (olfaction). Olfactory mucosa in the upper nasal cavity
column3: contains a type of nasal gland called olfactory glands or Bowman's glands
column4: which help in olfaction. The nasal conchae also help in olfaction function
column5: by directing air-flow to the olfactory region.

column1: Speech is produced with pressure from the lungs. This can be modified using airflow through the nose in a process called nasalisation. This involves the lowering of the soft palate to produce nasal vowels and consonants by allowing air to escape from both the nose and the mouth. Nasal airflow is also used to produce a variety of click consonants called nasal clicks. The large
column2: hollow cavities of the paranasal sinuses act as resonating chambers that modify
column3: and amplify speech and other vocal vibrations passing through them.

column1: One of the most common medical conditions involving the nose is a nosebleed (epistaxis). Most nosebleeds occur in Kiesselbach's plexus
column2: a vascular plexus in the lower front part of the septum involving the convergence of four arteries. A smaller proportion of nosebleeds that tend to be nontraumatic occur in Woodruff's plexus. Woodruff's plexus is a venous plexus of large thin-walled veins lying in the posterior part of the inferior meatus.

column1: Another common condition is nasal congestion
column2: usually a symptom of infection
column3: particularly sinusitis
column4: or other inflammation of the nasal lining called rhinitis
column5: including allergic rhinitis and nonallergic rhinitis. Chronic nasal obstruction resulting in breathing through the mouth can greatly impair or prevent the nostrils from flaring. One of the causes of snoring is nasal obstruction
column6: and anti-snoring devices such as a nasal strip help to flare the nostrils and keep the airway open. Nasal flaring
column7: is usually seen in children when breathing is difficult. Most conditions of nasal congestion also cause a loss of the sense of smell (anosmia). This may also occur in other conditions
column8: for example following trauma
column9: in Kallmann syndrome or Parkinson's disease. A blocked sinus ostium
column10: an opening from a paranasal sinus
column11: will cause fluid to accumulate in the sinus.

column2: the nose is a common site of foreign bodies. The nose is one of the exposed areas that is susceptible to frostbite.

column1: Because of the special nature of the blood supply to the human nose and surrounding area
column2: it is possible for retrograde infections from the nasal area to spread to the brain. For this reason
column3: the area from the corners of the mouth to the bridge of the nose
column4: including the nose and maxilla
column5: is known as the danger triangle of the face.

column1: Infections or other conditions that may result in destruction of
column2: or damage to a part of the nose include rhinophyma
column3: skin cancers particularly basal-cell carcinoma
column4: paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer
column5: granulomatosis with polyangiitis
column6: syphilis
column7: leprosy
column8: recreational use of cocaine
column9: chromium and other toxins. The nose may be stimulated to grow in acromegaly
column10: a condition caused by an excess of growth hormone.

column1: A common anatomic variant is an air-filled cavity within a concha known as a concha bullosa. In rare cases a polyp can form inside a bullosa. Usually a concha bullosa is small and without symptoms but when large can cause obstruction to sinus drainage.
Some drugs can be nasally administered
column2: including drug delivery to the brain
column3: and these include nasal sprays and topical treatments. The septal cartilage can be destroyed through the repeated inhalation of recreational drugs such as cocaine. This
column4: in turn
column5: can lead to more widespread collapse of the nasal skeleton.

column1: Sneezing can transmit infections carried in the expelled droplets. This route is called either airborne transmission or aerosol transmission.
Badly positioned alar cartilages lack proper support
column2: and can affect the function of the external nasal valve. This can cause breathing problems particularly during deep inhalation. The surgical procedure to correct breathing problems due to disorders in the nasal structures is called a rhinoplasty
column3: and this is also the procedure used for a cosmetic surgery when it is commonly called a ""nose job"". For surgical procedures of rhinoplasty
column4: the nose is mapped out into a number of subunits and segments. This uses nine aesthetic nasal subunits and six aesthetic nasal segments. A septoplasty is the specific surgery to correct a nasal septum deviation.

column1: A broken nose can result from trauma. Minor fractures may heal on their own. Surgery known as reduction may be carried out on more severe breaks that cause dislocation.
Several nasal procedures of the nose and paranasal sinuses can be carried out using minimally-invasive nasal endoscopy. These procedures aim to restore sinus ventilation
column2: mucociliary clearance
column3: and maintain the health of the sinus mucosa.

column1: Some non-nasal surgeries can also be carried out through the use of an endoscope that is entered through the nose. These endoscopic endonasal surgeries are used to remove tumours from the front of the base of the skull.
Swollen conchae can cause obstruction and nasal congestion
column2: and may be treated surgically by a turbinectomy.

column1: Some people choose to have cosmetic surgery (called a rhinoplasty) to change the appearance of their nose. Nose piercings
column2: such as in the nostril
column3: septum
column4: or bridge
column5: are also common. In certain Asian countries such as China
column6: Japan
column7: South Korea
column8: Malaysia
column9: Thailand and Bangladesh
column10: rhinoplasties are commonly carried out to create a more developed nose bridge or a ""high nose"". Similarly
column11: ""DIY nose lifts"" in the form of re-usable cosmetic items have become popular and are sold in many Asian countries such as China
column12: Japan
column13: South Korea
column15: Sri Lanka and Thailand. A high-bridged nose has been a common beauty ideal in many Asian cultures dating back to the beauty ideals of ancient China and India.

column2: nose pressing (""hongi"") is a traditional greeting originating among the Māori people. However it is now generally confined to certain traditional celebrations.

column1: The Hanazuka monument enshrines the mutilated noses of at least 38
column2: 000 Koreans killed during the Japanese invasions of Korea from 1592 to 1598.
mildly taboo habit. Medical risks include the spread of infections
column3: nosebleeds and
column4: rarely
column5: perforation of the nasal septum. When it becomes compulsive it is termed rhinotillexomania. The wiping of the nose with the hand
column6: commonly referred to as the ""allergic salute""
column7: is also mildly taboo and can result in the spreading of infections as well. Habitual as well as fast or rough nose wiping may also result in a crease (known as a transverse nasal crease or groove) running across the nose
column8: and can lead to permanent physical deformity observable in childhood and adulthood.

column1: Nose fetishism (or nasophilia) is the sexual partialism for the nose.
Clive Finlayson of the Gibraltar Museum said the large Neanderthal noses were an adaptation to the cold
column2: Todd C. Rae of the American Museum of Natural History said primate and arctic animal studies have shown sinus size reduction in areas of extreme cold rather than enlargement in accordance with Allen's rule. Therefore
column3: Todd C. Rae concludes that the design of the large and prognathic Neanderthal nose was evolved for the hotter climate of the Middle East and Africa and remained unchanged when they entered Europe.

column1: Miquel Hernández of the Department of Animal Biology at the University of Barcelona said the ""high and narrow nose of Eskimos and Neanderthals"" is an ""adaptation to a cold and dry environment""
column2: since it contributes to warming and moisturizing the air and the ""recovery of heat and moisture from expired air"".
a nose crippled by excessive resection of the inferior and/or middle turbinates of the nose
an Ayurvedic technique of nasal cleansing
the Scottish Gaelic word for nose and the name of some hills in the Scottish Highlands

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navel|A01.923.047.849|D014472|Navel|"The navel (clinically known as the umbilicus; pl.: umbilici or umbilicuses; commonly known as the belly button or tummy button) is a protruding
column2: flat
column3: or hollowed area on the abdomen at the attachment site of the umbilical cord. All placental mammals have a navel
column4: although it is generally more conspicuous in humans.

column1: The umbilicus is used to visually separate the abdomen into quadrants.
The umbilicus is a prominent scar on the abdomen
column2: with its position being relatively consistent among humans. The skin around the waist at the level of the umbilicus is supplied by the tenth thoracic spinal nerve (T10 dermatome). The umbilicus itself typically lies at a vertical level corresponding to the junction between the L3 and L4 vertebrae
column3: with a normal variation among people between the L3 and L5 vertebrae.

column1: Parts of the adult navel include the ""umbilical cord remnant"" or ""umbilical tip""
column2: which is the often protruding scar left by the detachment of the umbilical cord. This is located in the center of the navel
column3: sometimes described as the belly button. Around the cord remnant is the ""umbilical collar""
column4: formed by the dense fibrous umbilical ring. Surrounding the umbilical collar is the periumbilical skin. Directly behind the navel is a thick fibrous cord formed from the umbilical cord
column5: called the urachus
column6: which originates from the bladder.

column1: The belly button is unique to each individual due to it being a scar
column2: and various general forms have been classified by medical practitioners.

column1: Outie: A navel consisting of the umbilical tip protruding past the periumbilical skin is an outie. Essentially any navel which is not concave.
Swirly/spiral: A rare form in which the umbilical cord scar forms a swirl shape.
Split: The protruding umbilical cord scar extends outwards
column2: but is cleft in two by a fissure which extends part or all the way through the umbilical cord scar. This form is similar in appearance to a coffee bean.

column1: Protrusion: The umbilical cord remnant is completely divulged
column2: exposing the full umbilical scar.

column1: Circlet: Although the entirety of the umbilical cord remnant sits out with the umbilical collar
column2: the centre of the knot is inset by a deep fissure. Unlike a split outie
column3: in this form the fissure is contained centrally and does not extend past the umbilical cord remnant in any direction
column4: much akin to a 'donut' shape.

column1: Innie: A navel in which the umbilical tip does not protrude past the periumbilical skin. Any navel which is concave.
Round: Round navels are completely circular with no hooding.
Vertical: Some navels present in the form of a more elongate hollow parallel with the linea alba.
Oval: This form consists of three variants; superior hooding
column2: inferior hooding
column3: no hooding.

column2: the scar is in the shape of a T
column3: and may have superior hooding to various extent.

column1: Horizontal: The scar is the least visible
column2: as the natural lines of the tendinous intersection fold over the scar.

column1: Distorted: Any navel which does not fit well into any of the other categories.
Outies are sometimes mistaken for umbilical hernias; however
column2: they are a completely different shape with no health concern
column3: unlike an umbilical hernia. The navel (specifically abdominal wall) would be considered an umbilical hernia if the protrusion were 5 centimeters or more. The diameter of an umbilical hernia is usually 1/2-inch or more. Navels that are concave are nicknamed ""innies"". While the shape of the human navel may be affected by long term changes to diet and exercise
column4: unexpected change in shape may be the result of ascites.

column1: In addition to change in shape being a possible side effect from ascites and umbilical hernias
column2: the navel can be involved in umbilical sinus or fistula
column3: which in rare cases can lead to menstrual or fecal discharge from the navel. Menstrual discharge from the umbilicus is a rare disorder associated with umbilical endometriosis.

column2: an inflammatory condition of the umbilicus in the newborn
column3: usually caused by a bacterial infection.

column1: Omphalophobia is the fear of belly buttons. People suffering from omphalophobia are terrified of belly buttons—their own or
column2: in some cases
column3: those of others. They do not like touching their belly buttons (or even other people touching it). Sometimes just seeing a belly button is enough to make them feel disgusted or terrified.

column2: the navel is a recommended site of incision for various surgeries
column3: including transgastric appendicectomy
column4: gall bladder surgery
column5: and the umbilicoplasty procedure itself.

column2: society and culture ==

column1: The public exposure of the male and female midriff and bare navel was considered taboo at times in the past in Western cultures
column2: being considered immodest or indecent. Female navel exposure was banned in some jurisdictions
column3: but community perceptions have changed to this now being acceptable. The crop top is a shirt that often exposes the belly button and has become more common among young people. Exposure of the male navel has rarely been stigmatised and has become particularly popular in recent years
column4: due to the strong resurgence of the male crop top and male navel piercing. The navel and midriff are often also displayed in bikinis
column5: or when low-rise pants are worn.

column1: While the West was relatively resistant to navel-baring clothing until the 1980s
column2: it has long been a fashion with Indian women
column3: often displayed with saris or lehengas.

column1: The Japanese have long had a special regard for the navel. During the early Jōmon period in northern Japan
column2: three small balls indicating the breasts and navel were pasted onto flat clay objects to represent the female body. The navel was exaggerated in size
column3: informed by the belief that the navel symbolized the center where life began.

column2: belly dancing is a popular art form that consists of dance movements focused on the torso and navel.

column1: Buddhism and Hinduism refer to the chakra of the navel as the manipura. In qigong
column2: the navel is seen as the main energy centre
column3: or dantian. In Hinduism
column4: the Kundalini energy is sometimes described as being located at the navel.

column2: the head is at the top of the human body. It supports the face and is maintained by the skull
column3: which itself encloses the brain.

column1: The human head consists of a fleshy outer portion
column2: which surrounds the bony skull. The brain is enclosed within the skull.  There are 22 bones in the human head. The head rests on the neck
column3: and the seven cervical vertebrae support it. The human head typically weighs between 2.3 and 5 kilograms (5.1 and 11.0 lb) Over 98% of humans fit into this range. There have been odd incidences where human beings have abnormally small or large heads. The Zika virus was responsible for underdeveloped heads in the early 2000s.

column1: The face is the anterior part of the head
column2: containing the eyes
column3: nose
column4: and mouth. On either side of the mouth
column5: the cheeks provide a fleshy border to the oral cavity. The ears sit to either side of the head.

column1: The head receives blood supply through the internal and external carotid arteries. These supply the area outside of the skull (external carotid artery) and inside of the skull (internal carotid artery). The area inside the skull also receives blood supply from the vertebral arteries
column2: which travel up through the cervical vertebrae.

column1: The twelve pairs of cranial nerves provide the majority of nervous control to the head. The sensation to the face is provided by the branches of the trigeminal nerve
column2: the fifth cranial nerve. Sensation to other portions of the head is provided by the cervical nerves.

column1: Modern texts are in agreement about which areas of the skin are served by which nerves
column2: but there are minor variations in some of the details. The borders designated by diagrams in the 1918 edition of Gray's Anatomy are similar but not identical to those generally accepted today.

column1: The cutaneous innervation of the head is as follows:
Dorsal rami of cervical nerves (blue) and others are in picture which show following in upper column
The head contains sensory organs: two eyes
column2: two ears
column3: a nose and tongue inside of the mouth. It also houses the brain. Together
column4: these organs function as a processing center for the body by relaying sensory information to the brain. Humans can process information faster by having this central nerve cluster.

column2: the front of the head (the face) is the main distinguishing feature between different people due to its easily discernible features
column3: such as eye and hair colors
column4: shapes of the sensory organs
column5: and the wrinkles. Humans easily differentiate between faces because of the brain's predisposition toward facial recognition. When observing a relatively unfamiliar species
column6: all faces seem nearly identical. Human infants are biologically programmed to recognize subtle differences in anthropomorphic facial features.

column1: People who have greater than average intelligence are sometimes depicted in cartoons as having bigger heads as a way of notionally indicating that they have a ""larger head"". Additionally
column2: in science fiction
column3: an extraterrestrial having a big head is often symbolic of high intelligence. Despite this depiction
column4: advances in neurobiology have shown that the functional diversity of the brain means that a difference in overall brain size is only slightly to moderately correlated to differences in overall intelligence between two humans.

column1: The head is a source for many metaphors and metonymies in human language
column2: including referring to things typically near the human head ( ""the head of the bed"")
column3: things physically similar to the way a head is arranged spatially to a body (""the head of the table"")
column4: metaphorically (""the head of the class"")
column5: and things that represent some characteristics associated with the head
column6: such as intelligence (""there are a lot of good heads in this company"").

column1: Ancient Greeks had a method for evaluating sexual attractiveness based on the Golden ratio
column2: part of which included measurements of the head.

column1: Headhunting is the practice of taking and preserving a person's head after killing the person. Headhunting has been practiced across the Americas
column2: Europe
column3: Asia
column4: and Oceania for millennia.

column2: origin
column3: religious/spiritual beliefs
column4: social grouping
column5: team affiliation
column6: occupation
column7: or fashion choices.

column2: covering the head is seen as a sign of respect. Often
column3: some or all of the head must be covered and veiled when entering holy places or places of prayer. For many centuries
column4: women in Europe
column5: the Middle East
column6: and South Asia have covered their head hair as a sign of modesty. This trend has changed drastically in Europe in the 20th century
column7: although is still observed in other parts of the world. In addition
column8: a number of religions require men to wear specific head clothing—such as the Islamic taqiyah
column9: Jewish yarmulke
column10: or the Sikh turban. The same goes for women with the Muslim hijab or Christian nun's habit.

column1: A hat is a head covering that can serve a variety of purposes. Hats may be worn as part of a uniform or used as a protective device
column2: such as a hard hat
column3: a covering for warmth
column4: or a fashion accessory. Hats can also be indicative of social status in some areas of the world.

column1: While numerous charts detailing head sizes in infants and children exist
column2: most do not measure average head circumference past the age of 21. Reference charts for adult head circumference also generally feature homogeneous samples and fail to take height and weight into account.

column1: One study in the United States estimated the average human head circumference to be 57 centimetres (22+1⁄2 in) in males and 55 centimetres (21+3⁄4 in) in females. A British study by Newcastle University showed an average size of 57.2 cm for males and 55.2 cm for females with average size varying proportionally with height
Macrocephaly can be an indicator of increased risk for some types of cancer in individuals who carry the genetic mutation that causes Cowden syndrome. For adults
column2: this refers to head sizes greater than 58 centimeters in men or greater than 57 centimeters in women.

column1: Some values in the table below may not be correct. In particular
column2: a random biocular breadth measurement showed a value of 101.6 mm for an average adult male. The first percentile value below is 110 mm for an adult male.  Another user has also indicate around 100 mm being an average value for biocular breadth. Therefore
column3: the biocular breadth values appear to be increased by around 22 mm.

column1: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eyebrow|A17.360.296;A01.456.505.420.338|D005138|Eyebrow|"An eyebrow is an area of short hairs above each eye that follows the shape of the lower margin of the brow ridges of some mammals. In humans
column2: eyebrows serve two main functions: first
column3: communication through facial expression
column4: and second
column5: prevention of sweat
column6: water
column7: and other debris from falling down into the eye socket. It is common for people to modify their eyebrows by means of hair removal and makeup.

column1: A number of theories have been proposed to explain the function of the eyebrow in humans. One approach suggests its main function is to prevent moisture (mostly sweat and rain) from flowing into the eye. Another theory holds that clearly visible eyebrows provided safety from predators when early hominid groups started sleeping on the ground.

column2: however
column3: suggests eyebrows in humans developed as a means of communication and that this is their primary function. Humans developed a smooth forehead with visible
column4: hairy eyebrows capable of a wide range of movement. Such eyebrows can express a wide range of subtle emotions – including recognition and sympathy.

column1: Fashion in eyebrow shape has changed throughout the ages and eyebrows have always featured heavily in female fashion
column2: often as part of cultural demands made on women about body hair.

column1: Cosmetic methods over the centuries have been developed to alter the appearance of eyebrows by adding or removing hair
column2: changing the color
column3: or changing the position to meet the aesthetic ideal of the time
column4: for example
column5: by tinting the eyebrow with permanent dye
column6: similar to hair colour
column7: often in order to darken them.

column1: Cosmetics tools such as eyebrow brushes
column2: shaders
column3: and pencils are often used to define the eyebrow or make it appear fuller. These can create an outline for the brows or mimic hairs where there are sparse areas. Brow gels are also used in creating a thicker brow; they allow for the hairs to be more textured
column4: which gives the appearance of thicker
column5: fuller brows. Lastly
column6: brow powders or even eyeshadows are used for those who want a fuller and more natural look
column7: by placing the brow powder or eyeshadow (closest to the natural hair colour) in areas where there is less hair.

column1: Several options exist for removing hair to achieve a thinner or smaller eyebrow
column2: or to ""correct"" a unibrow
column3: including manual and electronic tweezing
column4: waxing
column5: and threading. The most common method is to use tweezers to thin out and shape the eyebrow. Waxing is becoming more popular. Lastly
column6: there is threading eyebrows
column7: where a cotton thread is rolled over hair to pull it out. Small scissors are sometimes used to trim the eyebrows
column8: either with another method of hair removal or alone. All of these methods can be painful for seconds or minutes due to the sensitivity of the area around the eye but
column9: often
column10: this pain decreases over time as the individual becomes used to it. In time
column11: hair that has been plucked will stop growing back. Some people wax or shave off their eyebrows and leave them bare
column12: stencil or draw them in with eye liner or tattoo them on. In Western societies
column13: it has become more common for men to pluck part of their eyebrows.

column2: eyebrows can be cloned in an eyebrow transplant. Individual strands of the eyebrow are created to mimic a natural-looking eyebrow of the desired shape. The process of eyebrow transplant is quite similar to the process of hair transplant. In this process as well
column3: follicles from an active area are transferred to the area where there are no hairs. Follicles are mostly taken from the back of the head because it is the best harvesting site when it comes to hairs. The follicles are then injected into the skin.

column1: The healing process after an eyebrow transplant is similar to the process of tattoo. In this process
column2: patients may experience light bruising and crusting of the skin. People who have genetically thin eyebrows or who have over-tweezed are considered ideal for the transplant.

column1: An eyebrow lift is a cosmetic surgery to raise the eyebrow
column2: usually to create a more feminine or youthful appearance. It is not a new phenomenon
column3: with the earliest description of brow lifting published in medical literature in 1919 by French surgeon Raymond Passot. Brows can be affected during a face lift or an eye lift. In the 1970s
column4: doctors started injecting patients' eyebrows with botox or similar toxins to paralyse the muscles temporarily
column5: causing the brow to raise.

column1: Japanese women and men from the 8th century practiced hikimayu: shaving or plucking the eyebrow hair and painting smudge-like ones higher on the forehead or pencilling in thin ones in a different place. This practice is comparable to that in the Elizabethan era when high-status women would remove eyebrows altogether. Thin eyebrows
column2: achieved by rigorous plucking
column3: were again fashionable in the 1920s and 1930s.

column2: tattooing became popular as a way to achieve and maintain an eyebrow shape
column3: using a coil machine
column4: rotary machine or a manual tool containing a row of needles. This process
column5: also called cosmetic tattooing or microblading involves an eyebrow artist implanting pigments in small
column6: precise cuts that mimic the look of hair. Shaving lines in eyebrows is another cosmetic alteration
column7: popular among some younger people in the 1990s and 2000s.

column2: a body piercing placed below the eyebrow
a body piercing done through the eyebrow
surgical procedure to change the look of one's eyebrows

column2: meaning ""body part"") is a jointed
column3: muscled appendage of a tetrapod vertebrate animal used for weight-bearing
column4: terrestrial locomotion and physical interaction with other objects. The distalmost portion of a limb is known as its extremity. The limbs' bony endoskeleton
column5: known as the appendicular skeleton
column6: is homologous among all tetrapods
column7: who use their limbs for walking
column8: running and jumping
column9: swimming
column10: climbing
column11: grasping
column12: touching and striking.

column1: All tetrapods have four limbs that are organized into two bilaterally symmetrical pairs
column2: with one pair at each end of the torso
column3: which phylogenetically correspond to the four paired fins (pectoral and pelvic fins) of their fish (sarcopterygian) ancestors. The cranial pair (i.e. closer to the head) of limbs are known as the forelimbs or front legs
column4: and the caudal pair (i.e. closer to the tail or coccyx) are the hindlimbs or back legs. In animals with a more erect bipedal posture (mainly hominid primates
column5: particularly humans)
column6: the forelimbs and hindlimbs are often called upper and lower limbs
column7: respectively. The fore-/upper limbs are connected to the thoracic cage via the pectoral/shoulder girdles
column8: and the hind-/lower limbs are connected to the pelvis via the hip joints. Many animals
column9: especially the arboreal species
column10: have prehensile forelimbs adapted for grasping and climbing
column11: while some (mostly primates) can also use hindlimbs for grasping. Some animals (birds and bats) have expanded forelimbs (and sometimes hindlimbs as well) with specialized feathers or membranes to achieve lift and fly. Aquatic and semiaquatic tetrapods usually have limb features (such as webbings) adapted to better provide propulsion in water
column12: while marine mammals and sea turtles have convergently evolved flattened
column13: paddle-like limbs known as flippers.

column2: the upper and lower limbs are commonly known as the arms and legs respectively
column3: although in academic usage
column4: these terms refer specifically to the upper arm and lower leg (the lower arm and upper leg are instead called forearm and thigh
column5: respectively). The human arms have relatively great ranges of motion and are highly adapted for grasping and for carrying objects. The extremity of each arm
column6: known as the hand
column7: has five opposable digits known as fingers (made up of metacarpal and metatarsal bones for hands and feet respectively) and specializes in intrinsic fine motor skills for precise manipulation of objects. The human legs and their extremities — the feet — are specialized for bipedal locomotion. Compared to most other mammals that walk and run on all four limbs
column8: human limbs are proportionally weaker but very mobile and versatile
column9: and the unique  dexterity of the human upper extremities allows them to make sophisticated tools and machines that compensate for the lack of physical strength and endurance.

column1: Limbs are attached to the torso via girdles
column2: either the pectoral girdle for the forelimbs
column3: or the pelvic girdle for the hindlimbs. In terrestrial tetrapods
column4: the pectoral girdles are more mobile
column5: floating over the rib cage connected only via the clavicles (to the sternum) and numerous muscles; while the pelvic girdles are typically fused together anteriorly via a fibrocartilaginous joint and posteriorly with the vertebral column (sacrum)
column6: forming an immobile ring-like pelvis. The girdles are each connected to the corresponding limb proper via a ball-and-socket synovial joint.

column1: The overall patterns of forelimbs and hindlimbs are homologous among all tetrapods
column2: as they all branched out of the same bottlenecked lineage of stegocephalians that survived the Late Devonian extinction. The body plan of tetrapod limbs are so similar (especially the pentadactyly) that they are given shared terminologies for each component of the appendicular skeleton.

column1: The proximal half of the limb proper has one long bone
column2: the stylopodium (plural: stylopodia)
column3: which may be the humerus of the upper arm (proximal forelimbs)
column4: or the femur of the thigh (proximal hindlimbs).

column1: The distal half of the limb proper has two long bones
column2: together termed the zeugopodium (plural: zeugopodia). These may be radius and ulna of the forearm
column3: or the tibia and fibula of the shin.

column1: The distalmost portion or extremity of the limb
column2: i.e. the hand or foot
column3: is known as the autopodium (plural: autopodia). Hands are technically known as the manus
column4: and feet as the pes.

column1: The proximal part of the autopodium
column2: i.e. the wrist or ankle region
column3: has many small nodular bones
column4: collectively termed the mesopodium (plural: mesopodia). Wrist bones are known as the carpals
column5: and ankle bones are known as the tarsals.

column1: The middle part of the autopodium is the metapodium (plural: metapodia)
column2: composed of the slender long bones each called a metapodial. The metapodials of the hand are known as metacarpals
column3: while the metapodials of the foot are known as metatarsals. The ventral (or flexor) aspect of the hand is known as the palm or vola
column4: and that of the foot as the sole or planta.

column1: The distalmost part of the autopodium are the digits (fingers or toes)
column2: which have multi-jointed phalanges and are highly mobile in most tetrapods. The ends of the digits are often protectively covered by hardened keratin outgrowths such as claws and nails.

column1: Limb development is controlled by Hox genes. All jawed vertebrates surveyed so far organize their developing limb buds in a similar way. Growth occurs from proximal to distal part of the limb. On the distal end
column2: the differentiation of skeletal elements occurs in an apical ectodermal ridge (AER) which expands in rays. A Zone of Polarizing Activity (ZPA) at the rear part of the AER coordinates the differentiation of digits.
