https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mammary_gland|A10.336.532;A01.236.249|D042361|Mammary gland|"A mammary gland is an exocrine gland in humans and other mammals that produces milk to feed young offspring. Mammals get their name from the Latin word mamma
column2: ""breast"". The mammary glands are arranged in organs such as the breasts in primates (for example
column3: humans and chimpanzees)
column4: the udder in ruminants (for example
column5: cows
column6: goats
column7: sheep
column8: and deer)
column9: and the dugs of other animals (for example
column10: dogs and cats). Lactorrhea
column11: the occasional production of milk by the glands
column12: can occur in any mammal
column13: but in most mammals
column15: the production of enough milk for nursing
column16: occurs only in phenotypic females who have gestated in recent months or years. It is directed by hormonal guidance from sex steroids. In a few mammalian species
column17: male lactation can occur. With humans
column18: male lactation can occur only under specific circumstances.

column1: Mammals are divided into 3 groups: prototherians
column2: metatherians
column3: and eutherians. In the case of prototherians
column4: both males and females have functional mammary glands
column5: but their mammary glands are without nipples. These mammary glands are modified sebaceous glands. Concerning metatherians and eutherians
column6: only females have functional mammary glands. Their mammary glands can be termed as breasts or udders. In the case of breasts
column7: each mammary gland has its own nipple (e.g.
column8: human mammary glands). In the case of udders
column9: pairs of mammary glands comprise a single mass
column10: with more than one nipple (or teat) hanging from it. For instance
column11: cows and buffalo udders have two pairs of mammary glands and four teats
column12: whereas sheep and goat udders have one pair of mammary glands with two teats protruding from the udder. Each gland produces milk for a single teat.  These mammary glands are modified sweat glands.

column1: The basic components of a mature mammary gland are the alveoli (hollow cavities
column2: a few millimeters large)
column3: which are lined with milk-secreting cuboidal cells and surrounded by myoepithelial cells. These alveoli join to form groups known as lobules. Each lobule has a lactiferous duct that drains into openings in the nipple. The myoepithelial cells contract under the stimulation of oxytocin
column4: excreting the milk secreted by alveolar units into the lobule lumen toward the nipple. As the infant begins to suck
column5: the oxytocin-mediated ""let down reflex"" ensues
column6: and the mother's milk is secreted — not sucked — from the gland into the baby's mouth.

column1: All the milk-secreting tissue leading to a single lactiferous duct is collectively called a ""simple mammary gland""; in a ""complex mammary gland""
column2: all the simple mammary glands serve one nipple. Humans normally have two complex mammary glands
column3: one in each breast
column4: and each complex mammary gland consists of 10–20 simple glands. The opening of each simple gland on the surface of the nipple is called a ""pore."" The presence of more than two nipples is known as polythelia and the presence of more than two complex mammary glands as polymastia.

column1: Maintaining the correct polarized morphology of the lactiferous duct tree requires another essential component – mammary epithelial cells extracellular matrix (ECM) which
column2: together with adipocytes
column3: fibroblast
column4: inflammatory cells
column5: and others
column6: constitute mammary stroma. Mammary epithelial ECM mainly contains myoepithelial basement membrane and the connective tissue. They not only help to support mammary basic structure
column7: but also serve as a communicating bridge between mammary epithelia and their local and global environment throughout this organ's development.

column1: A mammary gland is a specific type of apocrine gland specialized for manufacture of colostrum (first milk) when giving birth. Mammary glands can be identified as apocrine because they exhibit striking ""decapitation"" secretion. Many sources assert that mammary glands are modified sweat glands.
Mammary glands develop during different growth cycles. They exist in both sexes during the embryonic stage
column2: forming only a rudimentary duct tree at birth. In this stage
column3: mammary gland development depends on systemic (and maternal) hormones
column4: but is also under the (local) regulation of paracrine communication between neighboring epithelial and mesenchymal cells by parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP). This locally secreted factor gives rise to a series of outside-in and inside-out positive feedback between these two types of cells
column5: so that mammary bud epithelial cells can proliferate and sprout down into the mesenchymal layer until they reach the fat pad to begin the first round of branching. At the same time
column6: the embryonic mesenchymal cells around the epithelial bud receive secreting factors activated by PTHrP
column7: such as BMP4. These mesenchymal cells can transform into a dense
column8: mammary-specific mesenchyme
column9: which later develop into connective tissue with fibrous threads
column10: forming blood vessels and the lymph system. A basement membrane
column11: mainly containing laminin and collagen
column12: formed afterward by differentiated myoepithelial cells
column13: keeps the polarity of this primary duct tree. These components of the extracellular matrix are strong determinants of duct morphogenesis.

column1: Estrogen and growth hormone (GH) are essential for the ductal component of mammary gland development
column2: and act synergistically to mediate it. Neither estrogen nor GH are capable of inducing ductal development without the other. The role of GH in ductal development has been found to be mostly mediated by its induction of the secretion of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1)
column3: which occurs both systemically (mainly originating from the liver) and locally in the mammary fat pad through activation of the growth hormone receptor (GHR). However
column4: GH itself also acts independently of IGF-1 to stimulate ductal development by upregulating estrogen receptor (ER) expression in mammary gland tissue
column5: which is a downstream effect of mammary gland GHR activation. In any case
column6: unlike IGF-1
column7: GH itself is not essential for mammary gland development
column8: and IGF-1 in conjunction with estrogen can induce normal mammary gland development without the presence of GH. In addition to IGF-1
column9: other paracrine growth factors such as epidermal growth factor (EGF)
column10: transforming growth factor beta (TGF-β)
column11: amphiregulin
column12: fibroblast growth factor (FGF)
column13: and hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) are involved in breast development as mediators downstream to sex hormones and GH/IGF-1.

column2: IGF-1 levels are low
column3: and gradually increase from birth to puberty. At puberty
column4: the levels of GH and IGF-1 reach their highest levels in life and estrogen begins to be secreted in high amounts in females
column5: which is when ductal development mostly takes place. Under the influence of estrogen
column6: stromal and fat tissue surrounding the ductal system in the mammary glands also grows. After puberty
column7: GH and IGF-1 levels progressively decrease
column8: which limits further development until pregnancy
column9: if it occurs. During pregnancy
column10: progesterone and prolactin are essential for mediating lobuloalveolar development in estrogen-primed mammary gland tissue
column11: which occurs in preparation of lactation and nursing.

column1: Androgens such as testosterone inhibit estrogen-mediated mammary gland development (e.g.
column2: by reducing local ER expression) through activation of androgen receptors expressed in mammary gland tissue
column3: and in conjunction with relatively low estrogen levels
column4: are the cause of the lack of developed mammary glands in males.

column1: Mammary gland development is characterized by the unique process by which the epithelium invades the stroma. The development of the mammary gland occurs mainly after birth. During puberty
column2: tubule formation is coupled with branching morphogenesis which establishes the basic arboreal network of ducts emanating from the nipple.
mammary gland epithelium is constantly produced and maintained by rare epithelial cells
column3: dubbed as mammary progenitors which are ultimately thought to be derived from tissue-resident stem cells.

column1: Embryonic mammary gland development can be divided into a series of specific stages. Initially
column2: the formation of the milk lines that run between the fore and hind limbs bilaterally on each side of the midline occurs around embryonic day 10.5 (E10.5). The second stage occurs at E11.5 when placode formation begins along the mammary milk line.  This will eventually give rise to the nipple. Lastly
column3: the third stage occurs at E12.5 and involves the invagination of cells within the placode into the mesenchyme
column4: leading to a mammary anlage (biology).

column1: The primitive (stem) cells are detected in embryo and their numbers increase steadily during development

column2: the mammary ducts elongate into the mammary fat pad. Then
column3: starting around four weeks of age
column4: mammary ductal growth increases significantly with the ducts invading towards the lymph node. Terminal end buds
column5: the highly proliferative structures found at the tips of the invading ducts
column6: expand and increase greatly during this stage. This developmental period is characterized by the emergence of the terminal end buds and lasts until an age of about 7–8 weeks.

column2: the mammary ducts have invaded to the end of the mammary fat pad. At this point
column3: the terminal end buds become less proliferative and decrease in size. Side branches form from the primary ducts and begin to fill the mammary fat pad. Ductal development decreases with the arrival of sexual maturity and undergoes estrous cycles (proestrus
column4: estrus
column5: metestrus
column6: and diestrus). As a result of estrous cycling
column7: the mammary gland undergoes dynamic changes where cells proliferate and then regress in an ordered fashion.

column2: the ductal systems undergo rapid proliferation and form alveolar structures within the branches to be used for milk production. After delivery
column3: lactation occurs within the mammary gland; lactation involves the secretion of milk by the luminal cells in the alveoli. Contraction of the myoepithelial cells surrounding the alveoli will cause the milk to be ejected through the ducts and into the nipple for the nursing infant. Upon weaning of the infant
column4: lactation stops and the mammary gland turns in on itself
column5: a process called involution. This process involves the controlled collapse of mammary epithelial cells where cells begin apoptosis in a controlled manner
column6: reverting the mammary gland back to a pubertal state.

column2: due to much lower levels of estrogen
column3: and due to lower levels of GH and IGF-1
column4: which decrease with age
column5: mammary gland tissue atrophies and the mammary glands become smaller.

column1: Lactiferous duct development occurs in females in response to circulating hormones. First development is frequently seen during pre- and postnatal stages
column2: and later during puberty. Estrogen promotes branching differentiation
column3: whereas in males testosterone inhibits it. A mature duct tree reaching the limit of the fat pad of the mammary gland comes into being by bifurcation of duct terminal end buds (TEB)
column4: secondary branches sprouting from primary ducts and proper duct lumen formation. These processes are tightly modulated by components of mammary epithelial ECM interacting with systemic hormones and local secreting factors. However
column5: for each mechanism the epithelial cells' ""niche"" can be delicately unique with different membrane receptor profiles and basement membrane thickness from specific branching area to area
column6: so as to regulate cell growth or differentiation sub-locally. Important players include beta-1 integrin
column7: epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)
column8: laminin-1/5
column9: collagen-IV
column10: matrix metalloproteinase (MMPs)
column11: heparan sulfate proteoglycans
column12: and others. Elevated circulating level of growth hormone and estrogen get to multipotent cap cells on TEB tips through a thin
column13: leaky layer of basement membrane. These hormones promote specific gene expression. Hence cap cells can differentiate into myoepithelial and luminal (duct) epithelial cells
column14: and the increased amount of activated MMPs can degrade surrounding ECM helping duct buds to reach further in the fat pads. On the other hand
column15: basement membrane along the mature mammary ducts is thicker
column16: with strong adhesion to epithelial cells via binding to integrin and non-integrin receptors. When side branches develop
column17: it is a much more ""pushing-forward"" working process including extending through myoepithelial cells
column18: degrading basement membrane and then invading into a periductal layer of fibrous stromal tissue. Degraded basement membrane fragments (laminin-5) roles to lead the way of mammary epithelial cells migration. Whereas
column19: laminin-1 interacts with non-integrin receptor dystroglycan negatively regulates this side branching process in case of cancer. These complex ""Yin-yang"" balancing crosstalks between mammary ECM and epithelial cells ""instruct"" healthy mammary gland development until adult.

column1: There is preliminary evidence that soybean intake mildly stimulates the breast glands in pre- and postmenopausal women.
Secretory alveoli develop mainly in pregnancy
column2: when rising levels of prolactin
column3: estrogen
column4: and progesterone cause further branching
column5: together with an increase in adipose tissue and a richer blood flow. In gestation
column6: serum progesterone remains at a stably high concentration so signaling through its receptor is continuously activated. As one of the transcribed genes
column7: Wnts secreted from mammary epithelial cells act paracrinely to induce more neighboring cells' branching. When the lactiferous duct tree is almost ready
column8: ""leaves"" alveoli are differentiated from luminal epithelial cells and added at the end of each branch. In late pregnancy and for the first few days after giving birth
column9: colostrum is secreted. Milk secretion (lactation) begins a few days later due to reduction in circulating progesterone and the presence of another important hormone prolactin
column10: which mediates further alveologenesis
column11: milk protein production
column12: and regulates osmotic balance and tight junction function. Laminin and collagen in myoepithelial basement membrane interacting with beta-1 integrin on epithelial surface again
column13: is essential in this process. Their binding ensures correct placement of prolactin receptors on the basal lateral side of alveoli cells and directional secretion of milk into lactiferous ducts. Suckling of the baby causes release of the hormone oxytocin
column14: which stimulates contraction of the myoepithelial cells. In this combined control from ECM and systemic hormones
column15: milk secretion can be reciprocally amplified so as to provide enough nutrition for the baby.

column2: decreased prolactin
column3: missing mechanical stimulation (baby suckling)
column4: and changes in osmotic balance caused by milk stasis and leaking of tight junctions cause cessation of milk production. It is the (passive) process of a child or animal ceasing to be dependent on the mother for nourishment. In some species there is complete or partial involution of alveolar structures after weaning
column5: in humans there is only partial involution and the level of involution in humans appears to be highly individual. The glands in the breast do secrete fluid also in nonlactating women. In some other species (such as cows)
column6: all alveoli and secretory duct structures collapse by programmed cell death (apoptosis) and autophagy for lack of growth promoting factors either from the ECM or circulating hormones. At the same time
column7: apoptosis of blood capillary endothelial cells speeds up the regression of lactation ductal beds. Shrinkage of the mammary duct tree and ECM remodeling by various proteinase is under the control of somatostatin and other growth inhibiting hormones and local factors. This major structural change leads loose fat tissue to fill the empty space afterward. But a functional lactiferous duct tree can be formed again when a female is pregnant again.

column1: Tumorigenesis in mammary glands can be induced biochemically by abnormal expression level of circulating hormones or local ECM components
column2: or from a mechanical change in the tension of mammary stroma. Under either of the two circumstances
column3: mammary epithelial cells would grow out of control and eventually result in cancer. Almost all instances of breast cancer originate in the lobules or ducts of the mammary glands.

column1: The breasts of female humans vary from most other mammals that tend to have less conspicuous mammary glands. The number and positioning of mammary glands varies widely in different mammals. The protruding teats and accompanying glands can be located anywhere along the two milk lines. In general most mammals develop mammary glands in pairs along these lines
column2: with a number approximating the number of young typically birthed at a time. The number of teats varies from 2 (in most primates) to 18 (in pigs). The Virginia opossum has 13
column3: one of the few mammals with an odd number. The following table lists the number and position of teats and glands found in a range of mammals:

column1: Male mammals typically have rudimentary mammary glands and nipples
column2: with a few exceptions: male mice do not have nipples
column3: male marsupials do not have mammary glands
column4: and male horses lack nipples. The male dayak fruit bat has lactating mammary glands. Male lactation occurs infrequently in some species.

column1: Mammary glands are true protein factories
column2: and several labs have constructed transgenic animals
column3: mainly goats and cows
column4: to produce proteins for pharmaceutical use. Complex glycoproteins such as monoclonal antibodies or antithrombin cannot be produced by genetically engineered bacteria
column5: and the production in live mammals is much cheaper than the use of mammalian cell cultures.

column1: There are many theories on how mammary glands evolved. For example
column2: it is thought that the mammary gland is a transformed sweat gland
column3: more closely related to apocrine sweat glands. Because mammary glands do not fossilize well
column4: supporting such theories with fossil evidence is difficult. Many of the current theories are based on comparisons between lines of living mammals—monotremes
column5: marsupials
column6: and eutherians. One theory proposes that mammary glands evolved from glands that were used to keep the eggs of early mammals moist and free from infection (monotremes still lay eggs). Other theories suggest that early secretions were used directly by hatched young
column7: or that the secretions were used by young to help them orient to their mothers.

column1: Lactation is thought to have developed long before the evolution of the mammary gland and mammals; see evolution of lactation.

the metacarpal  bones or metacarpus
column3: also known as the ""palm bones""
column4: are the appendicular bones that form the intermediate part of the hand between the phalanges (fingers) and the carpal bones (wrist bones)
column5: which articulate with the forearm. The metacarpal bones are homologous to the metatarsal bones in the foot.

column1: The metacarpals form a transverse arch to which the rigid row of distal carpal bones are fixed. The peripheral metacarpals (those of the thumb and little finger) form the sides of the cup of the palmar gutter and as they are brought together they deepen this concavity. The index metacarpal is the most firmly fixed
column2: while the thumb metacarpal articulates with the trapezium and acts independently from the others. The middle metacarpals are tightly united to the carpus by intrinsic interlocking bone elements at their bases. The ring metacarpal is somewhat more mobile while the fifth metacarpal is semi-independent.

column1: Each metacarpal bone consists of a body or shaft
column2: and two extremities: the head at the distal or digital end (near the fingers)
column3: and the base at the proximal or carpal end (close to the wrist).

column1: The body (shaft) is prismoid in form
column2: and curved
column3: so as to be convex in the longitudinal direction behind
column4: concave in front. It presents three surfaces: medial
column5: lateral
column6: and dorsal.

column1: The medial and lateral surfaces are concave
column2: for the attachment of the interosseus muscles
column3: and separated from one another by a prominent anterior ridge.

column1: The dorsal surface presents in its distal two-thirds a smooth
column2: triangular
column3: flattened area which is covered in by the tendons of the extensor muscles. This surface is bounded by two lines
column4: which commence in small tubercles situated on either side of the digital extremity
column5: and
column6: passing upward
column7: converge and meet some distance above the center of the bone and form a ridge which runs along the rest of the dorsal surface to the carpal extremity. This ridge separates two sloping surfaces for the attachment of the interossei dorsales.

column1: To the tubercles on the digital extremities are attached the collateral ligaments of the metacarpophalangeal joints.
The base (basis) or carpal extremity is of a cuboidal form
column2: and broader behind than in front: it articulates with the carpal bones and with the adjoining metacarpal bones; its dorsal and volar surfaces are rough
column3: for the attachment of ligaments.

column1: The head (caput) or digital extremity presents an oblong surface markedly convex from before backward
column2: less so transversely
column3: and flattened from side to side; it articulates with the proximal phalanx. It is broader
column4: and extends farther upward
column5: on the volar than on the dorsal aspect
column6: and is longer in the antero-posterior than in the transverse diameter. On either side of the head is a tubercle for the attachment of the collateral ligament of the metacarpophalangeal joint.

column2: broad and flat
column3: supports the tendons of the extensor muscles.

column1: The volar surface is grooved in the middle line for the passage of the flexor tendons
column2: and marked on either side by an articular eminence continuous with the terminal articular surface.
or subcapital segment
column3: is the transition zone between the body and the head.

column2: the metacarpal bones articulate by carpometacarpal joints as follows:
trapezoid
column3: capitate and third metacarpal;

column1: the third with the capitate and second and fourth metacarpals;

column2: hamate
column3: and third and fifth metacarpals;

column1: and the fifth with the hamate and fourth metacarpal;
Extensor Carpi Radialis Longus/Brevis: Both insert on the base of metacarpal II; Assist with wrist extension and radial flexion of the wrist
Extensor Carpi Ulnaris: Inserts on the base of metacarpal V; Extends and fixes wrist when digits are being flexed; assists with ulnar flexion of wrist
Abductor Pollicis Longus: Inserts on the trapezium and base of metacarpal I; Abducts thumb in frontal plane; extends thumb at carpometacarpal joint
Opponens Pollicis: Inserts on metacarpal I; flexes metacarpal I to oppose the thumb to the fingertips

Opponens digiti minimi: Inserts on the medial surface of metacarpal V; Flexes metacarpal V at carpometacarpal joint when little finger is moved into opposition with tip of thumb; deepens palm of hand.
The fourth and fifth metacarpal bones are commonly ""blunted"" or shortened
column2: in pseudohypoparathyroidism and pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism.
with normal fifth metacarpal
column3: can signify Turner syndrome.

column1: Blunted metacarpals (particularly the fourth metacarpal) are a symptom of nevoid basal-cell carcinoma syndrome.
The neck of a metacarpal is a common location for a boxer's fracture
column2: but all parts of the metacarpal bone (including head
column3: body and base) are susceptible to fracture. During their lifetime
column4: 2.5% of individuals will experience at least one metacarpal fracture. Bennett's fracture (base of the thumb) is the most common. Several types of treatment exist ranging from non-operative techniques
column5: with or without immobilization
column6: to operative techniques using closed or open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF). Generally
column7: most fractures showing little or no displacement can be treated successfully without surgery. Intraarticular fracture-dislocations of the metacarpal head or base may require surgical fixation
column8: as fragment displacement affecting the joint surface is rarely tolerated well.

column2: the metacarpals form part of the forefeet
column3: and are frequently reduced in number
column4: appropriate to the number of toes. In digitigrade and unguligrade animals
column5: the metacarpals are greatly extended and strengthened
column6: forming an additional segment to the limb
column7: a feature that typically enhances the animal's speed. In both birds and bats
column8: the metacarpals form part of the wing.

column1: The Greek physician Galen used to refer to the metacarpus as μετακάρπιον. The Latin form metacarpium  more truly resembles its Ancient Greek predecessor μετακάρπιον than metacarpus. Meta– is Greek for beyond and carpal from Ancient Greek καρπός (karpós
column2: “wrist”).
adjectives like metacarpius
column3: metacarpicus

column6: metacarpianus and metacarpalis can be found. The form metacarpius is more true to the later Greek form μετακάρπιος.  Metacarpalis
column7: as in ossa metacarpalia in the current official Latin nomenclature
column8: Terminologia Anatomica is a compound consisting of Latin and Greek parts. The usage of such hybrids in anatomic Latin is disapproved by some.

column1: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neck|A01.598|D009333|Neck|"The neck is the part of the body on many vertebrates that connects the head with the torso. The neck supports the weight of the head and protects the nerves that carry sensory and motor information from the brain down to the rest of the body. In addition
column2: the neck is highly flexible and allows the head to turn and flex in all directions. The structures of the human neck are anatomically grouped into four compartments: vertebral
column3: visceral and two vascular compartments. Within these compartments
column4: the neck houses the cervical vertebrae and cervical part of the spinal cord
column5: upper parts of the respiratory and digestive tracts
column6: endocrine glands
column7: nerves
column8: arteries and veins. Muscles of the neck are described separately from the compartments. They bound the neck triangles.

column2: the neck is also called by its Latin names
column3: cervix or collum
column4: although when used alone
column5: in context
column6: the word cervix more often refers to the uterine cervix
column7: the neck of the uterus. Thus the adjective cervical may refer either to the neck (as in cervical vertebrae or cervical lymph nodes) or to the uterine cervix (as in cervical cap or cervical cancer).

column1: The neck structures are distributed within four compartments:

Vertebral compartment contains the cervical vertebrae with cartilaginous discs between each vertebral body. The alignment of the vertebrae defines the shape of the human neck. As the vertebrae bound the spinal canal
column2: the cervical portion of the spinal cord is also found within the neck.
larynx
column3: pharynx
column4: thyroid and parathyroid glands.

column1: Vascular compartment is paired and consists of the two carotid sheaths found on each side of the trachea. Each carotid sheath contains the vagus nerve
column2: common carotid artery and internal jugular vein.
the neck contains cervical lymph nodes which surround the blood vessels.

column1: Muscles of the neck attach to the skull
column2: hyoid bone
column3: clavicles and the sternum. They bound the two major neck triangles; anterior and posterior.

column1: Anterior triangle is defined by the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle
column2: inferior edge of the mandible and the midline of the neck. It contains the stylohyoid
column3: digastric
column4: mylohyoid
column5: geniohyoid
column6: omohyoid
column7: sternohyoid
column8: thyrohyoid and sternothyroid muscles. These muscles are grouped as the suprahyoid and infrahyoid muscles depending on if they are located superiorly or inferiorly to the hyoid bone. The suprahyoid muscles (stylohyoid
column9: digastric
column10: mylohyoid
column11: geniohyoid) elevate the hyoid bone
column12: while the infrahyoid muscles (omohyoid
column13: sternohyoid
column16: both groups facilitate speech and swallowing.

column1: Posterior triangle is bordered by the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle
column2: anterior border of the trapezius muscle and the superior edge of the middle third of the clavicle. This triangle contains the sternocleidomastoid
column3: trapezius
column4: splenius capitis
column5: levator scapulae
column6: omohyoid
column7: anterior
column8: middle and posterior scalene muscles.

column1: Sensation to the front areas of the neck comes from the roots of the spinal nerves C2-C4
column2: and at the back of the neck from the roots of C4-C5.

column1: In addition to nerves coming from and within the human spine
column2: the accessory nerve and vagus nerve travel down the neck.

column1: Arteries which supply the neck are common carotid arteries
column2: which bifurcate into the internal and external carotid arteries.

column1: The thyroid cartilage of the larynx forms a bulge in the midline of the neck called the Adam's apple. The Adam's apple is usually more prominent in men. Inferior to the Adam's apple is the cricoid cartilage. The trachea is traceable at the midline
column2: extending between the cricoid cartilage and suprasternal notch.
the sternomastoid muscle is the most striking mark. It separates the anterior triangle of the neck from the posterior.  The upper part of the anterior triangle contains the submandibular glands
column3: which lie just below the posterior half of the mandible. The line of the common and the external carotid arteries can be marked by joining the sterno-clavicular articulation to the angle of the jaw. Neck lines can appear at any age of adulthood as a result of sun damage
column4: for example
column5: or of ageing where skin loses its elasticity and can wrinkle.

column1: The eleventh cranial nerve or spinal accessory nerve corresponds to a line drawn from a point midway between the angle of the jaw and the mastoid process to the middle of the posterior border of the sterno-mastoid muscle and thence across the posterior triangle to the deep surface of the trapezius.  The external jugular vein can usually be seen through the skin; it runs in a line drawn from the angle of the jaw to the middle of the clavicle
column2: and close to it are some small lymphatic glands. The anterior jugular vein is smaller and runs down about half an inch from the middle line of the neck.  The clavicle or collarbone forms the lower limit of the neck
column3: and laterally the outward slope of the neck to the shoulder is caused by the trapezius muscle.

column1: Disorders of the neck are a common source of pain.  The neck has a great deal of functionality but is also subject to a lot of stress.  Common sources of neck pain (and related pain syndromes
column2: such as pain that radiates down the arm) include (and are strictly limited to):
strained a muscle or another soft tissue injury
like arterial dissections or internal jugular vein thrombosis

column1: Higher neck circumference has been associated with cardiometabolic risk. Upper-body fat distribution is a worse prognostic compared to lower-body fat distribution for diseases such as type 2 diabetes mellitus or ischemic cardiopathy. Neck circumference has been associated with the risk of being mechanically ventilated in COVID-19 patients
column2: with a 26% increased risk for each centimeter increase in neck circumference. Moreover
column3: hospitalized COVID-19 patients with a ""large neck phenotype"" on admission had a more than double risk of death.

column1: The neck appears in some of the earliest of tetrapod fossils
column2: and the functionality provided has led to its being retained in all land vertebrates as well as marine-adapted tetrapods such as turtles
column3: seals
column4: and penguins. Some degree of flexibility is retained even where the outside physical manifestation has been secondarily lost
column5: as in whales and porpoises. A morphologically functioning neck also appears among insects. Its absence in fish and aquatic arthropods is notable
column6: as many have life stations similar to a terrestrial or tetrapod counterpart or could otherwise make use of the added flexibility.

column1: The word ""neck"" is sometimes used as a convenience to refer to the region behind the head in some snails
column2: gastropod mollusks
column3: even though there is no clear distinction between this area
column4: the head area
column5: and the rest of the body.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metatarsal_bones|A01.378.610.250.300.480|D008684|Metatarsal bones|"The metatarsal bones or metatarsus (pl.: metatarsi) are a group of five long bones in the midfoot
column2: located between the tarsal bones (which form the heel and the ankle) and the phalanges (toes). Lacking individual names
column3: the metatarsal bones are numbered from the medial side (the side of the great toe): the first
column4: second
column5: third
column6: fourth
column7: and fifth metatarsal (often depicted with Roman numerals). The metatarsals are analogous to the metacarpal bones of the hand. The lengths of the metatarsal bones in humans are
column8: in descending order
column9: second
column10: third
column11: fourth
column12: fifth
column13: and first. A bovine hind leg has two metatarsals.

column1: The five metatarsals are dorsal convex long bones consisting of a shaft or body
column2: a base (proximally)
column3: and a head (distally). The body is prismoid in form
column4: tapers gradually from the tarsal to the phalangeal extremity
column5: and is curved longitudinally
column6: so as to be concave below
column7: slightly convex above. The base or posterior extremity is wedge-shaped
column8: articulating proximally with the tarsal bones
column9: and by its sides with the contiguous metatarsal bones: its dorsal and plantar surfaces are rough for the attachment of ligaments. The head or distal extremity presents a convex articular surface
column10: oblong from above downward
column11: and extending farther backward below than above. Its sides are flattened
column12: and on each is a depression
column13: surmounted by a tubercle
column14: for ligamentous attachment. Its plantar surface is grooved antero-posteriorly for the passage of the flexor tendons
column15: and marked on either side by an articular eminence continuous with the terminal articular surface.

column2: the growth plates are located distally on the metatarsals
column3: except on the first metatarsal where it is located proximally. Yet it is quite common to have an accessory growth plate on the distal first metatarsal.

column1: The base of each metatarsal bone articulates with one or more of the tarsal bones at the tarsometatarsal joints
column2: and the head with one of the first row of phalanges at the metatarsophalangeal joints.  Their bases also articulate with each other at the intermetatarsal joints

column1: The first metatarsal articulates with the medial cuneiform
column2: and to a small extent to the intermediate cuneiform.

column1: the second with all three cuneiforms.
the third with the lateral cuneiform.
the fourth with the lateral cuneiform and the cuboid.
The metatarsal bones are often broken by association football (soccer) players. These and other recent cases have been attributed to the lightweight design of modern football boots
column2: which provide less protection to the foot. In 2010 some football players began testing a new sock that incorporated a rubber silicone pad over the foot to provide protection to the top of the foot. Stress fractures are thought to account for 16% of injuries related to sports participation
column3: and the metatarsals are the bones most often involved. These fractures are sometimes called march fractures
column4: based on their traditional association with military recruits after long marches. The second and third metatarsals are fixed while walking
column5: thus these metatarsals are common sites of injury. The fifth metatarsal may be fractured if the foot is oversupinated during locomotion.

column1: Protection from injuries can be given by the use of safety footwear which can use built-in or removable metatarsal guards.

column1: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eyelash|A17.360.421;A09.371.337.338;A01.456.505.420.504.421|D005140|Eyelash|"An eyelash (also called lash) (Latin: cilia) is one of the hairs that grows at the edges of the top and bottom eyelids
column2: spanning outwards and away from the eyes. The lashes grow in up to six layers on each of the upper and lower eyelids. Eyelashes serve to protect the eye from debris
column3: dust
column4: and small particles
column5: and are highly sensitive to touch
column6: thus providing a warning that an object (such as an insect or lint) is near the eye
column7: which then reflexively closes or flutters to rid the area of the object. The eyelid margin from which lashes grow is among the most sensitive parts of the human body
column8: with many nerve endings enveloping the roots of the lashes
column9: giving it sensitivity to very light tactile input even at the tips of the lashes
column10: enabling it to trigger the blink reflex when touched. Eyelashes are also an important component of physical attractiveness
column11: with long prominent lashes giving the illusion of large
column12: gazing eyes
column13: and drawing attention to the eyes.

column1: The word eyelash is a portmanteau derived from the prefix eye- referring to the eye which the lashes surround (by means of growing on the lids) and protects
column2: and the suffix -lash
column3: which can refer to a whip or the act of a stroke with a whip. This is in reference to both the individual lashes resembling a whip
column4: and the action of blinking the eyes causing the lashes to move in a stroking or whipping motion.

column2: the eyelashes serve four main functions:

column1: Protect the eye from dust and debris by catching them before they can enter the eye
Trigger the blink reflex in the case of a foreign body approaching the eye and touching the lashes
Regulate or reduce evaporation of the tear film on the cornea
Protect the conjunctivae from excessive light and ultraviolet radiation
column2: by forming a filamentous curtain-like structure through their arrangement in multiple imperfect rows

column1: The eyelashes of the human embryo develop from the ectoderm between the 22nd and 26th week of pregnancy. Eyelashes take about seven to eight weeks to grow back if pulled out
column2: but constant pulling may lead to permanent damage. Their color may differ from that of the hair
column3: although they tend to be dark on someone with dark hair and lighter on someone with light hair. Eyelash hair is not androgenic and is therefore not affected by puberty. Lash follicles do not have an arrector pili muscle associated with them
column4: making the lashes static.

column1: Human eyelash length is the subject of extensive studies
column2: both for the effect on their functional efficacy
column3: and for their effect on human physical attractiveness. This is also because lashes do not continually grow to long lengths like scalp hair
column4: and the individual variability in their length is almost solely determined by genetics.

column1: While there is considerable variation in the length of lashes between individuals (3 mm to 10 mm for upper lashes)
column2: lashes do not vary in length by sex or ethnicity
column3: with the upper lashes of humans typically 7 to 8 mm in length regardless of sex
column4: and generally do not exceed 10 mm in length. Thus
column5: lashes of humans are considered to be remarkably long when they are 10 mm or greater in length. Lower lashes average between 5 and 6 mm in length. In trichomegaly
column6: the lashes may grow exceptionally long (occasionally 15 mm for the upper lashes). The longest lashes usually grow from the centre of the eyelid. Human eyelash length
column7: thickness
column8: and darkness decrease significantly with age
column9: hence long and thick lashes are sometimes seen as a mark of fertility and youthfulness.

column1: Eyelash length is closely linked to the width of the eye
column2: with the lashes typically growing to one-third the width of the eye as an evolutionary adaptation to reduce tear film evaporation and dust deposition. Lashes longer or shorter than one-third the width of the eye have been shown to have reduced efficacy in serving their function. The typical width of the human eye is 24.2 mm
column3: resulting in the average human eyelash length of 7 to 8 mm. This evolutionary trait is perhaps why lashes in humans rarely grow beyond 10 mm in length. However
column4: longer lashes offer more protection against ultraviolet radiation than their shorter counterparts.

column1: Lashes grow thick at the roots
column2: and have tapered ends. People of Asian ethnicities have significantly thicker lashes
column3: with an average lash diameter of 71.7 μm
column4: than people of Caucasian ethnicities
column5: with have an average lash diameter of 61.0 μm. However
column6: the number of lashes on the eyelids is fewer in Asians
column7: who typically have 150 lash hairs on the upper lids
column8: than in Caucasians
column9: who typically have 170 lash hairs on the upper lid.

column1: Eyelashes grow outwards from both upper and lower eyelids
column2: with varying degrees of curl. People of Caucasian ethnicities have lashes that are more curled than those of Asian ethnicities. However
column3: the degree of curling varies significantly even within a population or ethnicity
column4: where people of Asian ethnicities can also exhibit naturally highly curled lashes.

column1: The number of individual lashes on the upper eyelid is typically 90 to 160
column2: and on the lower eyelid 75 to 80. The number of follicles and hence lashes cannot be increased after birth because all follicles develop during embryogenesis.

column1: The follicles of eyelashes are associated with a number of glands known as the glands of Zeis and the glands of Moll.
There are a number of diseases or disorders involving the eyelashes:
Madarosis is the loss of eyelashes.
Blepharitis is the irritation of the lid margin
column2: where eyelashes join the eyelid.  The eyelids are red and itching
column3: the skin often becomes flaky
column4: and the eyelashes may fall out.

column1: Distichiasis is the abnormal growth of lashes from certain areas of the eyelid.
Eyelashes may become infested with parasitic crab louse.

column2: or stye
column3: is a purulent inflammation of infected eyelash follicles and surrounding sebaceous (Gland of Zeis) and apocrine (Moll's gland) glands of the lid margin.

column1: Trichotillomania is a disorder that urges the sufferer to pull out scalp hair
column2: eyelashes
column3: etc.

column1: Demodex folliculorum (or the demodicid) is a small mite that lives harmlessly in eyelash and other hair follicles
column2: and about 20% of people have these mites living on them. Occasionally they may cause blepharitis.

column1: People with vernal keratoconjunctivitis have longer eyelashes
column2: with the increased growth likely a result of the occular inflammation accompanying the condition.

column1: Trichomegaly is the condition of abnormally long and/or lush lashes (the objective criteria being lashes of 12 mm or greater in length on the upper eyelids).

Eyelash transplant surgeries may help to reconstruct lost or damaged lashes. The procedure may also be employed to increase the number of lash follicles on the eyelid to enhance the prominence and fullness of the lashes. The transplanted hairs usually do not have the tapered structure of real lashes
column2: and continue to grow at the same rate as hairs from the area the follicle was extracted from. As such
column3: they require maintenance by means of trimming.

column2: luscious eyelashes have long been considered a sign of beauty in many cultures
column3: almost universally
column4: and as such are highly coveted
column5: particularly by women. Having longer and thicker lashes can also have a positive psychological effect on women. Despite not varying by sex and not being a secondary sex characteristic
column6: long
column7: prominent lashes are frequently considered a feminine trait
column8: with studies showing that women possessing longer lashes are perceived as healthier and more feminine. Nevertheless
column9: long lashes are regarded as an attractive facial feature in both males and females. On the other hand
column10: Hadza women are known to trim their own eyelashes.

column1: Ancient Romans considered long eyelashes a component of aesthetically ideal eyes. Pliny the Elder wrote that eyelashes fell out from sexual excess
column2: so women desired long lashes as a symbol of chastity. This may have had medical basis as a symptom of syphilis is often alopecia of the lashes
column3: suggesting that individuals with short or sparse lashes were sexually promiscuous.

column1: The traditional Meitei writing system has two letters (symbols)
column2: related to eyelashes. The letter ""ꯄ"" (""Paa"") symbolises the human eyelash
column3: and its letter name ""Paa"" itself means ""eyelash"" in Meitei language. It has an additional form of letter
column4: known as ""Pa Lonsum"" (""ꯞ"").

column1: The lashes and lids play a role in eye contact and nonverbal communication. Voluntarily blinking slowly or a few times in succession quickly is a feminine flirtatious behaviour commonly referred to as to ""bat an eyelash""
column2: ""bat/batting eyelashes""
column3: or ""flutter/fluttering eyelashes"".

column1: Because long eyelashes are aesthetically pleasing and seen as a desirable trait that adds to physical attractiveness
column2: some people seek to enhance their eyelash length artificially
column3: by means of eyelash extensions
column4: false lashes attached to the eyelid
column5: cosmetics
column6: or growth products. Additionally
column7: eyelashes which are curled are also more prominent
column8: being able to better display their length especially when viewed from the front. The enhanced appearance of curled eyelashes can be cosmetically achieved by use of eyelash curlers
column9: or eyelash perms. However
column10: these methods do not physically lengthen the lashes.

column2: a black putty (usually antimony sulfide or lead sulfide)
column3: has been worn as far back as the Bronze Age to darken the edge of the eyelid (just at the bottom of the eyelashes). In Ancient Egypt
column4: it was used as well by the wealthy and the royal to beautify their eyes. Modern eye makeup includes mascara
column5: eyeliner
column6: eye putty
column7: and eye shadow to emphasize the eyes. The twentieth century saw the beginning of convincing false eyelashes
column8: popular in the 1960s.

column1: Permanent eyelash tints and eyelash extensions have also become popular procedures
column2: even in fairly basic salons. It is also possible to get eyelash transplants
column3: which are similar in nature to hair transplantation often done on the head. Since the hair is transplanted from the hair on the head
column4: the new eyelashes will continue to grow like head hair and will need to be trimmed regularly.

column1: Latisse was introduced in the first quarter of 2009 by Allergan as the first drug to receive FDA approval for eyelash growth. Latisse is a solution of bimatoprost
column2: a prostaglandin analog and the active component of the glaucoma medication Lumigan. According to Allergan
column3: noticeable eyelash growth occurs within 16 weeks. Growth is reported to occur primarily on the upper eyelashes
column4: with as much as a 25% increase in length. In addition
column5: the past decade has seen the rapid increase in the development of eyelash conditioners. These conditioners are designed to increase the health and length of lashes. Many utilize seed extract
column6: minerals
column7: and other chemicals to achieve these results.

column1: Cosmetic companies have recently relied on scientific research of prostaglandins and the Wnt/b-catenin signaling pathways to develop eyelash products. Although bimatoprost is effective in promoting increased growth of healthy eyelashes and adnexal hairs
column2: its effectiveness in patients with eyelash alopecia areata is debatable. Some cosmetic brands have begun using peptides in their formulation rather than prostaglandins because of regulatory rules in places like Canada and California.
being hair
column3: are found in mammals. Camels' lashes are remarkably long and thick. Horses and cows feature eyelashes as well. Inherited eyelash problems are common in some breeds of dogs as well as horses.

column1: Eyelashes are an uncommon but not unknown feature in birds. Hornbills have prominent eyelashes (vestigial feathers with no barbs)
column2: as do ostriches. Amongst the reptiles
column3: only Eyelash vipers show a set of modified scales over the eyes which look much like eyelashes.

column2: used to enhance the appearance of length
column3: curliness
column4: fullness
column5: and thickness of natural eyelashes

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pelvic_floor|A01.923.112.500;A02.633.567.050.750;A01.923.600.600|D017773|Pelvic floor|"The pelvic floor or pelvic diaphragm is an anatomical location in the human body
column2: which has an important role in urinary and anal continence

column5: ligaments and fascia. and separates between the pelvic cavity from above
column6: and the  perineum from below. It is formed by the levator ani muscle and coccygeus muscle

column1: The pelvic floor has two hiatuses (gaps): (anteriorly) the urogenital hiatus through which urethra and vagina pass

column1: Some sources do not consider ""pelvic floor"" and ""pelvic diaphragm"" to be identical

column1: The pelvic cavity of the true pelvis has the pelvic floor as its inferior boundary (and the pelvic brim as its superior boundary). The perineum has the pelvic floor as its superior boundary.

column2: the pelvic floor extends into the anal triangle.

column1: It is important in providing support for pelvic viscera (organs)
column2: e.g. the bladder
column3: intestines

column6: causing the fetus to rotate forwards to navigate through the pelvic girdle. It helps maintain optimal intra-abdominal pressure.

column1: The pelvic floor is subject to clinically relevant changes that can result in:
Vaginal vault prolapse (roof of vagina) - after hysterectomy
Pelvic floor dysfunction can result after treatment for gynecological cancers.
Damage to the pelvic floor not only contributes to urinary incontinence but can lead to pelvic organ prolapse.  Pelvic organ prolapse occurs in women when pelvic organs (e.g. the vagina
column2: bladder
column3: rectum
column4: or uterus) protrude into or outside of the vagina.  The causes of pelvic organ prolapse are not unlike those that also contribute to urinary incontinence.  These include inappropriate (asymmetrical
column5: excessive
column6: insufficient) muscle tone and asymmetries caused by trauma to the pelvis.  Age
column7: pregnancy
column8: family history
column9: and hormonal status all contribute to the development of pelvic organ prolapse.  The vagina is suspended by attachments to the perineum
column10: pelvic side wall and sacrum via attachments that include collagen
column11: elastin
column12: and smooth muscle.  Surgery can be performed to repair pelvic floor muscles.  The pelvic floor muscles can be strengthened with Kegel exercises.

column1: Disorders of the posterior pelvic floor include rectal prolapse
column2: rectocele
column3: perineal hernia
column4: and a number of functional disorders including anismus. Constipation due to any of these disorders is called ""functional constipation"" and is identifiable by clinical diagnostic criteria.

column2: also known as Kegel exercises
column3: may improve the tone and function of the pelvic floor muscles
column4: which is of particular benefit for women (and less commonly men) who experience stress urinary incontinence. However
column5: compliance with PFE programs often is poor
column6: PFE generally is ineffective for urinary incontinence unless performed with biofeedback and trained supervision
column7: and in severe cases it may have no benefit. Pelvic floor muscle tone may be estimated using a perineometer
column8: which measures the pressure within the vagina. Medication may also be used to improve continence. In severe cases
column9: surgery may be used to repair or even to reconstruct the pelvic floor. One surgery which interrupts pelvic floor musculature in males is a radical prostatectomy. With the removal of the prostate
column10: many males experience urinary incontinence post operation; pelvic floor exercises may be used to counteract this pre and post operation. Pre-operative pelvic floor exercising significantly decreases the prevalence of urinary incontinence post radical prostatectomy.  Prostatitis and prostatectomies are two contributors to erectile dysfunction; following a radical prostatectomy studies show that erectile dysfunction is improved by pelvic floor muscle training under the supervision of physical therapists certified in pelvic floor rehabilitation .

column1: Perineology or pelviperineology is a specialty dealing with the functional troubles of the three axes (urological

column2: the talocrural region or the jumping bone (informal) is the area where the foot and the leg meet. The ankle includes three joints: the ankle joint proper or talocrural joint
column3: the subtalar joint
column4: and the inferior tibiofibular joint. The movements produced at this joint are dorsiflexion and plantarflexion of the foot. In common usage
column5: the term ankle refers exclusively to the ankle region. In medical terminology
column6: ""ankle"" (without qualifiers) can refer broadly to the region or specifically to the talocrural joint.

column1: The main bones of the ankle region are the talus (in the foot)
column2: the tibia
column3: and fibula (both in the leg). The talocrural joint is a synovial hinge joint that connects the distal ends of the tibia and fibula in the lower limb with the proximal end of the talus. The articulation between the tibia and the talus bears more weight than that between the smaller fibula and the talus.

column1: The ankle region is found at the junction of the leg and the foot. It extends downwards (distally) from the narrowest point of the lower leg and includes the parts of the foot closer to the body (proximal) to the heel and upper surface (dorsum) of the foot.: 768
The talocrural joint is the only mortise and tenon joint in the human body
column2: : 1418  the term likening the skeletal structure to the woodworking joint of the same name. The bony architecture of the ankle consists of three bones: the tibia
column3: the fibula
column4: and the talus. The articular surface of the tibia may be referred to as the plafond (French for ""ceiling""). The medial malleolus is a bony process extending distally off the medial tibia. The distal-most aspect of the fibula is called the lateral malleolus. Together
column5: the malleoli
column6: along with their supporting ligaments
column7: stabilize the talus underneath the tibia.

column1: Because the motion of the subtalar joint provides a significant contribution to positioning the foot
column2: some authors will describe it as the lower ankle joint
column3: and call the talocrural joint the upper ankle joint. Dorsiflexion and Plantarflexion are the movements that take place in the ankle joint. When the foot is plantar flexed
column4: the ankle joint also allows some movements of side to side gliding
column5: rotation
column6: adduction
column7: and abduction.

column1: The bony arch formed by the tibial plafond and the two malleoli is referred to as the ankle ""mortise"" (or talar mortise). The mortise is a rectangular socket. The ankle is composed of three joints: the talocrural joint (also called talotibial joint
column2: tibiotalar joint
column3: talar mortise

column5: the subtalar joint (also called talocalcaneal)
column6: and the Inferior tibiofibular joint. The joint surface of all bones in the ankle is covered with articular cartilage.

The ankle joint is bound by the strong deltoid ligament and three lateral ligaments: the anterior talofibular ligament

column1: The deltoid ligament supports the medial side of the joint

column1: The anterior and posterior talofibular ligaments support the lateral side of the joint from the lateral malleolus of the fibula to the dorsal and ventral ends of the talus.
The calcaneofibular ligament is attached at the lateral malleolus and to the lateral surface of the calcaneus.
Though it does not span the ankle joint itself
column2: the syndesmotic ligament makes an important contribution to the stability of the ankle. This ligament spans the syndesmosis
column3: i.e. the articulation between the medial aspect of the distal fibula and the lateral aspect of the distal tibia. An isolated injury to this ligament is often called a high ankle sprain.

column1: The bony architecture of the ankle joint is most stable in dorsiflexion. Thus
column2: a sprained ankle is more likely to occur when the ankle is plantar-flexed
column3: as ligamentous support is more important in this position. The classic ankle sprain involves the anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL)
column4: which is also the most commonly injured ligament during inversion sprains. Another ligament that can be injured in a severe ankle sprain is the calcaneofibular ligament.

column1: A number of tendons pass through the ankle region. Bands of connective tissue called retinacula (singular: retinaculum) allow the tendons to exert force across the angle between the leg and foot without lifting away from the angle
column2: a process called bowstringing.

column1: The superior extensor retinaculum of foot extends between the anterior (forward) surfaces of the tibia and fibula near their lower (distal) ends. It contains the anterior tibial artery and vein and the tendons of the tibialis anterior muscle within its tendon sheath and the unsheathed tendons of extensor hallucis longus and extensor digitorum longus muscles. The deep peroneal nerve passes under the retinaculum while the superficial peroneal nerve is outside of it. The inferior extensor retinaculum of foot is a Y-shaped structure. Its lateral attachment is on the calcaneus
column2: and the band travels towards the anterior tibia where it is attached and blends with the superior extensor retinaculum. Along with that course
column3: the band divides and another segment attaches to the plantar aponeurosis. The tendons which pass through the superior extensor retinaculum are all sheathed along their paths through the inferior extensor retinaculum and the tendon of the fibularis tertius muscle is also contained within the retinaculum.

column1: The flexor retinaculum of foot extends from the medial malleolus to the medical process of the calcaneus
column2: and the following structures in order from medial to lateral: the tendon of the tibialis posterior muscle
column3: the tendon of the flexor digitorum longus muscle
column4: the posterior tibial artery and vein
column5: the tibial nerve
column6: and the tendon of the flexor hallucis longus muscle.

column1: The fibular retinacula hold the tendons of the fibularis longus and fibularis brevis along the lateral aspect of the ankle region. The superior fibular retinaculum extends from the deep transverse fascia of the leg and lateral malleolus to calcaneus. The inferior fibular retinaculum is a continuous extension from the inferior extensor retinaculum to the calcaneus.: 1418–9

Mechanoreceptors of the ankle send proprioceptive sensory input to the central nervous system (CNS). Muscle spindles are thought to be the main type of mechanoreceptor responsible for proprioceptive attributes from the ankle. The muscle spindle gives feedback to the CNS system on the current length of the muscle it innervates and to any change in length that occurs.

It was hypothesized that muscle spindle feedback from the ankle dorsiflexors played the most substantial role in proprioception relative to other muscular receptors that cross at the ankle joint. However
column2: due to the multi-planar range of motion at the ankle joint there is not one group of muscles that is responsible for this. This helps to explain the relationship between the ankle and balance.

a relationship between proprioception of the ankle and balance performance was seen in the CNS. This was done by using a fMRI machine in order to see the changes in brain activity when the receptors of the ankle are stimulated. This implicates the ankle directly with the ability to balance. Further research is needed in order to see to what extent does the ankle affect balance.
the role of the ankle in locomotion has been discussed by Aristotle and Leonardo da Vinci. There is no question that ankle push-off is a significant force in human gait
column3: but how much energy is used in leg swing as opposed to advancing the whole-body center of mass is not clear.

column1: The initial evaluation of suspected ankle pathology is usually by projectional radiography (""X-ray"").

column5: and an angle of more than 94 degrees is regarded as talipes valgus.

column2: there are three main landmarks on X-rays: The first is the tibiofibular clear space

column7: the distance between the lateral aspect of the medial malleolus and the medial border of the talus at the level of the talar dome
column8: with a measurement greater than 4 mm being abnormal. Loss of any of these normal anatomic spaces can indirectly reflect ligamentous injury or occult fracture
column9: and can be followed by MRI or CT.

column1: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buttocks|A01.378.610.100|D002081|Buttocks|"The buttocks (sg.: buttock) are two rounded portions of the exterior anatomy of most mammals
column2: located on the posterior of the pelvic region. In humans
column3: the buttocks are located between the lower back and the perineum. They are composed of a layer of exterior skin and underlying subcutaneous fat superimposed on a left and right gluteus maximus and gluteus medius muscles. The two gluteus maximus muscles are the largest muscles in the human body. They are responsible for movements such as straightening the body into the upright (standing) posture when it is bent at the waist; maintaining the body in the upright posture by keeping the hip joints extended; and propelling the body forward via further leg (hip) extension when walking or running.

column2: the buttocks play a role in sexual attraction. Many cultures have also used the buttocks as a primary target for corporal punishment
column3: as the buttocks' layer of subcutaneous fat offers protection against injury while still allowing for the infliction of pain.

column1: The buttocks are formed by the masses of the gluteal muscles or ""glutes"" (the gluteus maximus muscle and the gluteus medius muscle) superimposed by a layer of fat. The superior aspect of the buttock ends at the iliac crest
column2: and the lower aspect is outlined by the horizontal gluteal crease. The gluteus maximus has two insertion points: 1⁄3 superior portion of the linea aspera of the femur
column3: and the superior portion of the iliotibial tractus. The masses of the gluteus maximus muscle are separated by an intermediate intergluteal cleft or ""crack"" in which the anus is situated.

column1: The buttocks allow primates to sit upright without resting their weight on their feet as four-legged animals do. Females of certain species of baboon have red buttocks that blush to attract males. In the case of humans
column2: females tend to have proportionally wider and thicker buttocks due to higher subcutaneous fat and proportionally wider hips. In humans they also have a role in propelling the body in a forward motion and aiding bowel movement.
though otherwise fur-covered
column3: have characteristic naked callosities on their buttocks. While human children generally have smooth buttocks
column4: mature males and females have varying degrees of hair growth
column5: as on other parts of their body. Females may have hair growth in the gluteal cleft (including around the anus)
column6: sometimes extending laterally onto the lower aspect of the cheeks. Males may have hair growth over some or all of the buttocks.

column1: The Latin name for the buttocks is nates (English pronunciation  NAY-teez
column2: classical pronunciation nătes [ˈnateːs]) which is plural; the singular
column3: natis (buttock)
column4: is rarely used. There are many colloquial terms for them.

The capsule of the joint is lax and extends from the inferior sacciform recess to the ulnar shaft.  The DRUJ works with the proximal radioulnar joint (at the elbow) for pronation and supination.

column1: The radiocarpal (wrist) joint is an ellipsoid joint formed by the radius and the articular disc proximally and the proximal row of carpal bones distally. column3: through which some of the flexor tendons pass in tendon sheaths that enable them to slide back and forth through the narrow passageway (see carpal tunnel syndrome).

column1: Starting from the mid-position of the hand

movement towards the thumb) and ulnar deviation (adduction
column3: movement towards the little finger).  These movements take place about a dorsopalmar axis (back to front) at the radiocarpal and midcarpal joints passing through the capitate bone.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inguinal_canal|A01.923.047.412|D007264|Inguinal canal|"The inguinal canal is a passage in the anterior abdominal wall on each side of the body (one on each side of the midline)
column2: which in males
column3: convey the spermatic cords and in females
column4: the round ligament of the uterus. The inguinal canals are larger and more prominent in males.

column1: The inguinal canals are situated just above the medial half of the inguinal ligament. The canals are approximately 4 to 6 cm long
column2: angled anteroinferiorly and medially. In males
column3: its diameter is normally 2 cm (±1 cm in standard deviation) at the deep inguinal ring.

column1: A first-order approximation is to visualize each canal as a cylinder.

column2: these canals are often further approximated as boxes with six sides. Not including the two rings
column3: the remaining four sides are usually called the ""anterior wall""
column4: ""inferior wall (""floor"")""
column5: ""superior wall (""roof"")""
column6: and ""posterior wall"". These consist of the following:

column1: The deep inguinal ring (internal or deep abdominal ring
column2: abdominal inguinal ring
column3: internal inguinal ring
column4: annulus abdominalis) is the entrance to the inguinal canal.

column1: The surface marking of the deep inguinal ring is classically described as half an inch above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament.

column2: the surface anatomy of the point is disputed. In a recent study
column3: it was found to be in a region between the mid-inguinal point (situated midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis) and the midpoint of the inguinal ligament (i.e. midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic tubercle). Traditionally
column4: either one of these two sites was claimed as its location. However
column5: this claim is based upon the study's dissection of 52 cadavers
column6: and may not reflect the live in vivo anatomy.

column1: Some sources state that it is at the layer of the transversalis fascia.
The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia. It is of an oval form
column2: the long axis of the oval being vertical; it varies in size in different subjects
column3: and is much larger in the male than in the female. It is bounded
column4: above and laterally
column5: by the arched lower margin of the transversalis fascia; below and medially
column6: by the inferior epigastric vessels. It transmits the spermatic cord in the male and the round ligament of the uterus in the female.

column2: a thin funnel-shaped membrane
column3: the infundibuliform fascia
column4: is continued around the cord and testis
column5: enclosing them in a distinct covering.

column1: The superficial inguinal ring (subcutaneous inguinal ring or external inguinal ring) is an anatomical structure in the anterior wall of the mammalian abdomen. It is a triangular opening that forms the exit of the inguinal canal
column2: which houses the ilioinguinal nerve
column3: the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
column4: and the spermatic cord (in men) or the round ligament (in women). At the other end of the canal
column5: the deep inguinal ring forms the entrance.

column1: It is found within the aponeurosis of the external oblique
column2: immediately above the pubic crest
column3: 1 centimeter above and superolateral to the pubic tubercle.

column1: It has the following boundaries—medial crura by pubic crest
column2: lateral crura by pubic tubercle and inferiorly by inguinal ligament.

column1: The structures which pass through the canals differ between males and females:
in males: the spermatic cord and its coverings
column2: and the ilioinguinal nerve.

column1: in females: the round ligament of the uterus
column2: and the ilioinguinal nerve.

column1: The classic description of the contents of the spermatic cords in the male are:
3 arteries: artery to vas deferens (or ductus deferens)
column2: testicular artery
column3: cremasteric artery;

column2: cremasteric
column3: and internal spermatic fascia;

column2: vas deferens (ductus deferens)
column3: testicular lymphatics;

column1: 3 nerves: genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (L1/2)
column2: sympathetic and visceral afferent fibres
column3: ilioinguinal nerve (N.B. outside spermatic cord but travels next to it)

column1: Note that the ilioinguinal nerve passes through the superficial ring to descend into the scrotum
column2: but does not formally run through the canal.
each testicle descends from the starting point on the posterior abdominal wall (para-aortically) from the labioscrotal swellings  near the kidneys
column3: down the abdomen
column4: and through the inguinal canals to reach the scrotum. This way
column5: each testicle descends through the abdominal wall into the scrotum behind the processus vaginalis (which later obliterates).

column1: Abdominal contents (potentially including intestine) can be abnormally displaced from the abdominal cavity. Where these contents exit through the inguinal canal
column2: having passed through the deep inguinal ring
column3: the condition is known as an indirect or oblique inguinal hernia. This can also cause infertility. This condition is far more common in males than in females
column4: owing to the inguinal canal's small size in females.

column1: A hernia that exits the abdominal cavity directly through the deep layers of the abdominal wall
column2: thereby bypassing the inguinal canal
column3: is known as a direct inguinal hernia.

column1: In males with strong presentation of the cremasteric reflex
column2: the testes can—during supine sexual activity or manual manipulation—partially or fully retract into the inguinal canal for a short period of time. In juveniles and adults with inguinal injury
column3: retraction can be prolonged and potentially lead to overheating-related infertility.

column1: The superficial ring is palpable under normal conditions. It becomes dilated in a condition called athletic pubalgia. Abdominal contents may protrude through the ring in inguinal hernia.
Thus lymphatic spread from a testicular tumour is to the para-aortic nodes first
column2: and not the inguinal nodes.
