column1: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greater_omentum|A01.923.047.025.600.573|D009852|Greater omentum|"The greater omentum (also the great omentum
column2: omentum majus
column3: gastrocolic omentum
column4: epiploon
column5: or
column6: especially in non-human animals
column7: caul) is a large apron-like fold of visceral peritoneum that hangs down from the stomach. It extends from the greater curvature of the stomach
column8: passing in front of the small intestines and doubles back to ascend to the transverse colon before reaching to the posterior abdominal wall.  The greater omentum is larger than the lesser omentum
column9: which hangs down from the liver to the lesser curvature. The common anatomical term ""epiploic"" derives from ""epiploon""
column10: from the Greek epipleein
column11: meaning to float or sail on
column12: since the greater omentum appears to float on the surface of the intestines. It is the first structure observed when the abdominal cavity is opened anteriorly (from the front).

column1: The greater omentum is the larger of the two peritoneal folds. It consists of a double sheet of peritoneum
column2: folded on itself so that it has four layers.

column1: The two layers of the greater omentum descend from the greater curvature of the stomach and the beginning of the duodenum. They pass in front of the small intestines
column2: sometimes as low as the pelvis
column3: before turning on themselves
column4: and ascending as far as the transverse colon
column5: where they separate and enclose that part of the intestine.

column1: These individual layers are easily seen in the young
column2: but in the adult they are more or less inseparably blended.

column1: The left border of the greater omentum is continuous with the gastrosplenic ligament; its right border extends as far as the beginning of the duodenum.
The greater omentum is usually thin
column2: and has a perforated appearance. It contains some adipose tissue
column3: which can accumulate considerably in obese people. It is highly vascularised.

column1: The greater omentum is often defined to encompass a variety of structures. Most sources include the following three:
Gastrophrenic ligament—extends to the underside of the left dome of the diaphragm
Gastrocolic ligament—extends to the transverse colon (occasionally on its own considered synonymous with ""greater omentum"")
Gastrosplenic ligament (or Gastrolienal) ligament)— extends to the spleen
column2: overlying the kidney

column1: The splenorenal ligament (or lienorenal ligament) (from the left kidney to the spleen) is occasionally considered part of the greater omentum. It is derived from the peritoneum
column2: where the wall of the general peritoneal cavity comes into contact with the lesser sac between the left kidney and the spleen; the splenic artery and vein pass between its two layers. It contains the tail of the pancreas
column3: the only intraperitoneal portion of the pancreas
column4: and splenic vessels. One or more of the preceding sentences incorporates text in the public domain from  the 20th edition of Gray's Anatomy (1918)

column1: The phrenosplenic ligament (lienophrenic ligament or phrenicolienal ligament) is a double fold of peritoneum that connects the thoracic diaphragm and spleen.
The phrenicosplenic ligament is part of the greater omentum. Distinctions between the phrenicosplenic ligament and adjacent ligaments
column2: such as the gastrophrenic
column3: gastrosplenic and splenorenal ligaments
column4: which are all part of the same mesenteric sheet
column5: are often nebulous.

column1: The right and left gastroepiploic arteries (also known as gastroomental) provide the sole blood supply to the greater omentum. Both are branches  of the celiac trunk. The right gastroepiploic artery is a branch of the gastroduodenal artery
column2: which is a branch of the common hepatic artery
column3: which is a branch of the celiac trunk. The left gastroepiploic artery is the largest branch of the splenic artery
column4: which is a branch of the celiac trunk. The right and left gastroepiploic arteries anastomose within the two layers of the anterior greater omentum along the greater curvature of the stomach.

column1: The greater omentum develops from the dorsal mesentery that connects the stomach to the posterior abdominal wall. During its development
column2: the stomach undergoes its first 90° rotation along the axis of the embryo
column3: so that posterior structures are moved to the left and structures anterior to the stomach are shifted to the right. As a result
column4: the dorsal mesentery folds over on itself
column5: forming a pouch with its blind end on the left side of the embryo. A second approximately 90° rotation of the stomach
column6: this time in the frontal plane
column7: moves structures inferior if they were originally to the left of the stomach
column8: and superior if they were originally to the stomach's right. Consequently
column9: the blind-ended sac (also called the lesser sac) formed by the dorsal mesentery is brought inferiorly
column10: where it assumes its final position as the greater omentum. It grows to the point that it covers the majority of the small and large intestine.

column1: The functions of the greater omentum are:

column2: having varying amounts of adipose tissue
having milky spots of macrophage collections

column1: Infection and wound isolation; It may also physically limit the spread of intraperitoneal infections. The greater omentum can often be found wrapped around areas of infection and trauma.
Omentectomy refers to the surgical removal of the omentum
column2: a relatively simple procedure with no documented major side effects
column3: that is performed in cases where there is concern that there may be spread of cancerous tissue into the omentum. Examples for this are ovarian cancer and advanced or aggressive endometrial cancer as well as intestinal cancer and also appendix cancer. The procedure is generally done as an add-on when the primary lesion is removed.

column1: The greater omentum may be surgically harvested for reconstruction of the thoracic wall. It has also been used experimentally to reinforce bioengineered tissues transplanted to the surface of the heart for cardiac regeneration.
The greater omentum may be surgically harvested to provide revascularization of brain tissue after a stroke.
The greater omentum is also known as the great omentum
column2: the omentum majus
column3: the gastrocolic omentum
column4: the epiploon
column5: and the caul.

column2: the greater omentum was described as the ""abdominal policeman"" by the surgeon James Rutherford Morrison. This is due to its immunological function
column3: whereby omental tissue seems to ""surveil"" the abdomen for infection and cover areas of infection when found - walling it off with immunologically active tissue.

column2: the arm refers to the upper limb in common usage
column3: although academically the term specifically means the upper arm between the glenohumeral joint (shoulder joint) and the elbow joint. The distal part of the upper limb between the elbow and the radiocarpal joint (wrist joint) is known as the forearm or ""lower"" arm

column7: which serves as a root word for naming many anatomical structures
column8: may refer to either the upper limb as a whole or to the upper arm on its own.

column1: The humerus is one of the three long bones of the arm. It joins with the scapula at the shoulder joint and with the other long bones of the arm
column2: the ulna and radius at the elbow joint. The elbow is a complex hinge joint between the end of the humerus and the ends of the radius and ulna.

column1: The arm is divided by a fascial layer (known as lateral and medial intermuscular septa) separating the muscles into two osteofascial compartments: the anterior and the posterior compartments of the arm. The fascia merges with the periosteum (outer bone layer) of the humerus.
The anterior compartment contains three muscles: biceps brachii
column2: brachialis and coracobrachialis muscles. They are all innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve. The posterior compartment contains only the triceps brachii muscle
column3: supplied by the radial nerve.

column2: from C5
column3: C6
column4: C7
column5: is the main supplier of muscles of the anterior compartment. It originates from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus of nerves. It pierces the coracobrachialis muscle and gives off branches to the muscle
column6: as well as to brachialis and biceps brachii. It terminates as the anterior cutaneous nerve of the forearm.

column2: which is from the fifth cervical spinal nerve to the first thoracic spinal nerve
column3: originates as the continuation of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. This nerve enters the lower triangular space (an imaginary space bounded by
column4: amongst others
column5: the shaft of the humerus and the triceps brachii) of the arm and lies deep to the triceps brachii. Here it travels with the deep artery of the arm
column6: which sits in the radial groove of the humerus. This fact is very important clinically as a fracture of the shaft of the bone here can cause lesions or even transections in the nerve.

column1: Other nerves passing through give no supply to the arm. These include:

column2: nerve origin C5-T1
column3: which is a branch of the lateral and medial cords of the brachial plexus. This nerve continues in the arm
column4: travelling in a plane between the biceps and triceps muscles. At the cubital fossa
column5: this nerve is deep to the pronator teres muscle and is the most medial structure in the fossa. The nerve passes into the forearm.

column2: origin C8-T1
column3: is a continuation of the medial cord of the brachial plexus. This nerve passes in the same plane as the median nerve
column4: between the biceps and triceps muscles. At the elbow
column5: this nerve travels posterior to the medial epicondyle of the humerus. This means that condylar fractures can cause lesion to this nerve.

column1: The main artery in the arm is the brachial artery. This artery is a continuation of the axillary artery. The point at which the axillary becomes the brachial is distal to the lower border of teres major. The brachial artery gives off an unimportant branch
column2: the deep artery of arm. This branching occurs just below the lower border of teres major.

column1: The brachial artery continues to the cubital fossa in the anterior compartment of the arm. It travels in a plane between the biceps and triceps muscles
column2: the same as the median nerve and basilic vein. It is accompanied by venae comitantes (accompanying veins). It gives branches to the muscles of the anterior compartment. The artery is in between the median nerve and the tendon of the biceps muscle in the cubital fossa. It then continues into the forearm.

column1: The deep artery of the arm travels through the lower triangular space with the radial nerve. From here onwards it has an intimate relationship with the radial nerve. They are both found deep to the triceps muscle and are located on the spiral groove of the humerus. Therefore
column2: fracture of the bone may not only lead to lesion of the radial nerve
column3: but also haematoma of the internal structures of the arm. The artery then continues on to anastamose with the recurrent radial branch of the brachial artery
column4: providing a diffuse blood supply for the elbow joint.

column1: The veins of the arm carry blood from the extremities of the limb
column2: as well as drain the arm itself. The two main veins are the basilic and the cephalic veins. There is a connecting vein between the two
column3: the median cubital vein
column4: which passes through the cubital fossa and is clinically important for venepuncture (withdrawing blood).

column1: The basilic vein travels on the medial side of the arm and terminates at the level of the seventh rib.
The cephalic vein travels on the lateral side of the arm and terminates as the axillary vein. It passes through the deltopectoral triangle
column2: a space between the deltoid and the pectoralis major muscles.

Buddhist and Egyptian iconography the symbol of the arm is used to illustrate the power of the sovereign. In Hindu tradition gods are depicted with several arms which carry specific symbols of their powers. It is believed that several arms depict omnipotence of gods. In popular culture Thakur did not have arms in the movie Sholay.
the Bambara use forearm to symbolize the spirit
column3: which is a link between God and man.

column1: Symbolic gestures of raising both hands signal surrender
column2: appeals for mercy
column3: and justice.

column1: The cubital fossa is clinically important for venepuncture and for blood pressure measurement.
When the arm is fractured this may refer to a fracture of the humerus bone.
Veins on the arm may be taken when a coronary artery bypass graft is needed.

column2: the term arm can also be used for homologous or analogous  structures (such as one of the paired forelimbs of a four-legged animal or the arms of cephalopods
column3: respectively). In anatomical usage
column4: the term arm may sometimes refer specifically to the segment between the shoulder and the elbow
column5: while the segment between the elbow and wrist is the forearm. However
column6: in common
column7: literary
column8: and historical usage
column9: arm refers to the entire upper limb from shoulder to wrist. This article uses the former definition; see upper limb for the wider definition.

column2: the arm is adapted for precise positioning of the hand and thus assist in the hand's manipulative tasks. The ball and socket shoulder joint allows for movement of the arms in a wide circular plane
column3: while the structure of the two forearm bones which can rotate around each other allows for additional range of motion at that level.

column2: underarm  or oxter) is the area on the human body directly under the shoulder joint. It includes the axillary space

column1: The soft skin covering the lateral axilla contains many hair and sweat glands. In humans
column2: the formation of body odor happens mostly in the axilla. These odorant substances have been suggested by some to serve as pheromones
column3: which play a role related to mate selection
column4: although this is a controversial topic within the scientific community. The underarms seem more important than the pubic area for emitting body odor
column5: which may be related to human bipedalism.

column2: the boundaries of the axilla are:

column1: The lower posterior boundary is called the posterior axillary fold and this is a compound structure consisting of the latissimus dorsi and teres major muscles. It can descend after weight loss.
The anterior boundary is called the anterior axillary fold and this is rounded in shape and formed by the lower border of the pectoralis major.
Some sources also include the pectoralis minor. It can elongate after weight loss.
The contents of the axilla include the axillary vein and artery
column2: as well as the brachial plexus
column3: lymph nodes and fat.

column1: The axilla is the space between the side of the thorax and the upper arm.
Infraclavicular part of the brachial plexus
Five groups of axillary lymph nodes and the associated lymphatics
Axillary fat and areolar tissue in which the other contents are embedded
The term ""underarm"" typically refers to the outer surface of the axilla. However
column2: the terms are sometimes used interchangeably in casual contexts. Colloquially
column3: underarm  refers to the hollow beneath the junction of the arm and shoulder.

column1: The underarm is a ticklish area due to the number of nerves it contains. Most people find this area to be particularly unpleasant when tickled.
Underarm hair usually grows in the underarms of both females and males
column2: beginning in adolescence.
it is common for women to remove underarm hair. Some view this practice as an aesthetic matter
column3: while others view its removal for health-related concerns. As underarm hair grows quickly
column4: removal must be performed frequently
column5: or stubble will appear in the axilla.

column2: the hippie culture
column3: and in the punk rock scene
column4: some women retain their underarm hair for a variety of reasons
column5: from subversion to egalitarianism to comfort. Conversely but uncommonly
column6: some men choose to remove their underarm hair for aesthetic reasons or to reduce friction in sports such as swimming.

column4: it is an area where blood vessels and nerves pass relatively superficially

column1: Breast cancer typically spreads via lymphatic vessels to the lymph nodes found in the axilla.

Excessive perspiration without adequate  air circulation can result in axillary intertrigo. Intertrigo is an inflammatory skin condition of skin folds exposed to friction or maceration in the presence of heat and moisture. Intertrigo is worsened by infection
column2: usually fungal (Candida yeast species)
column3: but also bacterial or viral; warm
column4: wet underarms promote those growths. The condition results in rash-like symptoms
column5: pustules
column6: or chronic itching or burning in the underarm. Intertrigo (in any site) has no racial or sexual predilection.  Axillary intertrigo is common among those who work in hot environments where air circulation is restricted by necessary clothing or safety equipment.

column2: the thigh is the area between the hip (pelvis) and the knee. Anatomically
column3: it is part of the lower limb.

column1: The single bone in the thigh is called the femur. This bone is very thick and strong (due to the high proportion of bone tissue)
column2: and forms a ball and socket joint at the hip
column3: and a modified hinge joint at the knee.

column1: The femur is the only bone in the thigh and serves as an attachment site for all muscles in the thigh. The head of the femur articulates with the acetabulum in the pelvic bone forming the hip joint
column2: while the distal part of the femur articulates with the tibia and patella forming the knee. By most measures
column3: the femur is the strongest bone in the body. The femur is also the longest bone in the body.

column1: The femur is categorised as a long bone and comprises a diaphysis
column2: the shaft (or body) and two epiphyses
column3: the lower extremity and the upper extremity of femur
column4: that articulate with adjacent bones in the hip and knee.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perineum|A01.719|D010502|Perineum|"The perineum (pl.: perineums or perinea) in mammals is the space between the anus and the genitals. The human perineum is between the anus and scrotum in the male or between the anus and vulva in the female. The perineum is the region of the body between the pubic symphysis (pubic arch) and the coccyx (tail bone)
column2: including the perineal body and surrounding structures. The perineal raphe is visible and pronounced to varying degrees. The perineum is an erogenous zone. This area is also known as the taint or gooch in American slang.

column1: The word entered English from late Latin via Greek περίναιος ~ περίνεος perinaios
column2: perineos
column3: itself from περίνεος
column4: περίνεοι 'male genitals' and earlier περίς perís 'penis' through influence from πηρίς pērís 'scrotum'. The term was originally understood as a purely male body-part with the perineal raphe seen as a continuation of the scrotal septum since masculinization causes the development of a large anogenital distance in men
column5: in comparison to the corresponding lack of distance in women. As a result of folk etymologies (such as ἰνάω ináō
column6: ""to carry off by evacuations"")
column7: it is contemporaneously extended to both sexes.

column1: The perineum is generally defined as the surface region between the pubic symphysis and the coccyx. The perineum is below the pelvic diaphragm and between the legs. It is a diamond-shaped area that includes the anus and
column2: in females
column3: the vagina. Its definition varies: it can refer to only the superficial structures in this region
column4: or it can be used to include both superficial and deep structures. The perineum corresponds to the outlet of the pelvis.

column1: A line drawn across the surface connecting the ischial tuberosities divides the space into two triangles:
The anterior urogenital triangle contains the penis and scrotum (males) or vulva (females)
The posterior anal triangle contains the anus
The formal anatomical boundaries of the perineum may be said to be:
in front: the pubic arch and the arcuate ligament of the pubis
behind: the tip of the coccyx
on either side: the inferior rami of the pubis and ischial tuberosity
column2: and the sacrotuberous ligament

column1: The perineal body (or central tendon of perineum) is a pyramidal fibromuscular mass in the middle line of the perineum at the junction between the urogenital triangle and the anal triangle. In males
column2: it is found between the bulb of the penis and the anus; in females
column3: it is found between the vagina and anus
column4: and about 1.25 cm (0.49 in) in front of the latter.

column1: The perineal body is essential for the integrity of the pelvic floor
column2: particularly in females. Its rupture during vaginal birth leads to widening of the gap between the anterior free borders of levator ani muscle of both sides
column3: thus predisposing the woman to prolapse of the uterus
column4: rectum
column5: or even the urinary bladder. Perineal tears and episiotomy often occur in childbirth with first-time deliveries
column6: but the risk of these injuries can be reduced by preparing the perineum
column7: often through massage.

column2: the following muscles converge and are attached:

column1: Anterior fibers of the levator ani
Fibers from male or female external urinary sphincter
The terminology of the perineal fascia can be confusing
column2: and there is some controversy over the nomenclature. This stems from the fact that there are two parts to the fascia
column3: the superficial and deep parts
column4: and each of these can be subdivided into superficial and deep parts.

column1: The layers and contents are as follows
column2: from superficial to deep:

column1: The region of the perineum can be considered a distinct area from pelvic cavity
column2: with the two regions separated by the pelvic diaphragm. The perianal area (peri- and anal) is a subset of the perineum. The following areas are thus classified as parts of the perineal region:

column1: perineal pouches: superficial and deep (see above for details)
ischioanal fossa – a fat-filled space at the lateral sides of anal canal
column2: bounded laterally by the obturator internus muscle
column3: and medially by the pelvic diaphragm and anal canal; its base is the skin

column1: pudendal canal – contains internal pudendal artery and the pudendal nerve

The anogenital distance is a measure of the distance between the midpoint of the anus and the underside of the scrotum or the vagina. Studies show that the human perineum is twice as long in males as in females. Measuring the anogenital distance in neonatal humans has been suggested as a noninvasive method to determine male feminisation and thereby predict neonatal and adult reproductive disorders.

Extensive deformation of the pelvic floor occurs during a vaginal delivery. Approximately 85% of women have some perineal tear during a vaginal delivery and in about 69% suturing is required. Obstetric perineal trauma contributes to postpartum morbidity and frustration of women after delivery. In many women the childbirth trauma is manifested in advanced age when the compensatory mechanisms of the pelvic floor become weakened making the problem more serious among the aged population.
There are claims that sometimes the perineum is excessively repaired after childbirth
column2: using a so-called ""husband stitch"" and that this can increase vaginal tightness or result in pain during intercourse.

column1: Perineum sunning is a wellness practice that involves exposing the perineum (area between the genitals and anus) to sunlight. Adherents claim various unproven health benefits such as improved libido
column2: circulation
column3: sleep
column4: and longevity. There is no scientific evidence that this behavior promotes any of the alleged benefits. The practice of exposing a sensitive area of skin to sunlight also increases the risk of skin cancers such as melanoma
column5: squamous cell carcinoma
column6: and basal-cell carcinoma. Doctors recommend safer alternative options such as relaxation
column7: meditation
column8: and mindfulness
column9: which can also achieve the same desired benefits.

column1: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scalp|A01.456.810|D012535|Scalp|"The scalp is the area of the head where head hair grows. It is made up of skin
column2: layers of connective and fibrous tissues
column3: and the membrane of the skull. Anatomically
column4: the scalp is part of the epicranium
column5: a collection of structures covering the cranium. The scalp is bordered by the face at the front
column6: and by the neck at the sides and back. The scientific study of hair and scalp is called trichology.

column1: The scalp is usually described as having five layers
column2: which can be remembered using the mnemonic 'SCALP':

column1: S: Skin. The skin of the scalp contains numerous hair follicles and sebaceous glands.
C: Connective tissue. A dense subcutaneous layer of fat and fibrous tissue that lies beneath the skin
column2: containing the nerves and vessels of the scalp.

column1: A: Aponeurosis. The epicranial aponeurosis or galea aponeurotica is a tough layer of dense fibrous tissue which anchors the above layers in place. It runs from the frontalis muscle anteriorly to the occipitalis posteriorly.
L: Loose areolar connective tissue. This layer has a gel-like consistency
column2: and allows the more superficial layers of the scalp to shift about in relation to the pericranium. It is constituted of more matrix than fibers. It contains random collagen I bundles
column3: collagen III and is rich in glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). In craniofacial surgery and neurosurgery this layer provides an easy plane of separation between the upper three layers and the pericranium. In scalping the scalp is also torn off through this layer. The layer is sometimes referred to as the ""danger zone"" because infectious agents can easily spread through it to emissary veins which drain into the cranium.

column1: P: Pericranium. This is the periosteum of the skull bones
column2: a membrane that provides nutrition to the bone and the capacity for repair. During surgery it can be lifted from the bone to allow the removal of windows of bone (craniotomy).

column1: The blood supply of the scalp is via five pairs of arteries
column2: three from the external carotid and two from the internal carotid:

column1: the supratrochlear artery to the midline forehead. The supratrochlear artery is a branch of the ophthalmic branch of the internal carotid artery.
the supraorbital artery to the lateral forehead and scalp as far up as the vertex. The supraorbital artery is a branch of the ophthalmic branch of the internal carotid artery.
the superficial temporal artery gives off frontal and parietal branches to supply much of the scalp
the occipital artery which runs posteriorly to supply much of the posterior aspect of the scalp

column2: a branch of the external carotid artery
column3: ascends behind the auricle to supply the scalp above and behind the auricle.

column1: Because the walls of the blood vessels are firmly attached to the fibrous tissue of the superficial fascial layer
column2: cut ends of vessels here do not readily retract; even a small scalp wound may bleed profusely.

column1: The veins of the scalp accompany the arteries and thus have similar names
column2: e.g. Supratrochlear and supraorbital veins
column3: which unite at the medial angle of the eye
column4: and form the angular vein
column5: which further continues as the facial vein.

column1: The superficial temporal vein descends in front of the tragus
column2: enters the parotid gland
column3: and then joins the maxillary vein to form the retromandibular vein. The anterior part of it unites with the facial vein to form the common facial vein
column4: which drains into jugular vein
column5: and ultimately to the subclavian vein. The occipital vein terminates to the sub-occipital plexus.

column2: like the emissary vein and frontal diploic vein
column3: which also contribute to the venous drainage.

column1: Innervation is the connection of nerves to the scalp: the sensory and motor nerves innervating the scalp. The scalp is innervated by the following:
Supratrochlear nerve and the supraorbital nerve from the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve
Greater occipital nerve (C2) posteriorly up to the vertex
Lesser occipital nerve (C2) behind the ear
Zygomaticotemporal nerve from the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve supplying the hairless temple
Auriculotemporal nerve from the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve
The innervation of scalp can be remembered using the mnemonic 'Z-GLASS' for Zygomaticotemporal nerve
column2: Greater occipital nerve
column3: Lesser occipital nerve
column4: Auriculotemporal nerve
column5: Supratrochlear nerve
column6: and Supraorbital nerve.

column1: The motor innervation of the scalp
column2: specifically
column3: the occipitofrontalis muscle
column4: is split into two main factions: the frontal belly or frontalis muscle is supplied by the temporal branch of facial nerve
column5: while the occipital belly or occipitalis is supplied by the posterior auricular branch of facial nerve.

column1: Lymphatic channels from the posterior half of the scalp drain to occipital and posterior auricular nodes. Lymphatic channels from the anterior half drain to the parotid nodes. The lymph eventually reaches the submandibular and deep cervical nodes.
The 'danger area of the scalp' is the area of loose connective tissue. This is because pus and blood spread easily within it
column2: and can pass into the cranial cavity along the emissary veins. Therefore
column3: infection can spread from the scalp to the meninges
column4: which could lead to meningitis.

column1: The clinically important layer is the aponeurosis. Scalp lacerations through this layer mean that the ""anchoring"" of the superficial layers is lost and gaping of the wound occurs which would require suturing. This can be achieved with simple or vertical mattress sutures using a non-absorbable material
column2: which are subsequently removed at around days 7–10.

column1: All the current hair transplantation techniques utilize the patient's existing hair. The aim of the surgical procedure is to use such hair as efficiently as possible. The right candidates for this type of surgery are individuals who still have healthy hair on the sides and the back of the head in order that hair for the transplant may be harvested from those areas. Different techniques are utilized in order to obtain the desired cosmetic results; factors considered may include hair color
column2: texture
column3: curliness
column4: etc.

column1: The most utilized technique is the one known as micro grafting because it produces naturalistic results. It is akin to follicular unit extraction
column2: although less advanced. A knife with multiple blades is used to remove tissue from donor areas. The removed tissue is then fragmented into smaller chunks under direct vision inspection (i.e.
column3: without a microscope).

column1: The scalp is a common site for the development of tumours including:
Dandruff – a common problem caused by excessive shedding of dead skin cells from the scalp
Seborrhoeic dermatitis – a skin disorder causing scaly
column2: flaky
column3: itchy
column4: red skin

column1: Cradle cap – a form of seborrhoeic dermatitis which occurs in newborns
Tinea capitis - ringworm of the scalp
column2: and its severe form Favus

column1: Cutis verticis gyrata – a rare deformity of the scalp
The scalp plays an important role in the aesthetics of the face. Androgenic alopecia
column2: or male pattern hair loss
column3: is a common cause of concern to men. It may be treated with varying rates success by medication (e.g. finasteride
column4: minoxidil) or hair transplantation. If the scalp is heavy and loose
column5: a common change with ageing
column6: the forehead may be low
column7: heavy and deeply lined. The brow lift procedure aims to address these concerns.

column1: Scalping is the act of removing a human scalp
column2: usually with hair
column3: as a trophy. Often associated with the history of North America
column4: scalping developed independently on multiple continents and dates back to antiquity.

column1: Scalp reconstruction – surgery to correct scalp defects of injuries
Scalp reduction – surgery to reduce the size of bald spots

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nipple|A01.236.500|D009558|Nipple|"The nipple is a raised region of tissue on the surface of the breast from which
column2: in females
column3: milk leaves the breast through the lactiferous ducts to breastfeed an infant. The milk can flow through the nipple passively or it can be ejected by smooth muscle contractions that occur along with the ductal system. Male mammals also have nipples but without the same level of function
column4: and often surrounded by body hair.

column1: The nipple is surrounded by the areola
column2: which is often a darker colour than the surrounding skin.  A nipple is often called a teat when referring to non-humans. ""Nipple"" or ""teat"" can also be used to describe the flexible mouthpiece of a baby bottle. In humans
column3: the nipples of both males and females can be sexually stimulated as part of sexual arousal. In many cultures
column4: human female nipples are sexualized
column5: or regarded as sex objects and evaluated in terms of their physical characteristics and sex appeal. Some cultures have little to no sexualization of the nipple
column6: and going topless presents no barrier.

column1: The word ""nipple"" most likely originates as a diminutive of neb
column2: an Old English word meaning ""beak""
column3: ""nose""
column4: or ""face""
column5: and which is of Germanic origin. The words ""teat"" and ""tit"" share a Germanic ancestor. The second of the two
column6: tit
column7: was inherited directly from Proto-Germanic
column8: while the first entered English via Old French.

column2: a nipple (also called mammary papilla or teat) is a small projection of skin containing the outlets for 15–20 lactiferous ducts arranged cylindrically around the tip. Marsupials and eutherian mammals typically have an even number of nipples arranged bilaterally
column3: from as few as 2 to as many as 19.

column1: The skin of the nipple is rich in a supply of special nerves that are sensitive to certain stimuli: these are slowly-adapting and rapidly-adapting cutaneous mechanoreceptors. Mechanoreceptors are identified respectively by Type I slowly-adapting with multiple Merkel corpuscle end-organs and Type II slowly-adapting with single Ruffini corpuscle end-organs
column2: as well as Type I rapidly-adapting with multiple Meissner corpuscle end-organs and Type II rapidly-adapting with single Pacinian corpuscle end-organs. The dominant nerve supply to the nipple comes from the lateral cutaneous branches of fourth intercostal nerve. The nipple is also used as an anatomical landmark. It marks the T4 (fourth thoracic vertebra) dermatome and rests over the approximate level of the diaphragm.

column1: The arterial supply to the nipple and breast originates from the anterior intercostal branches of the internal thoracic (mammary) arteries; lateral thoracic artery; and thoracodorsal arteries. The venous vessels parallel the arteries. The lymphatic ducts that drain the nipple are the same for the breast. The axillary nodes are the apical axillary nodes
column2: the lateral group and the anterior group. 75% of the lymph is drained through the axillary lymph nodes located near the armpit. The rest of the drainage leaves the nipple and breast through infroclavicular
column3: pectoral
column4: or parasternal nodes.

column1: Since nipples change throughout the life span in men and women
column2: the anatomy of the nipple can change and this change may be expected and considered normal.

column1: Almost all mammals have nipples. Why males have nipples has been the subject of scientific research.  Differences among the sexes (called sexual dimorphism) within a given species are considered by evolutionary biologists to be mostly the result of sexual selection
column2: directly or indirectly. There is a consensus that the male nipple exists because there is no particular advantage to males losing the trait. Some biologists would call the male nipple a spandrel).

column1: The physiological purpose of nipples is to deliver milk
column2: produced in the female mammary glands during lactation
column3: to an infant. During breastfeeding
column4: nipple stimulation by an infant will stimulate the release of oxytocin from the hypothalamus. Oxytocin is a hormone that increases during pregnancy and acts on the breast to help produce the milk-ejection reflex. Oxytocin release from the nipple stimulation of the infant causes the uterus to contract even after childbirth. The strong uterine contractions that are caused by the stimulation of the mother's nipples help the uterus contract to clamp down the uterine arteries. These contractions are necessary to prevent post-partum haemorrhage.

column1: When the infant suckles or stimulates the nipple
column2: oxytocin levels rise and small muscles in the breast contract
column3: moving the milk through the milk ducts. The result of nipple stimulation by the infant helps to move breast milk out through the ducts and to the nipple. This contraction of milk is called the ""let-down reflex"". Latching on refers to the infant fastening onto the nipple to breastfeed. A good attachment is when the bottom of the areola (the area around the nipple) is in the infant's mouth and the nipple is drawn back inside his or her mouth. A poor latch results in insufficient nipple stimulation to create the let down reflex. The nipple is poorly stimulated when the baby latches on too close to the tip of the nipple. This poor attachment can cause sore and cracked nipples and a reluctance of the mother to continue to breastfeed. After birth
column4: the milk supply increases based upon the continuous and increasing stimulation of the nipple by the infant. If the baby increases nursing time at the nipple
column5: the mammary glands respond to this stimulation by increasing milk production.

column1: Nipple pain can be a disincentive for breastfeeding. Sore nipples that progress to cracked nipples is of concern since many women cease breastfeeding due to the pain. In some instances
column2: an ulcer will form on the nipple. One reason for the development of cracked and sore nipples is the incorrect latching-on of the infant to the nipple. If a nipple appears to be wedge-shaped
column3: white and flattened
column4: this may indicate that the attachment of the infant is not good and there is a potential of developing cracked nipples. Herpes infection of the nipple is painful. Nipple pain can also be caused by excessive friction of clothing against the nipple that causes a fissure.

column1: Nipple discharge refers to any fluid that seeps out of the nipple of the breast. Discharge from the nipple does not occur in lactating women. And discharge in non-pregnant women or women who are not breastfeeding may not cause concern. Men that have discharge from their nipples are not typical. Discharge from the nipples of men or boys may indicate a problem.  Discharge from the nipples can appear without squeezing or may only be noticeable if the nipples are squeezed. One nipple can have discharge while the other does not. The discharge can be clear
column2: green
column3: bloody
column4: brown or straw-coloured. The consistency can be thick
column5: thin
column6: sticky or watery.

column1: Some cases of nipple discharge will clear on their own without treatment. Nipple discharge is most often not cancer (benign)
column2: but rarely
column3: it can be a sign of breast cancer. It is important to determine what is causing the discharge and to get treatment. Reasons for nipple discharge include:

column1: Rubbing on the area from a bra or T-shirt
Inflammation and clogging of the breast ducts
Small growth in the breast (usually not cancer)
Fibrocystic breast (normal lumpiness in the breast)

column2: such as anise and fennel

babies can have nipple discharge. This is caused by hormones from the mother before birth. It usually goes away in two weeks. Cancers such as Paget's disease (a rare type of cancer involving the skin of the nipple) can also cause nipple discharge.

column1: Nipple discharge that is not normal is bloody
column2: comes from only one nipple
column3: or comes out on its own without squeezing or touching the nipple. Nipple discharge is more likely to be normal if it comes out of both nipples or happens when the nipples are squeezed. Squeezing the nipple to check for discharge can make it worse. Leaving the nipple alone may make the discharge stop.

column1: Nipple discharge in a male is usually of more concern. Most of the time a mammogram and an examination of the fluid is done. A biopsy is often performed. A fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy can be fast and least painful. A very thin
column2: hollow needle and slight suction will be used to remove a small sample from under the nipple. Using a local anesthetic to numb the skin may not be necessary since a thin needle is used for the biopsy. Receiving an injection to prevent pain from the biopsy may be more painful than the biopsy itself.

column1: Some men develop a condition known as gynecomastia
column2: in which the breast tissue under the nipple develops and grows. Discharge from the nipple can occur. The nipple may swell in some men possibly due to increased levels of estrogen.

column1: Changes in appearance may be normal or related to disease.
Inverted nipples – This is normal if the nipples have always been indented inward and can easily point out when touched. If the nipples are pointing in and this is new
column2: this is an unexpected change.

column1: Skin puckering of the nipple – This can be caused by scar tissue from surgery or an infection. Often
column2: scar tissue forms for no reason. Most of the time this issue does not need treatment. This is an unexpected change. This change can be of concern since puckering or retraction of the nipple can indicate an underlying change in breast tissue that may be cancerous.

column1: The nipple is warm to the touch
column2: red or painful – This can be an infection. It is rarely due to breast cancer.
flaking
column3: or itchy nipple – This is most often due to eczema or a bacterial or fungal infection. This change is not expected. Flaking
column4: scaly
column5: or itchy nipples can be a sign of Paget's disease.

column1: Thickened skin with large pores – This is called peau d'orange because the skin looks like an orange peel. An infection in the breast or inflammatory breast cancer can cause this problem. This is not an expected change.
Retracted nipples – The nipple was raised above the surface but changes
column2: begins to pull inward
column3: and does not come out when stimulated.

column1: The average projection and size of human female nipples is slightly more than 3⁄8 inch (9.5 mm).
Symptoms of breast cancer can often be seen first by changes of the nipple and areola
column2: although not all women have the same symptoms
column3: and some people do not have any signs or symptoms at all. A person may find out they have breast cancer after a routine mammogram.

column2: or breast or armpit

column1: Thickening or swelling of part of the breast
column2: areola
column3: or nipple

column1: Irritation or dimpling of breast skin
Redness or flaky skin in the nipple area or the breast
Pulling in of the nipple or pain in the nipple area
Nipple discharge other than breast milk
column2: including blood

column1: Any change in the size or the shape of the breast or nipple
Pain in any area of the breast
Changes in the nipple are not necessarily symptoms or signs of breast cancer. Other conditions of the nipple can mimic the signs and symptoms of breast cancer.
Some infections are transmitted through the nipple
column2: especially if irritation or injury to the nipple has occurred. In these circumstances
column3: the nipple itself can become infected with Candida that is present in the mouth of the breastfeeding infant. The infant will transmit the infection to the mother. Most of the time
column4: this infection is localized to the area of the nipple. In some cases
column5: the infection can progress to become a full-blown case of mastitis or breast infection. In some cases
column6: if the mother has an infection with no nipple cracks or ulcerations
column7: it is still safe to breastfeed the infant.

column1: Herpes infection of the nipple can go unnoticed because the lesions are small but usually are quite painful. Herpes in the newborn is a serious and sometimes fatal infection. Transmission of Hepatitis C and B to the infant can occur if the nipples are cracked.
Other infections can be transmitted through a break of the skin of the nipple and can infect the infant.
A nipple-sparing/subcutaneous mastectomy is a surgical procedure where breast tissue is removed
column2: but the nipple and areola are preserved. This procedure was historically done only prophylactically or with mastectomy for the benign disease over the fear of increased cancer development in retained areolar ductal tissue. Recent series suggest that it may be an oncologically sound procedure for tumours not in the subareolar position.

column1: The cultural tendency to hide the female nipple under clothing has existed in Western culture since the 1800s. As female nipples are often perceived an intimate part
column2: covering them might have originated under Victorian morality as with riding side saddle. Exposing the entire breast and nipple is a form of protest for some and a crime for others. The exposure of nipples is usually considered immodest and in some instances is viewed as lewd or indecent behavior.
Pennsylvania
column3: concerning the exposure of breasts and nipple proceeded to the United States Supreme Court. The Erie ordinance was regulating the nipple in public as an act that is committed when a person ""knowingly or intentionally
column4: ... appears in a state of nudity commits Public Indecency."" Later in the statute
column5: nudity is further described as an uncovered female nipple. But nipple exposure of a man was not regulated. An opinion column credited to Cecil Adams noted: ""Ponder the significance of that. A man walks around bare-chested and the worst that happens is he won't get served in restaurants. But a woman who goes topless is legally in the same boat as if she'd had sex in public. That may seem crazy
column6: but in the US it's a permissible law.""

column1: The legality around the exposure of nipples is inconsistently regulated throughout the US. Some states do not allow the visualization of any part of the breast. Other jurisdictions prohibit any female chest anatomy by banning anatomical structures that lie below the top of the areola or nipple. Such is the case in West Virginia and Massachusetts. West Virginia's regulation is very specific and is not likely to be misinterpreted
column2: stating: ""[The] display of 'any portion of the cleavage of the human female breast exhibited by a dress
column3: blouse
column4: skirt
column5: leotard
column6: bathing suit
column7: or other wearing apparel [is permitted] provided the areola is not exposed
column8: in whole or in part.'""

column1: The Instagram social media site has a ""no nipples"" policy with exceptions: material that is not allowed includes ""some photos of female nipples
column2: but photos of post-mastectomy scarring and women actively breastfeeding are allowed. Nudity in photos of paintings and sculptures is OK
column3: too"". Previously
column4: Instagram had removed images of nursing mothers. Instagram removed images of Rihanna and had her account cancelled in 2014 when she posted selfies with nipples. This was incentive for the Twitter campaign #FreeTheNipple. In 2016
column5: an Instagram page invited users to post images of nipples from both sexes; @genderless_nipples
column6: which displays close ups of both the nipples of men and women for the purpose of spotlighting what may be inconsistency. Some contributors have circumvented the policy. Facebook has also been struggling to define its nipple policy.

column1: Filmmaker Lina Esco made a film entitled Free the Nipple
column2: which is about ""laws against female toplessness or restrictions on images of female
column3: but not male
column4: nipples""
column5: which Esco states is an example of sexism in society.

column1: Nipples can be sensitive to touch
column2: and nipple stimulation can incite sexual arousal. Few women report experiencing orgasm from nipple stimulation. Before Komisaruk et al.'s functional magnetic resonance (fMRI) research on nipple stimulation in 2011
column3: reports of women achieving orgasm from nipple stimulation relied solely on anecdotal evidence. Komisaruk's study was the first to map the female genitals onto the sensory portion of the brain; it indicates that sensation from the nipples travels to the same part of the brain as sensations from the vagina
column4: clitoris and cervix
column5: and that these reported orgasms are genital orgasms caused by nipple stimulation
column6: and may be directly linked to the genital sensory cortex (""the genital area of the brain"").

column1: Some companies and non-profit organisations have used the word nipple or images of nipples to draw attention to their product or cause.

column4: tibia (shin bone)
column5: and adjacent fibula. The thigh is between the hip and knee
column6: while the calf (rear) and shin (front) are between the knee and foot.

column2: many forms of human movement
column3: recreation such as dancing
column4: and constitute a significant portion of a person's mass. Evolution has led to the human leg's development into a mechanism specifically adapted for efficient bipedal gait. While the capacity to walk upright is not unique to humans
column5: other primates can only achieve this for short periods and at a great expenditure of energy. In humans
column6: female legs generally have greater hip anteversion and tibiofemoral angles
column7: while male legs have longer femur and tibial lengths.

column2: the lower leg is the part of the lower limb that lies between the knee and the ankle. Anatomists restrict the term leg to this use
column3: rather than to the entire lower limb. The thigh is between the hip and knee and makes up the rest of the lower limb. The term lower limb or lower extremity is commonly used to describe all of the leg.

column1: The leg from the knee to the ankle is called the crus. The calf is the back portion
column2: and the tibia or shinbone together with the smaller fibula make up the shin
column3: the front of the lower leg.

column1: Evolution has provided the human body with two distinct features: the specialization of the upper limb for visually guided manipulation and the lower limb's development into a mechanism specifically adapted for efficient bipedal gait. While the capacity to walk upright is not unique to humans
column2: other primates can only achieve this for short periods and at a great expenditure of energy.

column1: The human adaption to bipedalism has also affected the location of the body's center of gravity
column2: the reorganization of internal organs
column3: and the form and biomechanism of the trunk. In humans
column4: the double S-shaped vertebral column acts as a great shock-absorber which shifts the weight from the trunk over the load-bearing surface of the feet. The human legs are exceptionally long and powerful as a result of their exclusive specialization for support and locomotion—in orangutans the leg length is 111% of the trunk; in chimpanzees 128%
column5: and in humans 171%. Many of the leg's muscles are also adapted to bipedalism
column6: most substantially the gluteal muscles
column7: the extensors of the knee joint
column8: and the calf muscles.

column1: The major bones of the leg are the femur (thigh bone)
column2: tibia (shin bone)
column3: and adjacent fibula
column4: and these are all long bones. The patella (kneecap) is the sesamoid bone in front of the knee. Most of the leg skeleton has bony prominences and margins that can be palpated and some serve as anatomical landmarks that define the extent of the leg. These landmarks are the anterior superior iliac spine
column5: the greater trochanter
column6: the superior margin of the medial condyle of tibia
column7: and the medial malleolus. Notable exceptions to palpation are the hip joint
column8: and the neck and body
column9: or shaft of the femur.

column2: the large joints of the lower limb are aligned in a straight line
column3: which represents the mechanical longitudinal axis of the leg
column4: the Mikulicz line. This line stretches from the hip joint (or more precisely the head of the femur)
column5: through the knee joint (the intercondylar eminence of the tibia)
column6: and down to the center of the ankle (the ankle mortise
column7: the fork-like grip between the medial and lateral malleoli). In the tibial shaft
column8: the mechanical and anatomical axes coincide
column9: but in the femoral shaft they diverge 6°
column10: resulting in the femorotibial angle of 174° in a leg with normal axial alignment. A leg is considered straight when
column11: with the feet brought together
column12: both the medial malleoli of the ankle and the medial condyles of the knee are touching. Divergence from the normal femorotibial angle is called genu varum if the center of the knee joint is lateral to the mechanical axis (intermalleolar distance exceeds 3 cm)
column13: and genu valgum if it is medial to the mechanical axis (intercondylar distance exceeds 5 cm). These conditions impose unbalanced loads on the joints and stretching of either the thigh's adductors and abductors.

column1: The angle of inclination formed between the neck and shaft of the femur (collodiaphysial angle) varies with age—about 150° in the newborn
column2: it gradually decreases to 126–128° in adults
column3: to reach 120° in old age. Pathological changes in this angle result in abnormal posture of the leg: a small angle produces coxa vara and a large angle coxa valga; the latter is usually combined with genu varum
column4: and coxa vara leads genu valgum. Additionally
column5: a line drawn through the femoral neck superimposed on a line drawn through the femoral condyles forms an angle
column6: the torsion angle
column7: which makes it possible for flexion movements of the hip joint to be transposed into rotary movements of the femoral head. Abnormally increased torsion angles result in a limb turned inward and a decreased angle in a limb turned outward; both cases resulting in a reduced range of a person's mobility.

column1: There are several ways of classifying the muscles of the hip:
By location or innervation (ventral and dorsal divisions of the plexus layer);
By development on the basis of their points of insertion (a posterior group in two layers and an anterior group); and

column2: flexors
column3: adductors
column4: and abductors).

column1: Some hip muscles also act either on the knee joint or on vertebral joints. Additionally
column2: because the areas of origin and insertion of many of these muscles are very extensive
column3: these muscles are often involved in several very different movements. In the hip joint
column4: lateral and medial rotation occur along the axis of the limb; extension (also called dorsiflexion or retroversion) and flexion (anteflexion or anteversion) occur along a transverse axis; and abduction and adduction occur about a sagittal axis.

column1: The anterior dorsal hip muscles are the iliopsoas
column2: a group of two or three muscles with a shared insertion on the lesser trochanter of the femur. The psoas major originates from the last vertebra and along the lumbar spine to stretch down into the pelvis. The iliacus originates on the iliac fossa on the interior side of the pelvis. The two muscles unite to form the iliopsoas muscle
column3: which is inserted on the lesser trochanter of the femur. The psoas minor
column4: only present in about 50 per cent of subjects
column5: originates above the psoas major to stretch obliquely down to its insertion on the interior side of the major muscle.

column1: The posterior dorsal hip muscles are inserted on or directly below the greater trochanter of the femur. The tensor fasciae latae
column2: stretching from the anterior superior iliac spine down into the iliotibial tract
column3: presses the head of the femur into the acetabulum but also flexes
column4: rotates medially
column5: and abducts to hip joint. The piriformis originates on the anterior pelvic surface of the sacrum
column6: passes through the greater sciatic foramen

column8: but it also assists extending the thigh. The gluteus maximus has its origin between (and around) the iliac crest and the coccyx
column9: from where one part radiates into the iliotibial tract and the other stretches down to the gluteal tuberosity under the greater trochanter. The gluteus maximus is primarily an extensor and lateral rotator of the hip joint
column10: and it comes into action when climbing stairs or rising from a sitting to a standing posture. Furthermore
column11: the part inserted into the fascia latae abducts and the part inserted into the gluteal tuberosity adducts the hip. The two deep glutei muscles
column12: the gluteus medius and minimus
column13: originate on the lateral side of the pelvis. The medius muscle is shaped like a cap. Its anterior fibers act as a medial rotator and flexor; the posterior fibers as a lateral rotator and extensor; and the entire muscle abducts the hip. The minimus has similar functions and both muscles are inserted onto the greater trochanter.

column1: The ventral hip muscles function as lateral rotators and play an important role in the control of the body's balance. Because they are stronger than the medial rotators
column2: in the normal position of the leg
column3: the apex of the foot is pointing outward to achieve better support. The obturator internus originates on the pelvis on the obturator foramen and its membrane
column4: passes through the lesser sciatic foramen
column5: and is inserted on the trochanteric fossa of the femur.  ""Bent"" over the lesser sciatic notch
column6: which acts as a fulcrum
column7: the muscle forms the strongest lateral rotators of the hip together with the gluteus maximus and quadratus femoris. When sitting with the knees flexed it acts as an abductor. The obturator externus has a parallel course with its origin located on the posterior border of the obturator foramen. It is covered by several muscles and acts as a lateral rotator and a weak adductor. The inferior and superior gemelli muscles represent marginal heads of the obturator internus and assist this muscle. These three muscles form a three-headed muscle (tricipital) known as the triceps coxae. The quadratus femoris originates at the ischial tuberosity and is inserted onto the intertrochanteric crest between the trochanters. This flattened muscle act as a strong lateral rotator and adductor of the thigh.

column1: The adductor muscles of the thigh are innervated by the obturator nerve

column3: and the adductor magnus which receives fibers from the tibial nerve. The gracilis arises from near the pubic symphysis and is unique among the adductors in that it reaches past the knee to attach on the medial side of the shaft of the tibia
column4: thus acting on two joints. It share its distal insertion with the sartorius and semitendinosus
column5: all three muscles forming the pes anserinus. It is the most medial muscle of the adductors
column6: and with the thigh abducted its origin can be clearly seen arching under the skin. With the knee extended

column8: rectangular in shape

column10: and an adductor and a weak medial rotator of the thigh. The adductor brevis originates on the inferior ramus of the pubis below the gracilis and stretches obliquely below the pectineus down to the upper third of the linea aspera. Except for being an adductor
column11: it is a lateral rotator and weak flexor of the hip joint.

column1: The adductor longus has its origin at superior ramus of the pubis and inserts medially on the middle third of the linea aspera. Primarily an adductor
column2: it is also responsible for some flexion. The adductor magnus has its origin just behind the longus and lies deep to it. Its wide belly divides into two parts: One is inserted into the linea aspera and the tendon of the other reaches down to adductor tubercle on the medial side of the femur's distal end where it forms an intermuscular septum that separates the flexors from the extensors. Magnus is a powerful adductor
column3: especially active when crossing legs. Its superior part is a lateral rotator but the inferior part acts as a medial rotator on the flexed leg when rotated outward and also extends the hip joint. The adductor minimus is an incompletely separated subdivision of the adductor magnus. Its origin forms an anterior part of the magnus and distally it is inserted on the linea aspera above the magnus. It acts to adduct and lateral rotate the femur.

column1: The muscles of the thigh can be classified into three groups according to their location: anterior and posterior muscles and the adductors (on the medial side). All the adductors except gracilis insert on the femur and act on the hip joint
column2: and so functionally qualify as hip muscles. The majority of the thigh muscles

column5: the extensors lie on anterior of the thigh and flexors lie on the posterior. Even though the sartorius flexes the knee
column6: it is ontogenetically considered an extensor since its displacement is secondary.

column1: Of the anterior thigh muscles the largest are the four muscles of the quadriceps femoris: the central rectus femoris

column4: medialis
column5: and lateralis. Rectus femoris is attached to the pelvis with two tendons

Fibers from the medial and lateral vasti form two retinacula that stretch past the patella on either sides down to the condyles of the tibia. The quadriceps is the knee extensor
column7: but the rectus femoris additionally flexes the hip joint

column1: There are four posterior thigh muscles. The biceps femoris has two heads: The long head has its origin on the ischial tuberosity together with the semitendinosus and acts on two joints. The short head originates from the middle third of the linea aspera on the shaft of the femur and the lateral intermuscular septum of thigh

column3: the long head extends the hip joint. The semitendinosus and the semimembranosus share their origin with the long head of the biceps

column6: and medial rotation of the leg. Distally

column1: Dorsiflexion (extension) and plantar flexion occur around the transverse axis running through the ankle joint from the tip of the medial malleolus to the tip of the lateral malleolus. Pronation (eversion) and supination (inversion) occur along the oblique axis of the ankle joint.
Three of the anterior muscles are extensors. From its origin on the lateral surface of the tibia and the interosseus membrane
column2: the three-sided belly of the tibialis anterior extends down below the superior and inferior extensor retinacula to its insertion on the plantar side of the medial cuneiform bone and the first metatarsal bone. In the non-weight-bearing leg
column3: the anterior tibialis dorsal flexes the foot and lifts the medial edge of the foot. In the weight-bearing leg

column5: and the interosseus membrane. At the ankle

column11: and acts similar to the tibialis anterior in the weight-bearing leg. Two muscles on the lateral side of the leg form the fibular (peroneal) group. The fibularis (peroneus) longus and fibularis (peroneus) brevis both have their origins on the fibula
column12: and they both pass behind the lateral malleolus where their tendons pass under the fibular retinacula. Under the foot

column2: the tibialis posterior has its origin on the interosseus membrane and the neighbouring bone areas and runs down behind the medial malleolus. Under the foot it splits into a thick medial part attached to the navicular bone and a slightly weaker lateral part inserted to the three cuneiform bones. The muscle produces simultaneous plantar flexion and supination in the non-weight-bearing leg

The flexor hallucis longus arises distally on the fibula and on the interosseus membrane from where its relatively thick muscle belly extends far distally. Its tendon extends beneath the flexor retinaculum to the sole of the foot and finally attaches on the base of the last phalanx of the hallux. It plantarflexes the hallux and assists in supination. The flexor digitorum longus

column1: The intrinsic muscles of the foot
column2: muscles whose bellies are located in the foot proper
column3: are either dorsal (top) or plantar (sole).

column2: two long extrinsic extensor muscles are superficial to the intrinsic muscles
column3: and their tendons form the dorsal aponeurosis of the toes. The short intrinsic extensors and the plantar and dorsal interossei radiates into these aponeuroses. The extensor digitorum brevis and extensor hallucis brevis have a common origin on the anterior side of the calcaneus
column4: from where their tendons extend into the dorsal aponeuroses of digits 1–4. They act to dorsiflex these digits.

column1: The plantar muscles can be subdivided into three groups associated with three regions: those of the big digit
column2: the little digit
column3: and the region between these two. All these muscles are covered by the thick and dense plantar aponeurosis
column4: which

column1: The abductor hallucis stretches along the medial edge of the foot
column2: from the calcaneus to the base of the first phalanx of the first digit and the medial sesamoid bone. It is an abductor and a weak flexor
column3: and also helps maintain the arch of the foot. Lateral to the abductor hallucis is the flexor hallucis brevis
column4: which originates from the medial cuneiform bone and from the tendon of the tibialis posterior. The flexor hallucis has a medial and a lateral head inserted laterally to the abductor hallucis. It is an important plantar flexor which comes into prominent use in classical ballet (i.e. for pointe work). The adductor hallucis has two heads; a stronger oblique head which arises from the cuboid and lateral cuneiform bones and the bases of the second and third metatarsals; and a transverse head which arises from the distal ends of the third-fifth metatarsals. Both heads are inserted on the lateral sesamoid bone of the first digit. The muscle acts as a tensor to the arches of the foot
column5: but can also adduct the first digit and plantar flex its first phalanx.

column1: The opponens digiti minimi originates from the long plantar ligament and the plantar tendinous sheath of the fibularis (peroneus) longus and is inserted on the fifth metatarsal. When present
column2: it acts to plantar flex the fifth digit and supports the plantar arch. The flexor digiti minimi arises from the region of base of the fifth metatarsal and is inserted onto the base of the first phalanx of the fifth digit where it is usually merged with the abductor of the first digit. It acts to plantar flex the last digit. The largest and longest muscles of the little toe is the abductor digiti minimi. Stretching from the lateral process of the calcaneus

column4: to the base of the fifth digit's first phalanx

column1: The four lumbricales have their origin on the tendons of the flexor digitorum longus
column2: from where they extend to the medial side of the bases of the first phalanx of digits two-five. Except for reinforcing the plantar arch
column3: they contribute to plantar flexion and move the four digits toward the big toe. They are
column4: in contrast to the lumbricales of the hand
