https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forearm|A01.378.800.585|D005542|Forearm|"The forearm is the region of the upper limb between the elbow and the wrist. The term forearm is used in anatomy to distinguish it from the arm
column2: a word which is used to describe the entire appendage of the upper limb
column3: but which in anatomy
column4: technically
column5: means only the region of the upper arm
column6: whereas the lower ""arm"" is called the forearm. It is homologous to the region of the leg that lies between the knee and the ankle joints
column7: the crus.

column1: The forearm contains two long bones
column2: the radius and the ulna
column3: forming the two radioulnar joints. The interosseous membrane connects these bones. Ultimately
column4: the forearm is covered by skin
column5: the anterior surface usually being less hairy than the posterior surface.

column2: including the flexors and extensors of the wrist
column3: flexors and extensors of the digits
column4: a flexor of the elbow (brachioradialis)
column5: and pronators and supinators that turn the hand to face down or upwards
column6: respectively. In cross-section
column7: the forearm can be divided into two fascial compartments. The posterior compartment contains the extensors of the hands
column8: which are supplied by the radial nerve. The anterior compartment contains the flexors and is mainly supplied by the median nerve. The flexor muscles are more massive than the extensors because they work against gravity and act as anti-gravity muscles. The ulnar nerve also runs the length of the forearm.

column1: The radial and ulnar arteries and their branches supply the blood to the forearm. These usually run on the anterior face of the radius and ulna down the whole forearm. The main superficial veins of the forearm are the cephalic
column2: median antebrachial and the basilic vein. These veins can be used for cannularisation or venipuncture
column3: although the cubital fossa is a preferred site for getting blood.

column1: The bones of the forearm are the radius (located on the lateral side) and the ulna (located on the medial side)

column2: the head of the radius articulates with the capitulum of the humerus and the radial notch of the ulna at the elbow. The articulation between the radius and the ulna at the elbow is known as the proximal radioulnar joint.
it articulates with the ulna again at the distal radioulnar joint. It forms part of the wrist joint by articulating with the scaphoid at its lateral aspect and with the lunate at its medial aspect.
the trochlear notch of the ulna articulates with the trochlea of the humerus and the radial notch articulates with the head of the radius at the elbow.

column1: Distally it forms part of the distal radioulnar joint and also articulates with the wrist.
E/I"" refers to ""extrinsic"" or ""intrinsic"". The intrinsic muscles of the forearm act on the forearm
column2: meaning
column3: across the elbow joint and the proximal and distal radioulnar joints (resulting in pronation or supination)
column4: whereas the extrinsic muscles act upon the hand and wrist. In most cases
column5: the extrinsic anterior muscles are flexors
column6: while the extrinsic posterior muscles are extensors.

column2: flexor of the forearm
column3: is unusual in that it is located in the posterior compartment
column4: but it is actually in the anterior portion of the forearm.

column1: The anconeus is considered by some as a part of the posterior compartment of the arm.

The forearm can be brought closer to the upper arm (flexed) and brought away from the upper arm (extended) due to movement at the elbow. The forearm can also be rotated so that the palm of the hand rotates inwards (pronated) and rotated back so that the palm rotates outwards (supinated) due to movement at the elbow and the distal radioulnar joint.
A fracture of the forearm can be classified as to whether it involves only the ulna (ulnar fracture)
column2: only the radius (radius fracture)
column3: or both radioulnar fracture.

column1: For treatment of children with torus fractures of the forearm splinting appears to work better than casting.

Genetically determined disorders like hereditary multiple exostoses can lead to hand and forearm deformities. Hereditary multiple exostoses is due growth disturbance of the epiphyses of the radius and ulna
column2: the two bones of the forearm.
